Skills Assessments

What are they

  • Independent exercises to review and solidify the concepts presented in the past week

  • Easy, medium, and hard questions

  • Take anywhere from 1 to >6 hours

  • Required â if you canât finish, please still turn it in

Goals of Skills Assessments

  • To help you reinforce what youâve learned

  • To help us understand how youâre doing with the material

  • To help you understand how youâre doing with the material

Format

  • When assigned, you will recieve links to

    • Directions

    • Materials (usually Python files; similar to lab exercises)

  • Types of questions will vary

How to Succeed

  • Do the Study Guide (in the Homework section on Frodo)

  • Read directions carefully

  • Complete the entire assessment

If you canât figure out a problem

  • Still try it out

  • Leave comments about ideas/problems

  • Write some pseudocode

If you submit your assessment with errors that prevent
tests or your code from running, itâs an automatic zero credit

Really make sure your code runs

Fix or comment out code that results in a syntax error

Always run your file right before you submit

Make sure the code you ran is the same as the one you submitted

What we look for

Completeness

  • Discussion questions (short answer)

  • Coding questions

Correctness

  • All tests pass

  • Code does what it is supposed to

Feel free to refer to your notes

Assessments are open-note and open-book, so feel free to refer to your lecture notes and handouts!

Other things we like to see

  • Pseudocode for problems you couldnât finish

  • Consistent expressiveness and readability

  • Appropriate use of data structures (where not already specified)

  • Use of intermediate/advanced concepts

  • Handling of compelling edge cases

  • Providing multiple appropriate solutions

Examples

Lacks Expressiveness, Bad Naming

def items(list):
    """Print all items."""

    for x in list:

        print(x)

Why?

list is an especially bad variable name; in using it, weâre overwriting the built-in list function in Python

Same goes for int, str, set, etc.

Shows Expressiveness, Good Naming

def print_animals(animals):
    """Prints each animal in a given list of animals."""

    for animal in animals:
        print(animal)

Lacks Directness

def is_cute(thing):
    """Determine whether thing is cute."""

    cuteness = False

    if thing == "cat":
        cuteness = True
    else:
        cuteness = False

    return cuteness

Getting More Direct

def is_cute(thing):
    """Determine whether thing is cute."""

    if thing == "cat":
        return True
    else:
        return False

Even More Direct

def is_cute(thing):
    """Determine whether thing is cute."""

    return thing == "cat"

Warning!

  • Short != Direct

  • Good code balances succinctness and expressiveness

Getting Started

The instructions for Skills 1 will walk you through this process in more detail

Find Assignment in Homework Section

Go to the Homework section on FRODO to find the skills assessment instructions

  • Download is a link to a .zip file with starter code

  • Instructions is a link to the assignment instructions

Create a Working Directory

Follow the setup instructions in Skills 1 to download your materials and create a working directory with git

Each assessment should have its own git repository and GitHub remote

Remember to Make a Private GitHub Repo

Remember to make a private GitHub repo to turn in your assessment

Donât forget to add the GitHub user, hackbright-grader, as a collaborator

Turning In Your Assessment

How to Submit

  • Youâll submit a link to your assessmentâs GitHub repository on Frodo

  • Your last commit before the deadline will be graded

  • If you miss the deadline, we still want you to complete the assessment!

    • Talk with your advisor if you need to make a late submission

On your student profile, youâll find a box called Assessments

Youâll use the âSkillsâ assessments to turn in your work.

Fill out the following sections.

GitHub Link and Duration in min are required.

Summary

Important Things to Remember

  • Assessments are for you

  • Show us your best effort, any way you can

  • Every part of the assessment is required

You will only get credit for:

  • Code committed before the deadline

  • Code that runs successfully

Collections

Review

Lists are mutable, iterable, and ordered.

What do these words mean?

  • Mutable
  • Iterable
  • Ordered

Goals

Learn about tuples and sets

More ways to work with collections:

  • Nested collections
  • Comprehensions

Tuples

Immutable, iterable, ordered

Often used for groupings of data with meaningful order

instance = ('Instance', 'gray', 2)
instance[1]          # => 'gray'

Making a tuple with one item in it

This is not a tuple:

x = (1)
type(x)    # => <class 'int'>

Python evaluates (<object>) like it would any other expression wrapped in parentheses.

If you need to make a single-item tuple, you can put a comma after the item, before closing the parentheses:

x = (1,)
type(x)   # => <class 'tuple'>

Lists vs. Tuples

Theyâre both iterable and ordered.

# a list
fruits = ['apple', 'berry', 'cherry']
fruits[0]    # => 'apple'

for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

# a tuple
fruit = ('ripe', 'Red Delicious')
fruit[0]     # => 'ripe'

for attribute in fruit:
    print(attribute)

Unlike lists, tuples are immutable

You canât modify a tuple, but you can create a new one

# t[0] = 'Instance'    ...doesn't work :(
t = ('Instance', 'gray', 2)

It is good practice to use tuples when you have a collection
of values that need to be together

Otherwise, just use a list!

Lists Tuples
mutable immutable
l[0] = 'Instance' t = ('Instance', 'gray', 2)
l.extend([3, 4]) t = t + (3, 4) creates new tuple; rebinds t
arbitrary lists collection of attributes

Sets

Mutable, iterable, unordered

Unique collection of items

Fast look-up (reason mysterious for now ð­)

Making a Set

moods = set(['happy', 'sad', 'cheerful'])

or:

moods = {'happy', 'sad', 'cheerful'}

(shorter but might get confused with dictionary syntax)

Pursuing Uniqueness

Starting with a non-unique group of items, we create a set.

moods = ['happy', 'sad', 'sad', 'cheerful', 'happy', 'sad']
moods = set(moods)

moods            # => {'happy', 'sad', 'cheerful'}
len(moods)       # => 3

In creating the set, the duplicates were removed. Sweet!

Iterable, but Unordered

>>> for mood in {'happy', 'sad', 'cheerful'}:
...     print(mood)
cheerful
happy
sad

Sets donât support indexing.

>>> moods[3]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: 'set' object does not support indexing

Changing Sets

moods.add('grumpy')

Notice the careful phrasing of this method! Itâs âaddâ, not âappendâ, because itâs not guaranteed to add items to the end. Sets are unordered, after all.

moods.remove('sad')

moods.pop()     # returns an item and removes it

moods.pop(0)    # error --- this is nonsensical!

zomg Set Math!

moods = {'happy', 'sad', 'grumpy'}
dwarfs = {'happy', 'grumpy', 'doc'}

moods | dwarfs  # {'happy', 'sad', 'grumpy', 'doc'}  # union
moods & dwarfs  # {'happy', 'grumpy'}                # intersection
moods ^ dwarfs  # {'sad', 'doc'}             # symmetric difference
moods - dwarfs  # {'sad'}
dwarfs - moods  # {'doc'}

Constructor Functions

  • list(), tuple(), set()
  • No arguments: creates an empty collection
  • With another collection as an argument, will return new collection with specified type
  • Only take one argument; i.e. list(1, 2, 3) will return an error.

Summary

Collections

  Ordered Mutable Unique Iterable
Lists â â no â
Tuples â no no â
Sets no â â â

Collections of Collections

animals = [ ('Instance', 'gray', 2),
            ('RAM', 'green', 3),
            ('Unicode', 'blue', 2) ]
  • animals[1]
    • ('RAM', 'green', 3)
  • animals[1][0]
    • 'RAM'
  • animals[2] = ('Unicode', 'blue', 2)
    • animals = [ ('Instance', 'gray', 2), ('RAM', 'green', 3), ('Unicode', 'blue', 2) ]
  • animals[2][2] = 1
    • TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment

Comprehensions

The Pattern

âGet a new list of these words, uppercasedâ

words = ["awesome", "alex", "orange", "ant", "deadly"]

upper_words = []
for word in words:
      upper_words.append(word.upper())

words = ["awesome", "alex", "orange", "ant", "deadly"]
upper_words = ["AWESOME", "ALEX", "ORANGE", "ANT", "DEADLY"]

List Comprehension

Super-simple syntax for same idea:

upper_words = [word.upper() for word in words]

âGet a new list of just the âaâ wordsâ

words = ["awesome", "alex", "orange", "ant", "deadly"]

a_words = []
for word in words:
    if word.startswith("a"):
        a_words.append(word)

a_words = [word for word in words if word.startswith("a")]

Syntax:

[word.upper() for word in words if word.startswith("a")]

[expression for item in list if condition]

[expression
 for item in list
 if condition]

Set Comprehension

Same idea but for sets:

big_states = set()
for population in US_STATES_POPULATIONS:
    if population > 1000000:
        big_states.add(population)

big_states = {population
              for population in US_STATES_POPULATIONS
              if population > 1000000}

What Did We Learn?

What Might You Use Forâ¦?

  • Items on a todo list
  • Statistics about a race (time to finish, winnerâs name, date)
  • Hackbright house names

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • Dictionaries
  • Linked Lists
  • Trees, Binary Trees
  • More information on âruntimeâ

Python Tools

Intro

Goals

  • What is Python and where does it come from?
  • How does Python work?
  • Learn how to use interactive mode
  • Alternative Python shells
  • Good Python style

Python

Strongly-typed, dynamic, high-level language

  • Strongly-typed: type of a value does not change
    • "1" does not become 1 magically
  • Dynamic: can create new types/structures as program runs
    • Instead of everything being done during a “compilation phase”
  • High-level: operates at higher levels of abstraction
    • Deal with lists and dictionaries, rather than arrays and pointers
    • Generally: faster to write code, slower for computer
    • Most modern programming happens this way

Friends and Frenemies

Low Level, static-typed:

  • C
  • C++
  • Go
  • Java

High Level, dynamic-typed:

  • Perl
  • Python
  • PHP
  • Ruby
  • Javascript

Where Does Python Come From?

Guido van Rossum

  • And â 450 other language contributors
  • Open Source product and community

Python Versions

Python 2

  • What most people still use

Python 3

  • Some significant changes in syntax
  • Becoming more widely adopted
  • Can learn the differences in a 1-2 days
  • Much larger project to upgrade an entire codebase from 2 â 3

How Does Python Work?

Python is Compiled

def add_two(x, y):
    total = x + y
    return total

Python compiles that, once, to opcodes:

2           0 LOAD_FAST                0 (x)
            3 LOAD_FAST                1 (y)
            6 BINARY_ADD
            7 STORE_FAST               2 (total)

3          10 LOAD_FAST                2 (total)
           13 RETURN_VALUE

It then runs those opcodes

Compilation and .pyc

Compilation is fast, but why compile twice if you don’t have to?

  • Python keeps a copy of the compiled source in a .pyc file
    • calculator.py â calculator.pyc
  • When you import calculator, Python looks for .pyc
    • If original .py file hasn’t changed, it uses .pyc
    • Otherwise, Python recompiles

.pyc in the Wild

Sometimes, people may only provide you with a .pyc file.

It’ll still be useable, but you won’t be able to read or edit the source code.

Modes

Running a Source File

$ python3 mygame.py
You win! Your score is 10

$ # back in shell
  • Runs Python
  • Loads mygame.py
  • Executes the code
  • Returns to the terminal when done.

Using Python Interactively

$ python3
>>> # waiting in Python console
  • Runs Python
  • Leaves you in the Python console
  • Allows you to execute Python expressions

Best of Both Worlds?

$ python3 -i mygame.py
You win! Your score is 10
>>> score
10
  • “Interactive Mode”
  • Runs Python, loads mygame.py
  • Runs your code
  • Returns you to Python console
    • All variables still in memory, all functions still defined

Play in the Console

It’s. The. Best. Way. To. Learn.

Good idea: open a console at the same time as your editor!

Getting Help

dir()

“Show me the methods and attributes of this object”

>>> dir([])
['__add__', 'append', 'count', 'extend', 'index', 'insert',
'pop', 'remove', 'reverse', 'sort']

__methods__

You’ll notice many objects provide a lot of methods that have names starting and ending with double-underscores (Python programmers often call these “special methods” or “dunder [for ‘double-underscore’] methods”.

These aren’t methods you call directly (i.e., if you had a list called fruits you wouldn’t ever say fruits.__add__()) — instead, these work behind-the-scenes to support other operations of the object.

Generally, you can ignore them when examining an object.

This works for custom objects, too:

>>> dir(some_kitten)
['cuddle', 'feed', 'name', 'pet', 'weight']

help()

“Show me help about how to use this object”

>>> help([])

Alternate Consoles

For interactive modes, there are better Pythons than python

IPython

  • Powerful & advanced
  • Commands for showing history & replaying
  • Can edit entire blocks of code at once
  • Especially useful for heavy interactive work
    • Like in data science or debugging

jupyter

  • Graphical shell for IPython
    • Especially useful for doing math/science work
    • Deep integration with numpy, matplotlib
  • Requires some effort — a great area for self-study

Style

Style Matters

“Style is character.”

— Joan Didion, The White Album

  • Well-styled code is easier to read
    • Faster to read
    • Skimming is more accurate
  • Well-styled code has fewer bugs
  • Companies are more likely to hire you

Tabs versus Spaces

Indenting in Python:

def invite_friends(friends):
    """Invite cool friends to party."""

    for friend in friends:
        if friend in cool_friends:
            email_invite(friend)
  • You can use spaces or tabs for indentation
  • Spaces are preferred in the Python world
  • Never mix and match them!
  • In Sublime: View â Indentation â Convert Indentation to Spaces

Line Lengths

Python doesn’t care about line length.

  • But long lines are hard to read

    • Official Python style guide uses 79 char. line limit

  • You can always break a line “inside of something”

    for animal in ["zebra", "dog", "pony",
               "balloonicorn", "fish", "lemur"]:

  • You can use parentheses to be “inside an expression”

    if (name == 'Balloonicorn'
    or animal_type == 'unicorn'
    or awesomeness_level >= 1000):

Can Also Use Backslashes

You can also break a line at any point by using a backslash (\) character but this must be the absolute last character of the line.

if name == 'Balloonicorn' or animal_type == 'unicorn' \
    or awesomeness_level >= 1000:

This is mildly discouraged, though, as it’s so easy to screw up—if you had a space after that backslash, it wouldn’t work, and this would raise a SyntaxError.

Space is Your Friend

  • Good style to put spaces around operators: if x == 9

  • Good style to divide “thoughts” with blank lines:

    for animal in animals:
     pet_animal(animal)

print("I'm done petting everything!")

  • Good style to put more blank lines between functions:

    def foo():
    print("foo")


def bar():
    print("bar")

Good Variable Names

  • Use snake_case for variables and functions
  • Function names should be “verby”
    • print_score, is_valid_zipcode, etc
  • Variable names should tell us what something is for, not what it is
    • fruits_for_sale not my_list

Good variable names hint at the data type of the variable

  • Use plural nouns for collections (lists, dictionaries, etc.)

    fruits = ["apple", "berry", "cherry"]
fruit_quantities = {"apple": 1}

  • Use singular nouns for everything else (integers, strings, etc.)

    fruit = "apple"
qty = 5

  • Common pattern — use singular version of collections’ names in for-loops:

    for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

Constants

If a variable should never change, give a hint!

Convention here is to write it in ALL_UPPER_CASE

FLAT_SHIPPING_COST = 5

def calculate_total_shipping(num_packages):
    """Return total cost of shipping."""

    return num_packages * FLAT_SHIPPING_COST


def explain_shipping():
    """Print explanation of shipping."""

    print(f"We charge ${FLAT_SHIPPING_COST} to ship packages.")

Docstrings

def calculate_order_cost(price, qty, tax):
    """Calculate and return total order cost.

    price: individual item cost
    qty: number of items
    tax: tax percentage as whole number (ie, 5 for 5%)

    Returns total order cost in US dollars.
    Does not include shipping.
    """
  • Always a one-line summary
    • This should never run more than one line
    • Use imperative language (use calculate, not calculates)
  • If more information is needed, separate with blank lines
  • Always use triple-quotes
    • Even for one-line docstrings (it’s considered conventional)

Comments vs Docstrings

def calculate_order_cost(price, qty, tax):
    """Calculate and return total order cost.

    Returns total order cost in US dollars.
    Does not include shipping.
    """

    # In July, we have a tax holiday
    if current_month == "July":
        tax = 0

    # ...
  • Docstrings tell you when and why to use a function
  • Comments tell you how it works on the inside
  • Docstrings are for users of your function
  • Comments are for maintainers of your function

Put Example Code in Docstrings!

def calculate_order_cost(price, qty, tax):
    """Calculate and return total order cost.

    price: individual item cost
    qty: number of items
    tax: tax percentage as whole number (ie, 5 for 5%)

    Returns total order cost in US dollars.
    Does not include shipping.

    For example:

      >>> calculate_order_cost(10, 5, 5)
      52.5
    """
  • Show other programmers how to use your function
  • Python can even test this for you!
    • python3 -m doctest yourfile.py

sys.argv

You can hard code info in a Python script:

for melon_data in open("melon-data.txt"):
    print(melon_data)

We want more flexibility:

$ python3 process.py melon-data.txt

import sys

filename = sys.argv[1]   # first real argument
for melon_data in open(filename):
    print(melon_data)
  • sys.argv is a list of things on command line
  • The first item (sys.argv[0] is the name of your script)

Everything is a String

Everything given on sys.argv is split on spaces and given as a string — so a line like:

$ python3 process.py hello 2 3

arrives in Python like ['process.py', 'hello', '2', '3'].

In addition, it splits things on spaces — so if you want the users to pass in a multi-word phrase as one argument, this should be given in quotes:

$ python3 process.py hi there "everyone in class"

arrives like ['process.py', 'hi', 'there', 'everyone in class']

The Zen of Python

>>> import this
The Zen of Python, by Tim Peters

Beautiful is better than ugly.
Explicit is better than implicit.
Simple is better than complex.
Complex is better than complicated.
Flat is better than nested.
Sparse is better than dense.
Readability counts.
Special cases aren't special enough to break the rules.
Although practicality beats purity.
Errors should never pass silently.
Unless explicitly silenced.
In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess.
There should be one-- and preferably only one --obvious way to do it.
Although that way may not be obvious at first unless you're Dutch.
Now is better than never.
Although never is often better than right now.
If the implementation is hard to explain, it's a bad idea.
If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea.
Namespaces are one honking great idea -- let's do more of those!

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • Debugging
  • Testing
  • Libraries / Importing
Important Policies

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Important Policies

« Back to Homepage

  • Important Policies
    • Ethics
      • General Ethics
      • Skills Assessments
      • Skills Assessments
    • Attendance
      • Attendance Policy Breakdown
      • Approved Absences
      • Normal Absences
      • Tardiness
    • Mental Health and Well-being
      • Mental Health and Well-being
      • When We Can’t Help

Important Policies

Ethics

General Ethics

Most important thing:

You can’t represent code that someone else wrote as your own.

  • When in doubt, cite your sources.
  • Include the URL of a stackoverflow post in a comment
  • Email your adviser or instructor a resource you used
  • Don’t ever copy/paste code and claim it as your own
  • Understand the code that you write

Skills Assessments

  • Not like normal programming where you have free roam on Google
  • Cannot use Stack Overflow, or any other non-documentation resources
    • Good to use: Python Docs, official documentation for specific topic
  • All answers can be found in the Hackbright curriculum
  • Open-note assessment
    • But you learn more if you don’t look at notes!
  • We test all solutions for originality
  • If you accidentally look at StackOverflow or some other non-doc or Hackbright resource, LET YOUR ADVISER KNOW
    • Email
    • Add comment to your code with link to resource
    • Add note when you turn in your assessment
    • Find a way!

Attendance

Attendance Policy Breakdown

No. Absences No. Tardies Action
1 whole day missed 1-2 tardy/leave early no action
2 whole days missed 3-4 tardy/leave early no action
3 whole days missed 5-6 tardy/leave early written warning
4 whole days missed 7-8 tardy/leave early out of compliance

Approved Absences

  • Prior approval granted for:
    • 1-2 day personal events that requires attendance
    • Pre-approved absences agreed to prior to admission into the program
  • Prior approval will not be granted for more than 2 absences unless those were agreed to prior to admission into the program
  • After 2 approved absences, any remaining days will count towards your remaining allocated absences

Normal Absences

  • No prior approval needed for these reasons:
    • Sickness
    • Personal emergency
    • Can’t come to class for some other reason
  • You must let us know within 12 hours of the lecture (or day) you are planning to miss
  • These absences will still count towards your remaining allocated absences

Tardiness

  • Tardiness is defined as not being at lecture when attendance is taken
  • Each tardy counts for a 1/2 absence (see attendance policy breakdown)
  • This means that 2 tardies == 1 day of class missed
  • Leaving early at any point in the day will constitute a tardy

Mental Health and Well-being

  • This is a stressful and exciting time!
    • Try to be conscious of your mental health & well-being through this transition
  • Extended absences due to health or well-being may impact your ability to finish the course – but we will be happy to have you defer to the next cohort if this occurs
    • This is rare but it happens
    • If you are concerned, please speak with your adviser immediately
  • If we do not hear from you within 3 hours of you not coming to class or responding to emails, we reserve the right to call your emergency contact
    • Please let the instructors know if you will be absent ASAP

When We Can’t Help

  • Advisers can help with stress, general strategizing about schedule, commute, and work life balance
  • We aren’t equipped, trained, or authorized to provide actual counseling, mental health treatment, or help with anxiety disorders.
  • We can help you get help if you need it, though

Mental Health Resources

  • MentalHealth.gov
  • UCSF Psychiatric Clinic
  • Berkeley Free Clinic
  • Well Clinic Sliding Scale Therapy
  • Dial 211
Skills Assessments and Lightning Talks

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Skills Assessments and Lightning Talks

« Back to Homepage

  • Skills Assessments and Lightning Talks
    • Skills Assessments
      • What are they
      • How to Submit
    • Lightning Talks
      • What are they
      • How to Prepare
      • Topics
      • Past Topics

Skills Assessments and Lightning Talks

Skills Assessments

What are they

  • Independent exercises to review and solidify the concepts presented in the past week
  • Easy, medium, and hard questions
  • Take anywhere from 1-6 hours
  • Required
  • If you can’t finish, please still turn it in.

How to Submit

  • Due by 9PM on the Sunday after it was assigned
  • Push to github, and submit link on FRODO on your student profile.
    • If you have any problems pushing to Github, email your adviser your solution by 9pm on Sunday.

Lightning Talks

What are they

  • Short, 8-minute presentation on a technology
  • Practice talking about technology
  • Talk about something you know about, or something you did some research on and want to share

How to Prepare

  • Get your topic approved by your adviser
  • Add your topic to your Student Profile on FRODO
  • Research!
  • Make a short slidedeck and upload this to FRODO
    • Must present from PDF – no fancy transitions, please.

Topics

  • Remember, you only have 8 minutes.
  • Can be something you might want to use for your project
    • A python or javascript library
    • An API (such as Facebook, Pinterest, Twitter, Amazon)
  • Can be a tool or customization for your development environment
    • Difftools for git
    • Bash prompt customization
    • Text editor shortcuts! Command line shortcuts!
  • Can be something you’re excited to learn how to do
    • Web scraping
    • Advanced linux commands

Past Topics

  • How to use grep on the command line
  • Web Requests: GET vs. POST
  • Advanced CSS selectors
  • The Heartbleed Bug (SSL)

Not so great topics:

  • machine learning
  • another programing language
Dictionaries

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Dictionaries

« Back to Homepage

Dictionaries

The Situation

So We Opened an Animal Sanctuary

Species Number
Goats 6
Ponies 1
Ducks 14

How can we hold the data for our animal roster?

So far we have numbers, strings, lists, and tuples.

Parallel Lists

animal_types  = ['goat', 'pony', 'duck']
animal_counts = [6,      1,       14   ]

How would we use Python to figure out the amount of ducks on our farm?

How Many Ducks?

animal_types  = ['goat', 'pony', 'duck']
animal_counts = [6,      1,       14]

Wouldn’t It Be Nice...

... if we could get the ‘duckth’ element?

>>> animals['duck']
14

Dictionaries

aka hashmap, hash, map, associative array

A collection of key-value pairs

A dictionary by any other language would still be a dictionary.

Dictionaries go by many names in other programming languages. If you explore other languages, you’ll find out that the concept of dictionaries is a pretty common one.

Lists
data = [
    value1,
    value2,
    value3,
]
Dictionaries
data = {
    key1: value1,
    key2: value2,
    key3: value3,
}

Why Use Dictionaries?

How dictionaries differ from lists:

  • Index using keys instead of numbers
    • “Get the item stored at 'duck'” instead of “get the third item”
  • Lookup time is very fast
    • We can find out if 'duck' is in the dictionary right away; lists have to loop through each item, one-by-one

Lookup Time with Lists vs. Dictionaries

Lists are like decks of cards.

How would you search a deck of cards for the Queen of Hearts? You would have to look at each card, one at a time.

This is exactly what Python does when you check if something is in a list:

>>> if 'Queen of Hearts' in cards:
...     print('Took a while to find it...')
...
Took a while to find it...

Dictionaries are like... dictionaries.

How would you look up the word, “queen”, in a dictionary? You wouldn’t have to look at every page in the dictionary! Since dictionaries store words in alphabetical order, you could just flip to the correct page.

>>> if 'queen' in english_dictionary:
...     print('Found it right away!')
...
Found it right away!

Therefore

Let’s store our animal roster as a dictionary

Dictionaries Cheatsheet

Creating

An empty dictionary:

lists
>>> animal_types = []
dictionaries
>>> animals = {}

With initial content:

lists
>>> animal_types = ['goat', 'pony', 'duck']
dictionaries
>>> animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}

Getting Values

Index into the dictionary with the key you want to access

>>> animals['duck']
14

Adding/Updating

The same syntax is used to add/update values in a dictionary

If the key exists, the value is updated

>>> animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}

>>> animals['pony'] = 2

>>> animals
{'goat': 6, 'pony': 2, 'duck': 14}

If the key doesn’t exist, the value is added

>>> animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}

>>> animals['rabbit'] = 1

>>> animals
{'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14, 'rabbit': 1}

Deleting Items

Use the del keyword to delete a key-value pair

>>> animals
{'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14, 'rabbit': 1}

>>> del animals['rabbit']

>>> animals
{'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}

Keys and Values as Expressions

You can use variables instead of literal values

>>> key = 'rabbit'
>>> value = 3

>>> animals[key] = value

Iterating

Iterating over dictionaries gets each key

>>> animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}
>>> for animal in animals:
...     print(animal)
...
goat
pony
duck

Checking for Existence of Keys

Use the in keyword to check if a key is in the dictionary

>>> animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}
>>> if 'duck' in animals:
...     print('found duck WICKED FAST!')
...
found duck WICKED FAST!

The Rules

Keys Must Be Unique

There can only be one value for a key.

Trying to ‘add it a second time’ updates value for that key.

>>> animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}
>>> animals['duck']
14

>>> animals['duck'] = 2
>>> animals
{'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 2}

Keys Must Be Immutable

Mutable Types

  • lists
  • dictionaries
  • sets

Immutable Types

  • numbers
  • strings
  • tuples

Using a mutable data type results in a TypeError

>>> animals[['mule', 'donkey']] = 3
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'

Hashing

In order to store a value in a dictionary (or a set), Python creates a ‘hash’ of it. This is a numeric value that roughly corresponds to the value. It uses this hash to quickly look up the value in the dictionary.

Since lists (and other mutable things) can change, Python refuses to hash them — as a hash of the list ['pig', 'duck'] wouldn’t be the same hash if you mutated the list into``[‘pig’, ‘duck’, ‘porcupine`]``.

You can play with Python’s hash function by trying it out:

>>> hash('hello')
840651671246116861

>>> hash(('my', 'tuple'))
-3582301512568096774

>>> hash(['my', 'list'])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'

(You may get different hash values than those shown here. That’s fine.)

What if Key not in Dictionary?

Attempting to index into a dictionary with a nonexistant key results in a KeyError

>>> animals['porcupine']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
KeyError: 'porcupine'

Checking for a key is okay though

>>> 'porcupine' in animals
False

We can also avoid a KeyError with dict.get

>>> animals.get('porcupine', 0)
0

The Dictionary API

dictionary.get()

Python Docs: dict.get

>>> animals.get('porcupine', 0)
0

>>> animals.get('porcupine') is None
True

dictionary.keys()

Python Docs: dict.keys

>>> animals.keys()
dict_keys(['goat', 'pony', 'duck'])

>>> for animal in animals.keys():
...     print(animal)
...
goat
pony
duck

dictionary.values()

Python Docs: dict.values

>>> animals.values()
dict_values([6, 1, 14])

>>> for number in animals.values():
...     print(number)
...
6
1
14

dictionary.items()

Python Docs: dict.items

>>> animals.items()
dict_items([('goat', 6), ('pony', 1), ('duck', 14)])

>>> for animal, number in animals.items():
...    print(f'{animal}: {number}')
...
goat: 6
pony: 1
duck: 14

No Sort Method

Dictionaries can’t sort themselves in place.

Python doesn’t have a dict.sort method

>>> animals.sort()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'sort'

... but sorted (the built-in function) still works!

>>> sorted(animals)         # turns keys into list then sorts
['duck', 'goat', 'pony']

Remember, sorted will not mutate the dictionary.

Dictionaries are not ordered (kinda)

In Python 3.6, dictionaries are insertion ordered, but this is just a coincidence due to how dictionaries are implemented.

Since we can’t rely on coincidences, don’t count on the possibility that a dictionary’s keys are ordered in your code.

Nested Collections

More Data

Remember our animals dictionary?

animals = {'goat': 6, 'pony': 1, 'duck': 14}

We want to store more information:

  • still want number of animals
  • plus type of feed
  • plus if they bite

With Tuples as Values

Tuples can store data with a meaningful order

animals = {
    'goat': (6, 'everything', True),
    'pony': (1, 'hay and oats', True),
    'duck': (14, 'pond muck', False)
}

How do we check if ponies bite?

>>> animals['pony'][2]
True

With Dictionaries as Values

With dictionaries, we don’t have to remember the position of each piece of information

animals = {
    'goat': {
        'number': 6,
        'feed': 'everything',
        'bites': True
    },
    'pony': {
        'number': 1,
        'feed': 'hay and oats',
        'bites': True
    },
    'duck': {
        'number': 14,
        'feed': 'pond muck',
        'bites': False
    },
}

How do we check if ponies bite?

>>> animals['pony']['bites']
True

Using Dictionaries

Creating Dictionaries

Before creating a dictionary, think about:

  • How do I want to access my data — what are the keys?
  • What data do I want to store — what are the values?

When to Use Dictionaries?

When is a dictionary more advantageous than a list?

  • When you want to store information that is accessible by key
    • animal name â data
    • first letter of string â list of words with that first letter
    • word â its opposite
  • Counting

Counting with Dictionaries

We want the # of each letter in this phrase:
'delicious knishes'

How can dictionaries help us?

  • Take advantage of key uniqueness
  • What to use for keys? values?
dict-1-demo/lettercount.py
def make_letter_counts_dict(phrase):
    """Return dict of letters and # of occurrences in phrase."""

    letter_counts = {}

    for letter in phrase:
        letter_counts[letter] = letter_counts.get(letter, 0) + 1

    return letter_counts

Resources

If You Didn’t Get to It

How to Think Like a Computer Scientist has an excellent introduction.

Coming Up

  • Lots of examples of using dictionaries
  • How dictionaries are implemented

Advanced Self-Study

Dictionary comprehensions

Shell 2: Additional Tools

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Shell 2: Additional Tools

      • Looking Ahead

Shell 2: Additional Tools

Goals

  • Learn useful shortcuts for Sublime Text and Shell
  • Learn about UNIX terminal input/output
  • Learn how to keep things secret out of Git

Agenda

  • Sublime Text & Shell keyboard shortcuts
  • Useful UNIX command-line programs
  • Standard input & output
  • Shell pipelines and redirection
  • Shell environment & environmental variables
  • Keeping secret things out of Git

Sublime Shortcuts

CTRL-/ : Comment/Uncomment

  • Applies to:
    • selected line(s)
    • if nothing selected: current line
  • Comments correctly for language you’re using
  • Toggles comment / uncomment

CTRL-] and CTRL-[ : Indent/Dedent

  • Applies to selected lines(s) or current line
  • CTRL-] will indent
  • CTRL-[ will dedent

Other useful keyboard shortcuts for Sublime:

  • CTRL-L: Select current line
    • Press it repeatedly to select many lines
  • CTRL-F: Find
  • CTRL-SHIFT-F: Find and replace
  • CTRL-G: Go to line number
    • Particularly useful when a Python error references a line number.
  • CTRL-TAB: Go to next tab
    • When you’ve got a bunch of Sublime tabs open and don’t want to reach for your mouse.

Shell Shortcuts

Reminder of useful shortcuts:

  • Tab: complete word
  • Up Arrow / Down Arrow: navigate history

Line Editing

  • <CTRL-A>: go to beginning of line
  • <CTRL-E>: Go to end of line
  • <CTRL-D>: Delete forward
  • There are many others, but these are the most immediately useful.

Useful UNIX Utilities

Print File: cat

Prints entire contents of file:

$ cat foods
apple
cherry
hummus
... entire contents of file ...

Top of File: head

Prints first 10 lines of file:

$ head foods
apple
cherry
hummus
durian
jackfruit
eggplant
ice cream
fennel
gelato
berry

Can specify number of lines with -n

$ head -n 1 foods
apple

Bottom of File: tail

Prints last 10 lines of file:

$ tail foods
jackfruit
eggplant
ice cream
fennel
gelato
berry
jackfruit
matzo ball
kimchee
lemon

Can specify number of lines with -n

$ tail -n 1 foods
lemon

Tail is especially useful for logging files, which add new output at the bottom.

Another useful option is -f. This prints the bottom 10 lines and continues running without returning to the shell. As new lines get added to the file, they’ll be printed. This is particularly helpful when seeing what gets added to a logging file as you do work in another terminal window.

Length of File: wc

Prints line, words, and byte length of file:

$ wc foods
      14      16     111 foods       # 14 lines, 16 words, 111 bytes

Sort File: sort

Prints file with lines sorted:

$ sort foods
apple
berry
cherry
durian
eggplant
... rest of file, sorted ...

Doesn’t change file — just prints sorted version

Input and Output

Standard Input

  • Often called stdin
  • Where input comes from
  • By default, this is user at keyboard
shell-2-demo/greet.py
"""Greet user and print welcome."""

fname = input("First Name? ")
lname = input("Last Name? ")

print("Hi {fname} {lname}".format(fname=fname, lname=lname))

Standard Output

  • Often called stdout
  • Where print statements go to
  • By default, this is printed to shell

In shell, use echo

$ echo "Hello, Hackbright"
Hello, Hackbright

In Python, use print:

>>> print("Hello, Hackbright")
Hello, Hackbright

Standard Error

  • Often called stderr
  • Where error messages go
  • By default, also printed to shell

Shell commands use this for errors

$ ls nonexistent
ls: nonexistent: No such file or directory

To do in Python:

>>> import sys
>>> print("Oh No", file=sys.stderr)
Oh No

Interactive Input

Some programs that take a filename argument use stdin if no file given:

$ wc
Hello Jane
Hi
<Control-D>   # <Control-D> means "end-of-file" in UNIX
2     3     14

We’ll see in a minute how useful this can be!

Redirecting Input/Output

Redirecting Output

You can “redirect” standard output to a file with >:

$ sort foods > sorted_foods
  • Don’t see the output on the terminal anymore
  • Instead, sorted_foods contains the output

In particular, there’s one place Python programmers will use this often: there’s a command, pip3 freeze, which lists installed Python libraries, and you’ll often want to save the output of this command to the file requirements.txt. Therefore, you’ll use this redirection often:

$ pip3 freeze > requirements.txt

You can “redirect” standard output to append to a file with >>:

$ wc foods >> sorted_foods
  • Don’t see the output on the terminal anymore
  • Instead output added to end of sorted_foods

Redirecting Standard Error

It’s less common to want to redirect the standard error (you often want to see errors in the terminal), but you can do so by putting 2 in front of the redirection operator: command 2> errors will write any error messages to errors and command 2>> errors will append any error messages to errors.

Redirecting Input

You can “redirect” standard input from a file with <:

shell-2-demo/greet.py
"""Greet user and print welcome."""

fname = input("First Name? ")
lname = input("Last Name? ")

print("Hi {fname} {lname}".format(fname=fname, lname=lname))

$ cat names
Jane
Smith

$ python3 greet.py < names
First Name? Last Name? Hi Jane Smith

This is very useful for testing interactive programs!

Redirecting Input and Output

Can even do both at once:

$ python3 greet.py < names > outfile

$ cat outfile
First Name? Last Name? Hi Jane Smith

Pipelines

You can feed standard output of one program into another as standard input:

$ head -n 2 foods | python3 greet.py
First Name? Last Name? Hi apple cherry

$ head -n 2 foods | python3 greet.py | wc
1       7      39

Finding Things

Filename “Globbing”

You can use * to match filenames:

$ ls *.py
charge.py
greet.py

$ mv temp-*.txt backups/

There are many other parts to globbing than just the * though it is the most useful. You can read info on advanced filename globbing.

It is not recommended that you use filename globbing when you do a git add. You might accidentally add something you didn’t mean to. Better to add one file at a time.

Searching In Files: grep

Search for text within files.

$ grep print greet.py
"""Greet user and print welcome."""
print("Hi {fname} {lname}".format(fname=fname, lname=lname))

Other Uses of Grep

You can use a “filename glob” to search a file pattern.

If you do, it shows which file contains each line:

$ grep my_variable_name *.py
script.py:for my_variable_name in text:
script.py:    print(my_variable_name)

$ grep -l my_variable_name *.py
myscript.py

You can use the -r flag to recursive look in a directory and everywhere below it. This is very useful when searching an entire project for a particular bit of text:

$ grep -r Jane data/
data/sales.txt:Jane Smith
data/sales.txt:Jane Brown
data/2014/invoices.txt:Jessica Jane Jones: $200

Pipelines Using Grep

Grep is very useful in pipelines:

$ python3 sales.py | grep "Watermelons"
Delivered 10 Watermelons for total of $22.50
Delivered 1 Watermelons for total of $2.25

Shell Environment

  • The shell has an “environment” of variables
  • Many variables are already set, but you can add/change these

Viewing Environmental Variables

To view all environmental variables, use env

$ env
SHELL=/bin/bash
USER=jane
HOME=/Users/jane
PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
...

To view an individual variable, use echo $VARNAME

$ echo $SHELL
/bin/bash

Shell Path

PATH is an environment variable used to find programs.

Q: When you run python3, where does the shell look for this?

A: It looks in the $PATH

$ echo $PATH
/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin

The shell will search the PATH value from left to right, and stop when it finds the first path containing the command. If it never finds the command, it will return command not found.

Finding Commands: which

Where will my shell find python3? Ask the program which:

$ which python3
/usr/bin/python3

Settings Environmental Variables

You can set or change an environmental variable with export:

$ export MY_VARIABLE='my_value'

$ env | grep MY_
MY_VARIABLE=my_value

Note that it is not legal syntax to have spaces around the equal sign.

It’s legal to use single or double quotes here, but there is a difference — double quotes “expand shell metacharacters”. That is, if you use special symbols in a double-quoted string, the shell will try to interpret them. Until you learn what these are and know that you need them, its safer to use single quotes. This way, the value you’re setting will be exactly what you think it is.

Setting Variables Every Time

Note that environmental variables aren’t permanent – they’re only being set for this shell and any program that this shell starts. So, if you set an environmental variable in a terminal window and then open a new window, it won’t be set in that second window.

You can set in that window with the same command, of course. This can be tedious if you always want this variable set.

Therefore, the shell has a file in every user’s home directory called .bashrc. It always runs this file when starting a new shell.

To have something happen every time you start a shell, edit the file called ~/.bashrc and add your command at the bottom.

Be extra cautious when editing this file — everything you do here is run when you open a new shell, so errors here may be more difficult to fix.

On non-Linux systems, like OSX or Windows, this file may have another name, like ~/.bash_profile or ~/.profile. There are subtle differences here, so you should learn about the differences before editing these files except on Linux.

Environmental Variables and Python

Python can see the environmental variables it got from the shell:

$ export NAME="Jane"

$ python3
>>> import os
>>> os.environ['NAME']
'Jane'

The os.environ object is a dictionary — so you can use dictionary methods like .get(), .keys(), etc on it.

You can change the values in os.environ or add new values, but these values will only last as long as your Python script is running. When Python quits back to the shell, the changes will be lost.

Keeping Secret Things Safe

Don’t put secret things into Python scripts:

CREDIT_CARD = "1234-5678-1234-1234"

def charge_card(amt, card):
    # ...

charge_card(100, CREDIT_CARD)

When you check this into Git and push to GitHub, anyone could see it!

Use Environmental Variables

Better: set an environmental variable in the shell:

import os

CREDIT_CARD = os.environ['CREDIT_CARD']

Then, you can export that env var before running your script:

$ export CREDIT_CARD='1234-1234-1234-1234'

$ python3 charge.py
Charging $100 to 1234-1234-1234-1234

Automating Environmental Variables

It’s a pain to create that variable every time you open a shell.

So: put it in a “shell script” (conventionally called secrets.sh):

shell-2-demo/secrets.sh
export CREDIT_CARD="4444 4444 4444 4444"
export PASSWORD="blah blah"

You read those variables into your shell with source:

$ source secrets.sh

$ echo $CREDIT_CARD
1234-1234-1234-1234

$ python3 charge.py
Charging $100 to 1234-1234-1234-1234

The source Command

When you source a file that contains environment variables from the command line, those variables are available only in that shell. If you open a new shell and want to use the same variables in that new shell, you need to run the source command again in the new shell.

Telling Git To Ignore Files

Of course, if we check secrets.sh into Git, that’s terrible!

You could just try to remember to not add it, but it’s too easy to forget.

Instead: we’ll tell Git to ignore that file

Git looks in a file called .gitignore for files to ignore

You should create or edit this file to tell it to ignore files.

So, at root of your project, subl .gitignore and add “secrets.sh”

Good Things to Ignore

  • secrets.sh or any other file containing passwords/secrets/tokens
  • Notes you don’t want others to see
  • Python virtual environment directory
  • Python .pyc files
  • Any crufty files your editor or operating system makes
    • eg, Mac Finder can create a pointless file called .DS_Store

Example .gitignore File

You can use file glob * in your .gitignore:

$ cat .gitignore
*secret.*
env
*.pyc
.DS_Store

Using Git Status

Before:

$ git status

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

      secrets.sh
      env/
      script.pyc

$ subl .gitignore     # add to .gitignore

$ git status
On branch master
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/master'.
nothing to commit, working tree clean

Do This First!

Warning: once you’ve put something in Git, it’s never gone

Even if you delete it and commit that deletion — it’s still in the history

If you push that commit to GitHub, someone will find it

Always be careful when using git add

Add files to .gitignore as soon as you make them so you don’t forget to later!

Looking Ahead

  • Self-study: Writing Shell Scripts
Markov Chains

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Markov Chains

      • Example: @KimKierkagaard
      • Example: Calvin and Markov
      • Example: Music Generation

      • Let’s Break Down Our Marketing Copy

      • These Bigrams Are the Keys to Our Dictionary
      • The Values Are the Words that Follow the Key

Markov Chains

Goals

  • Learn about “markov chains” and an algorithm for how to use them
  • Understand goal of the markov-chains lab

Background

Markov Chains

  • Process that moves between states with different probabilities
  • Used to create plausible models based on data

Used in finance, healthcare, chemistry, Google search, genetics,
baseball analysis, algorithmic music composition...

Here’s an excellent visual example.

Marketing Panic!

Squysh Poached Our Social Media Intern

You have:

  • Loads of marketing copy
  • No time for Mel’s B.S.
  • Python!

Use Marketing Copy to Make New Copy

  • Just picking words at random makes gibberish
  • Using word patterns in copy makes more realistic output

These Word Patterns Are Called n-grams

  • n-gram is a sequence of n words
  • Constructed from a text
  • Can be thought of as the links in a chain
  • We’ll see how to make n-grams in a bit

Use n-grams to Make New Text

By analyzing the n-grams and listing which words most often follow
a given n-gram, we can construct new text that sounds like the source text.

Example: @KimKierkagaard

Example: Calvin and Markov

Credit: Calvin and Markov

Example: Music Generation

The Eternal Jukebox

Breaking Text Into n-grams

Let’s Break Down Our Marketing Copy

Would you could you in a house?
Would you could you with a mouse?
Would you could you in a box?
Would you could you with a fox?
Would you like them, Sam I Am?

Visualization

Would you could you in a house?
Would you could you with a mouse?

Would you could you in a house?
Would you could you with a mouse?
Would you could you in a box?
Would you could you with a fox?
Would you like them Sam I am?

Make Bigrams (Two Word Phrases)

Let’s break down the first line:

Would you could you in a house?

Would you
you could
could you
you in
in a
a house?

Find Unique Bigrams

Would you (5x)      you could (4x)      could you (4x)
you in (2x)         in a (2x)           a house? (1x)
you with (2x)       with a (2x)         a mouse? (1x)
a box? (1x)         a fox? (1x)         you like (1x)
like them (1x)      them Sam (1x)       Sam I (1x)
I am? (1x)

Also: bigrams breaking lines:

house? would (1x)      mouse? would (1x)
box? would (1x)        fox? would (1x)

These Bigrams Are the Keys to Our Dictionary

Dictionary keys must be:

  • Immutable
  • Unique

The Values Are the Words that Follow the Key

chains = {
    ("Would", "you,"): ["could", "could", "could", "could", "like"],
    ("you,", "could"): ["you", "you", "you", "you"],
    ("could", "you"):  ["in", "with", "in", "with"],
    ("you", "in"):     ["a", "a"],
    ("in", "a"):       ["house?", "box?"],
    # ...
    ("Sam", "I"):      ["am"]
}

Putting it Back Together

Step 1: Pick a Starting Point

Pick a random key from your dictionary

("could", "you")

our_string = "could you"

Step 2: Choose Your Next Word

{("could", "you"): ["in", "with", "in", "with"]}

Choosing randomly, we have a 50% chance of “in” and a 50% chance of “with”.

Let’s say we randomly choose “in”.

our_string = "could you in"

Step 3: Make a New Key, Choose a New Word

Take 2nd word of your previous key, and your newly chosen word,
and use that as your new key.

current_key = ("could", "you")
chosen_word = "in"
new_key = ("you", "in")

{("you", "in"): ["a", "a"]}

Now, both follow words are the same — but we can still pick a “random one”.

our_string = "could you in a"

Step 4: Rinse, Repeat

Repeat process until you make a key not in your dictionary
(this will mean you’ve reached the end of the source text)

Things to Think About

Punctuation and Capitalization

  • Leaving your text as-is initially is simpler
  • Leaving your text as-is will generate more English-like output
  • Leaving your text as-is will allow for adding other features later

How You Read in the Text Matters

If you read in your source text line-by-line, it’s more difficult to process.

If you read in the entire text at once, you don’t need to worry about
what happens at the line breaks in the original text.

We Have Provided You with a Framework

  • Use it!
  • If you don’t understand it, ask!
  • Get one function working at a time. Test it as you go!

Projects: Demos

Overview

The Goal

See examples of successful, reasonably-scoped past Hackbright projects.

Scene Francisco

  • Student loved living in the Bay Area and watching movies with scenes displaying well-known San Francisco landmarks
  • Used San Francisco Film Commission data and Google Maps
  • Very well-scoped MVP: view a list of movies, view list of filming locations for each movie
  • Many second possibilities:
    • searching and filtering movies, locations
    • map of locations for each movie
    • plan a walking route to see some locations

Netflix and Chow

  • Student wanted to eliminate the debate over what’s for dinner and what to watch
  • Picks food to be delivered and movie to watch based on your location and video service
  • Used Delivery.com and Guidebox.com APIs

Landfill Database

  • Student was interested in using data on waste
  • Used the EPA’s Landfill Methane Outreach Program
  • Displayed data by location using Google Maps API and JavaScript graphing libraries (Chart.js and Plotly.js)

Hamildata

  • Student wanted to use lyrics from the musical Hamilton and visualize connections across songs
  • Used D3 for data visualization

LGBT MD

  • Student wanted to create an interactive resource to address the problem of finding a medical provider that is trustworthy and knowledgable about LGBT issues
  • Data came from Health Professionals Advancing LGBT Equality (GLMA), a non-profit organization of LGBT medical providers
  • MapBox for maps

Not Clothes Minded

  • Student loved wearing vintage dresses, hated searching for ones in her size
  • Used Etsy API and Python library

WikiGraph

  • Answers the question, How many clicks between one topic on Wikipedia and another?
  • Used Wikipedia data and D3 for data visualization

Rideminder

  • Student wanted an app that would send the user an alert on public transit when they were approaching their destination
  • Used Transit Open Data Sets from Firebase and Google Map Directions

More

Organizing Python Projects

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Organizing Python Projects

      • dunder-name-equals-dunder-main

      • Organizing Your Code
