Organizing Python Projects

Our Goals

Goals

  • How can I organize my code?
  • How should I organize my code?
  • What’s a “library,” anyway?
  • Python virtual environments

Using Modules to Organize Code

Modules

  • You don’t want all of your code in one file.

    • That file would be huge.
    • You would have to copy-paste standard Python code to use, say, random

Enter Modules

  • A module is importable python code from a file

  • Example filenames: cupcakes.py, cupcakes.pyc or others

  • You reference the module without the filename suffix:

    import cupcakes

  • (more on import in a bit)

Some possible filename extensions and their meanings:

  • cupcakes.py: Python source code
  • cupcakes.pyc: Compiled Python source code
  • cupcakes.pyo: Optimized compiled Python source code
  • cupcakes.pyd: Compiled C importable by Python

Namespaces

  • Namespace is the menu of identifiers available for use

  • For example, if you type

    cupcake_flavor = 'chocolate'

    or

    def decorate_cupcake(cupcake):
  """Add icing, sprinkles and candies."""

    you are adding cupcake_flavor or decorate_cupcake to your namespace.

Import

Three Ways to Import

  1. import module
import random

# now we can use stuff in random, like random.choice()
  • Pulls random module into our namespace
  • Can then refer to random.choice
  1. from module import item
from random import choice

# now can talk about choice() -- but not other stuff in random
  • Pulls just choice into our namespace
    • But can’t refer to it as random.choice
  1. from module import *
from random import *

  • Imports everything inside random directly in

  • So we can talk about choice, randint, etc

    • But not random.choice, etc

  • Generally not a good idea

    seed = "sesame"

from random import *

# what's the value of seed?

Import As

Example: Web servers and databases both have something called a session.

But they’re different things (they just use the same name, grrr)

So we can’t:

from flask import session
from database import session  # this overwrites session

But we could:

import flask
import database

# can now refer to flask.session and database.session

from flask import session as flask_session  # server session
from database import session as db_session     # database session

Could also:

from flask import session
from database import session as db_session

If you don’t want to type the library name again and again:

import sqlalchemy as sqla

# can now refer to sqla.Integer, sqla.Text, etc

Some libraries have standard aliases that are commonly used, such as:

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

When to import the whole library

It can be useful to import random instead of
from random import choice if

  • You may want to use other items from this module in the future.
  • You want to protect your namespace.

Importing vs. Running a Module

  • Importing a module (import cupcakes) runs all lines of code in the module
    • including print statements, etc.
  • Running the file (python cupcakes.py) also runs all lines of code
  • What if you want something not to run on import?
    • for example, doctests

dunder-name-equals-dunder-main

  • if __name__ == '__main__' tests for import vs running directly

    if __name__ == '__main__':
    # code goes here

    # executes when file is run directly
    # does NOT execute when imported as a module

Typically, put this at the bottom of the file.

Organizing Your Code

For any complex program, it’s good to break it into modules:

pacman/
  game.py        # the player, and how we move around
  score.py       # functions dealing with the score
  ghosts.py      # logic around how ghosts move
  maze.py        # the mazes and levels

Then, in game.py:

from score import set_score, is_high_score
from ghosts import move_ghosts
from maze import get_maze_by_level

# ... etc

Libraries & Pip

Your Code Vs Other People’s Code

pacman/
  game.py
  score.py
  ghosts.py
  maze.py

from score import set_score
from random import choice
from twitter import send_tweet
  • You can import modules in the same directory as you’re in
  • You can import from things in the “standard library” (like random)
  • You can install & then use other people’s code (“libraries”)

Libraries

  • Python comes with dozens of library packages (eg, random, sys)
  • And you can download more! (tens of thousands of libraries available on PyPI)
  • Example popular libraries:
    • Requests (week 3!)
    • Flask (week 4!)
    • SQLAlchemy (week 5!)

The random and sys modules (both of which you’ve already used in lab) are part of the Python standard library. The standard library comes with Python and does not need to be installed separately. A full list of the modules in the Python standard library is here.

Pip

  • Pip is a tool for installing Python libraries from the PyPI

  • Similar to RubyGems for Ruby, or npm for Nodejs

  • To use pip:

    $ pip3 install flask

  • But don’t do this — yet

Read the below section on virtualenv before attempting to pip install anything on your computer. You most likely will want/need to do this inside a virtual environment.

Virtual Environments

Potential Problems

  • What if you don’t have permission to install globally on your computer?
  • How can you let others know what libraries they need to run your project?

Another scenario: Suppose you are working on a team UberMelon project, and your teammates are still using an older version of a library. However, for your Hackbright project (which you’re working on at the same time), you want to use the newest version. Which should you install?

Solution: Virtual Environments

  • virtualenv creates isolated Python environments with their own place to keep installed libraries
  • Can run specific versions of libraries for this project
  • Can run a different version of Python itself
  • Creates a folder in your project directory where libraries will be installed

This is all that virtualenvs do. They are not a virtual machine, and they don’t do anything related to security.

Repeated Vocabulary

  • Shell environment: key / value pairs used by the shell
  • Virtual machine: a separate computer running on the same hardware as a host computer
  • Python virtual environment: an isolated Python instance for installing specific libraries

Creating a Virtual Env

Inside your project directory:

  $ virtualenv env
  New python executable in env/bin/python
  Installing setuptools, pip...done.
  • env is the directory name we chose for the virtualenv
  • Directory name can be anything, but env or venv are traditional

No Spaces in Your Directory Name

It’s a little obscure, but Python’s virtualenv doesn’t work if you try to create and use a virtual environment when you have a space in your path.

For example, if you wanted to create a virtual environment in /Users/jessica/hackbright homework, you’ll get an error.

Go ahead rename that directory to /Users/jessica/hackbright-homework and you’ll be fine. Then you can go ahead and make a new virtual environment and use it.

To use a different version of Python, you must already have that version installed on your computer. Then run:

$ virtualenv -p /path/to/python3 env

What Does That Give Me?

  $ virtualenv env
  New python executable in env/bin/python
  Installing setuptools, pip...done.

your-project-directory/
  game.py
  score.py
  ghosts.py
  maze.py
  env/         <-- makes new "env" folder

Inside that env directory:

bin/
  activate
  pip
  python
lib/
  # standard Python library is here
  # other things you installed go here
  • A “virtual environment” is just a folder!
    • With a copy of Python and pip (and a few other things) in bin/
    • And a place to keep libraries to use for this project

Using a Virtual Env

You only need to create a virtual env once

You need to activate it each time you start working:

$ source env/bin/activate
(env)$ which python     # uses our version & our libraries!
/.../env/bin/python

To deactivate:

(env)$ deactivate
$ which python     # back to the system python
/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/bin/python

You are said to be “in” the virtualenv while it’s activated.

The simplest explanation of what this does is to take a look at your $PATH. It adds a path to your environment at the front of your path, forcing things to install and read from there first.

Note that even though you are said to be “in” the virtualenv while activated, you are never actually in the env folder.

Installing Libraries

(env)$ pip3 install python-twitter
... lots of stuff ...
Successfully installed python-twitter requests oauthlib
Cleaning up...

Stuff installed in virtualenv is only available to that virtualenv.

Once you deactivate, you don’t have access to those libraries.

Viewing Your Env Config

$ pip3 freeze
oauthlib==0.7.2
python-twitter==2.2
requests==2.6.0
requests-oauthlib==0.4.2
wsgiref==0.1.2

Saving Your Env Config

$ pip3 freeze > requirements.txt

Great way to share your requirements with others who want to run your project

$ pip3 install -r requirements.txt

Virtual Env Notes

  • You have to activate it each time you start working in it
  • Don’t check your env directory into Git (include in .gitignore!)
    • Instead: create it on new places you clone your repo
  • Do check your requirements.txt in to Git.

Summary

What Did We Learn?

  • Module: importable namespace (from a file)
  • Can import foo or from foo import this
  • Good idea: create “virtual environments” for independence
    • virtualenv env will create one and source env/bin/activate activates it
    • Look for (env) in shell prompt to show you’re activated

Self-Study

  • Packages (subfolders of Python code, for larger projects)
  • Pip docs
  • Virtualenv docs
Lightning Talks

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Lightning Talks

« Back to Homepage

  • Lightning Talks
    • Lightning Talks
      • What are they
      • How to Prepare
      • Topics
      • Past Topics

Lightning Talks

What are they

  • Short, 7-10 minute presentation on a technology
    • Save 1-2 minutes for questions
  • Practice talking about technology
  • Talk about something you know about, or something you did some research on and want to share

How to Prepare

  • Get your topic approved by your adviser
  • Add your topic to your Student Profile on FRODO
  • Research!
  • Make a short slidedeck and upload this to FRODO
    • Must present from PDF – no fancy transitions, please.

Topics

  • Remember, you only have 8 minutes.
  • Can be something unique that you’ve used in your project
    • A python or javascript library
    • An API (such as Facebook, Pinterest, Twitter, Amazon)
  • Can be a tool or customization for your development environment
    • Difftools for git
    • Bash prompt customization
    • Text editor shortcuts! Command line shortcuts!
  • Can be something you’re excited to learn how to do
    • Web scraping
    • Advanced linux commands

Past Topics

  • How to use grep on the command line
  • Web Requests: GET vs. POST
  • Advanced CSS selectors
  • The Heartbleed Bug (SSL)

Not so great topics:

  • machine learning
  • another programming language
Classes

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Classes

« Back to Homepage

  • Classes
    • Introduction
      • Our Goal
      • Why Classes?
      • Classes Versus Dicts
      • Classes You Know
    • Classes and Instances
      • Some Lingo
      • A Class
      • Making Instances
      • What Are You?
    • Attributes
      • Instances Have Attributes
      • Classes Can Define Class Attributes
      • Getting Attributes
    • Methods
      • Methods
      • Methods Can Refer to Attributes
      • Self
      • Methods Can Call Methods
      • Functions Versus Methods
    • Initialization
      • Creation
      • Initialization
    • Rewind
      • Hey, What Did We Cover?
    • Looking Ahead
      • Coming Up
      • Further Study

Classes

Introduction

Classes are a core part of object-oriented programming. This lecture covers them and introduces good design principles.

Our Goal

Learn the basics of classes/objects in Python.

Why Classes?

We want to write functions that can process melons.

We have melons of different types, with different attributes.

crenshaw = {
    'price': 2.00,
    'color': 'green',
    'source': ['USA', 'Brazil'],
    'seedless': False,
}

def buy_melon(melon_type):
    """Buy a melon, checking source country and price."""

def seed_melon(melon_type):
    """Seed a melon, if the melon isn't already seeded."""

Potential downsides to this code

Structuring code like this can work, but it’s not ideal. For instance, it’s not immediately apparent that these functions only work on dictionaries with particular keys (price, color, source, seedless).

It’s also unclear that the dictionary and functions ought to stay together. Even though the dictionary and functions exist in the same file, it’s hard to tell that buy_melon and seed_melon only work on melon-dictionaries.

crenshaw = {
    'price': 2.00,
    'color': 'green',
    'source': ['USA', 'Brazil'],
    'seedless': False,
}

watermelon = {
    'price': 3.00,
    'size': 'large',
    'comes_from': ['USA', 'Spain'],
}

Why is this bad?

These two dictionaries were probably meant to have similar keys, so the same functions could use them. There’s variation (probably needless variation in the case of the source and comes_from keys), making it difficult to re-use code on both of these.

Classes Versus Dicts

Feature Dict Class
Store data â â
Flexible â Some
Structured Some â
Has own smarts   â

Classes You Know

Lists, Tuples, Files, and more!

>>> my_file = open("/path/to/file")

>>> my_file
<open file '/path/to/file', mode 'r' at 0x106c1c9c0>

>>> my_file.read()
'Four score and seven years ago...'

>>> houses = [
...     'gryffindor', 'slytherin', 'ravenclaw', 'hufflepuff']

>>> houses.append("balloonicorn")

Classes and Instances

Some Lingo

Class
Type of thing, like String (str) or File (file)
Instance
An individual occurrence of a class (the string 'hackbright')

The terms instance and object are equivalent.

A Class

class Animal:
    pass

pass

Classes can’t have entirely empty bodies (just like functions and if statements and other blocks in Python). The pass statement is just a do-nothing statement that is useful to put in so the body isn’t totally empty.

A docstring can play the same role and provide documentation at the same time, so it’s much nicer.

Class names are written in UpperCamelCase.

Or, nicer:

class Animal:
  """A living creature."""

Making Instances

To make an instance of the class, call the class:

>>> fido = Animal()

Can have more than one instance of an animal:

>>> arfy = Animal()

This process is called instantiation

What Are You?

Can ask an instance what class it is

>>> type(fido)
<class 'Animal'>

Attributes

Instances Have Attributes

>>> fido = Animal()
>>> arfy = Animal()

Setting instance attributes:

>>> fido.name = 'Fido'
>>> fido.fav_color = 'gray'

>>> arfy.name = 'Arfy'
>>> arfy.fav_color = 'light gray'

Getting instance attributes:

>>> fido.name
'Fido'
>>> fido.fav_color
'gray'

>>> arfy.name
'Arfy'
>>> arfy.fav_color
'light gray'

Classes Can Define Class Attributes

class Animal:
    species = 'dog'

>>> Animal.species
'dog'

Class attributes are shared by all instances

>>> fido = Animal()
>>> fido.species
'dog'

>>> arfy = Animal()
>>> arfy.species
'dog'

New attributes can be defined on a class

>>> Animal.diet = 'omnivore'

>>> fido.diet
'omnivore'

>>> arfy.diet
'omnivore'

Instance attributes take precedence over class attributes

>>> fido.species = 'ferret'
>>> fido.species
'ferret'

>>> Animal.species
'dog'

>>> arfy.species
'dog'

Getting Attributes

>>> Animal.species
'dog'

>>> fido.name
'Fido'

>>> arfy.species
'dog'

>>> fido.tail_length
Traceback (most recent call last):
    ...
AttributeError: 'Animal' object has no attribute 'tail_length'

getattr

If you want to “safely” get an attribute, you can use getattr(). You can provide a third value of “what to return if the named attribute isn’t found”.

getattr(obj, attr-name[, default-value])
>>> getattr(fido, 'tail_length', 'unknown')
'unknown'

Methods

A method is like a function defined on a class:

class Animal:

    def speak(self):
        print('Woof!')

    def dance(self):
        return ':prance, prance, prance:'

(Note that methods always have at least one parameter, self)

>>> fido = Animal()

>>> fido.speak()
Woof!

Methods Can Refer to Attributes

class Animal:
    name = None
    species = 'dog'

    def speak(self):
        print(f'Woof! I am {self.name} the {self.species}')

>>> fido = Animal()
>>> arfy = Animal()

>>> fido.name = 'Fido'
>>> arfy.name = 'Arfy'

>>> fido.speak()
Woof! I am Fido the dog
>>> arfy.speak()
Woof! I am Arfy the dog

Self

The self parameter is the instance itself:

class Animal:
    name = None
    species = 'dog'

    def speak(self):
        print(f'Woof! I am {self.name} the {self.species}')

    def graduate(self):
        self.name = f'Dr. {self.name}'

self

Methods parameter lists must begin with self; this isn’t passed explicitly when you call a method, but is the object the method is called on.

>>> fido.speak()
Woof! I am Fido the dog

>>> fido.graduate()

>>> fido.speak()
Woof! I am Dr. Fido the dog

Methods Can Call Methods

class Animal:
    name = None
    species = 'dog'

    def speak(self):
        print(f'Woof! I am {self.name} the {self.species}')

    def do_trick(self):
        print('(wag tail)')
        self.speak()

Functions Versus Methods

  • Both are code
  • Both have lists of parameters
  • Both get called with ()
  • Methods are defined on a class
  • Methods take self as first argument
  • When you call a method, Python passes instance as self

Initialization

Creation

When you make an instance:

  • it is created (by Python)
  • then it is initialized (perhaps by your code)

Initialization

from random import randint

class Animal:
    name = None
    species = None

    def __init__(self):
        self.age = randint(1, 10)
  • __init__ is an optional “special method”
    • It is called when an instance is made
  • It must take self
  • It must return None

Often, this is used to set instance attributes at creation time:

from random import randint

class Animal:

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        """Create an Animal."""

        print('initializing Animal')
        self.name = name
        self.species = species
        self.age = randint(1, 10)

To create fido:

>>> fido = Animal('Fido', 'dog')
initializing Animal

Class Attributes as Declarations

This is rare in Python, but in languages like Java, class attributes are sometimes used to outline attributes that all instances should have.

class Animal:
    name = None
    species = None
    age = None

The attributes are given real values once an instance has been created.

Rewind

Hey, What Did We Cover?

  • Classes are a bit like “smarter dictionaries”
  • They can define data (attributes) and smarts (methods)
  • Each instance of a class is separate & has own data
  • Methods are functions defined on class
    • They get called with instance as first parameter
    • So include self as the first parameter
  • __init__() gets called to set up an instance

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • oo-drawing exercise
  • Classes 2: object-oriented design principles
  • Data Modeling
  • And then lots of practice with objects!

Further Study

Python 3 Getter/Setter Properties

Classes II

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Classes II

« Back to Homepage

  • Classes II
    • Review
      • Review
      • What’s So Great About OO?
    • A Different Type of Animal
      • Changing Our Focus
    • Inheritance
      • Inheriting
      • Superclass / Subclass
      • Subclasses
      • Calling a Super’s Method
    • Polymorphism
      • Polymorphism
      • Design
    • Looking Ahead
      • Coming Up
      • Self-Study

Classes II

Review

class Animal:
    hunger = 50                            # class attribute

    def __init__(self, name):              # special method
        self.name = name                   # instance attribute
        self.info()                        # call a method

    def info(self):                        # normal method
        print(f"{self.name} has hunger {self.hunger}")  # using attributes

>>> fido = Animal("Fido")   # making an object ("instantiating")
Fido has hunger 50

>>> fido.hunger             # using an attribute
50

>>> fido.info()             # calling a method
Fido has hunger 50

Class Attributes vs Instance Attributes

There’s a small difference between a class attribute and an instance attribute. The class attribute is a piece of data on the class itself; when you ask for this on an instance, it finds it on the class. An instance attribute is set directly on the object.

This makes a difference if you create a class, create an object, and then update the class.

For a simple class with both a class attribute and an instance attribute:

class MyClass:

 class_attr = 1

 def __init__(self):
     self.instance_attr = 1

Let’s make an instance of this object:

>>> o = MyClass()

And then change the class attribute on the class:

>>> MyClass.class_attr = 2

Now, o will find the new value:

>>> o.class_attr
2

However, if at any point, we changed class_attr on our object, the new value will be set on the object, and it won’t see changes to the class:

>>> o.class_attr = 3
>>> MyClass.class_attr = 4
>>> o.class_attr
3

What’s So Great About OO?

  • Data lives close to its functionality
    • Encapsulation
  • Don’t need to know info a method uses internally
    • Abstraction
  • Easy to make different, interchangeable types of animals
    • Polymorphism

A Different Type of Animal

Changing Our Focus

Our example is rather generic ...

We can try to add “cat functionality” to our generic Animal through smarter methods. In this case, we try to have cats speak differently:

class Animal:
    hunger = 50

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species

    def speak(self):                   # now we handle cats!
        if self.species == 'cat':
            greeting = 'Meow'
        else:
            greeting = 'Hey'
        print(f"{greeting}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")

However, this leads to a kind of “spaghetti code,” where there may be lots of conditionals and special cases inside of increasingly-complicated methods.

Or we can make a new Cat class simply based on copying the existing Animal class and modifying it:

class Cat:
    hunger = 50

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
        self.species = "cat"

    def speak(self):
        print(f"Meow, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")

There’s a lot of duplicate code here; this would be hard to maintain, as we might have to make changes in two places, and it might be hard to keep track of what functionality is cat-specific or animal-general.

Inheritance

Inheriting

We can make a Cat class that inherits from Animal:

class Animal:
    hunger = 50

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species

    def speak(self):
        print(f"Hey, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):
    pass

Now, our Cat has the same attributes and methods of Animal.

Note that we only need the pass statement there because we need something in a class body. Like function bodies or conditional blocks, they can be completely empty.

Superclass / Subclass

Animal
Superclass (parent)
Cat
Subclass (child)

Subclasses

Can add attributes:

class Animal:
    hunger = 50


class Cat(Animal):
    purr_volume = 10

Now cats will have both hunger and purr_volume attributes available.

Can change attributes:

class Animal:
    hunger = 50


class Cat(Animal):
    hunger = 70

Can add methods:

class Animal:

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species

    def speak(self):
        print(f"Hey, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):

    def purr(self):
        print("{} enfurs you!".format(self.name))

Now cats can both speak and purr.

Can replace methods:

class Animal:

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species

    def speak(self):
        print(f"Hey, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")

class Cat(Animal):

    def speak(self):
        print(f"Meow, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")

>>> fido = Animal("Fido", "dog")
>>> whiskers = Cat("Whiskers", "cat")

This is a bit ugly; why should we have to pass in species when we know we’re creating a cat?

Can have a different initializer:

class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species


class Cat(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name):    # no species!
        self.name = name
        self.species = "cat"

>>> fido = Animal("Fido", "dog")
>>> whiskers = Cat("Whiskers")

Calling a Super’s Method

The best way to get to a parent class’s methods is to use the super function, like this:

super().methodName(arguments)
class Cat(Animal):

    def __init__(self, name):
        super().__init__(name, 'cat')

Always use super()

There’s an older syntax, where you call the parent method on the class directly, manually passing in self. This works, but has some subtle differences in more advanced class hierarchies, and is not recommended. You may see this in other people’s code, though.

class Cat(Animal):

    def __init__(self, name):
        Animal.__init__(self, name, 'cat')

Don’t do it this way.

Sometimes, you’ll call super first:

class FriendlyCat(Cat):

    def greet(self):
        msg = super().greet()
        return msg + " You seem awesome."

Sometimes afterwards:

class HungryCat(Cat):

    def greet(self):
        """Eats every time before it speaks."""

        self.feed()
        return super().greet()

Polymorphism

Flexibility of types without conditionals.

for some_animal in family_animals:

   if some_animal.species == "dog":
       some_animal.speak()

   elif some_animal.species == "cat":
       some_animal.meow()

Yuck. We’re having to do a lot of logic for the same basic idea.

for some_animal in family_animals:
    some_animal.speak()

Much nicer.

Design

Common for constructor (__init__) to take different args:

class Animal:

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species


class Cat(Animal):

    def __init__(self, name):
        super().__init__(name, 'cat')

>>> fido = Animal("Fido", "dog")
>>> whiskers = Cat("Whiskers")

... but not other methods.

class Animal:

    def speak(self, greet):
        print(f"{greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):

    def speak(self):
        super().speak('Meow')

>>> for animal in animals:
...    animal.speak()          # uh-oh

Often solved with parameters with default values.

class Animal:

    def speak(self, greet="Hey"):
        print(f"{greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):

    def speak(self):
        super().speak('Meow')

>>> for animal in animals:
...    animal.speak()          # w00t!

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • Classes 3!
  • Data Modeling
  • Lots of use of objects
  • oo-melons

  • A good overview

    • Classes and Methods

Classes 3

Why use classes?

What are 3 benefits of OO?

Abstraction
Hiding details we don’t need
Encapsulation
Keeping everything “together”
Polymorphism
Interchangeability of components

Class Design

Who’s The Superclass?

If, instead of Animal and Cat, we wanted to keep track of just cats and dogs, which would be the superclass of which?

Neither is great, because we’d still be mixing in the pieces that are general to all animals with what is specifically different about cats and dogs.

Hierarchies

class Animal:
   pass

class Mammal(Animal):
   pass

class Dog(Mammal):
   pass

class Cat(Mammal):
   pass

class Lizard(Animal):
   pass

The Search for Cattitude

Common Ancestor

class Animal:
    hunger = 50

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def feed(self):
        self.hunger = self.hunger - 50


class Cat(Animal):
    hunger = 20

    def speak(self):
        print("Meow, I'm {} the cat.".format(self.name))


class Dog(Animal):

    def speak(self):
        print("Woof, I'm {} the dog.".format(self.name))

Factoring

We can have our Cat and Dog subclasses mostly rely on a flexibly-designed parent class method. Notice how they pass arguments to the superclass __init__ and speak:

class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species

    def speak(self, greet="Hey"):
        print(f"{greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name):
        super().__init__(name, 'cat')

    def speak(self):
        super().speak('Meow')


class Dog(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name):
        super().__init__(name, 'dog')

    def speak(self):
        super().speak('Woof')

We might also factor out the idea that speak changes only in the greeting, and make that a class attribute. Now we don’t need to override the speak method in subclasses—the functionality is the same and the change just comes from that attribute change.

class Animal:
    greet = "Hey"

    def __init__(self, name, species):
        self.name = name
        self.species = species

    def speak(self):
        print(f"{self.greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):
    greet = "Meow"

    def __init__(self, name):
        super().__init__(name, 'cat')


class Dog(Animal):
    greet = "Woof"

    def __init__(self, name):
        super().__init__(name, 'dog')

We could even write a slightly-smarter base __init__ so that the Cat and Dog subclasses didn’t need to override it.

This might be good or bad depending on how complex we had to make the base method—we don’t want to go back to spaghetti code!

class Animal:
    greet = "Hey"

    def __init__(self, name, species=None):
        self.name = name
        if species:
            self.species = species

    def speak(self):
        print(f"{self.greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(Animal):
    greet = "Meow"
    species = "cat"


class Dog(Animal):
    greet = "Woof"
    species = "dog"

AbstractAnimal

Abstract Class

In some cases, you may design base classes that are non-functioning themselves, but are meant to be useful only when subclasses and when additional attributes or methods are defined.

These are called abstract classes. In Python, they are typically given names to signify that, like AbstractAnimal or BaseAnimal.

class AbstractAnimal:

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def speak(self):
        print(f"{self.greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")


class Cat(AbstractAnimal):
    greet = "Meow"
    species = "cat"


class Dog(AbstractAnimal):
    greet = "Woof"
    species = "dog"

Notice how AbstractAnimal has a speak() method, which relies on the presence of instance attributes not on AbstractAnimal. The abstract class’ speak() won’t work by itself, but it will work on the subclasses.

Python has some libraries that make it easy to create abstract classes that are even smarter: they can tell you which methods you need to override or create, and can refuse to make instances of themselves directly.

Mixins

We could add features to our Cat class:

class Cat(Animal):

    # ...

    def chase_laser(self):
        print("Wheee!")

    def enfur(self):
        print("(fur, fur, fur)")
  • But other kinds of animals might have these, too!

And these features may not match our hierarchy well!

A mixin is a lightweight class meant to provide a feature

class ChaseLaserPointersMixin:
    """Can chase laser pointers."""

    def chase_laser(self):
          print("Wheee!")


class CoverYouInFurMixin:
     """Can cover you in fur."""

     def enfur(self):
          print("(fur, fur, fur)")

How do we use these?

We can subclass from multiple parent classes—including our mixins!

class MyClass(ParentA, ParentB, ParentC):
    pass

First looks in A, then B, then C.

class Cat(ChaseLaserPointerMixin, CoverYouInFurMixin, Animal):
    """A cat."""

    # ...


class Dog(CoverYouInFurMixin, Animal):
    """A dog."""

    # ...


class HairlessRobot(ChaseLaserPointerMixin, Animal):
    """A robot."""

    # ...

Looking Forward

Coming Up

  • Classes 4
  • Data Modeling

Self-Study

  • Mastering Object-Oriented Python

HTML

Intro

What is HTML?

HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language

Markup languages are used to categorize content

Without markup
What is HTML? HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. Markup
languages are used to organize text into logical sections.
With markup
<h1>What is HTML?</h1>
<p>
  HTML stands for <cite>HyperText Markup Language</cite>.
</p>
<p>
  Markup languages are used to organize text into logical
  sections.
</p>

Goals

  • Components of HTMl syntax

  • Enough HTML to make you dangerous

  • How to build forms in HTML

HTML Syntax

Elements

A fundamental unit of HTML is called an element

Some elements contain text

A paragraph element
<p>HTML is cool.</p>

  • Start the element with an open tag (<p>)

  • End with a close tag (</p>)

Some elements donât contain text content

An image element
<img src="/static/cat.png">

They comprise of a single, self-closing tag

Attributes

Attributes are used to configure elements

An input of type, âpasswordâ
<input type="password">

  • If you donât explicitly add attributes, youâll use the default values

  • To override defaults, add attr="value" to the elementâs tag

Boolean attributes default to false

  • You can explicitly set their value to true

    A required input
    <input required="true">

  • But most prefer using this shortcut

    <input required>

Entities

Entities are shortcuts for displaying special characters

Theyâre also used to display characters that are reserved for HTML syntax

Character

Entity

&

&amp;

<

&lt;

>

&gt;

â

&quot;

More entities

You can view an official list of all available entities here.

Comments

Comments are not displayed by the browser, but still viewable in source

<!-- This is a comment -->

<!--
  Everything in between is ignored, so
  your comment can contain multiple lines
-->

Whitespace

Whitespace is almost insignificant

HTML squeezes any amount of whitespace into a single space character

<p>
  This is one line.
  This is another line.
</p>

This is one line. This is another line.

You can add newline characters with the line-break tag (<br>)

<p>
  This is one line.<br>
  This is another line.
</p>

This is one line.
This is another line.

Using <br> is not a good practice, but fine while learning

In reality, you wouldnât use <br> to add a visual line-break. Instead, you would use CSS to adjust the amount of space between two lines.

HTML Basics

The Most Minimal Webpage

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <!-- Metadata goes here -->
  </head>

  <body>
    <!-- Actual contents of page goes here -->
  </body>
</html>

  • doctype declaration tells the browser that the page is written in HTML

  • All HTML should be contained in the html element

  • head is for metadata content

  • body should contain content that the user should see

The most basic webpage

The example above is a minimal HTML skeleton. It is not the standard, basic skeleton. A standard HTML page for the web looks like this:

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
    <title>Title Goes Here</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <!-- Page content goes here -->
  </body>
</html>

Browser Dev Tools

Firefox, Chrome, and Safari have special developer tools used for debugging HTML, CSS, and JavaScript on the web

You may need to google how to enable developer tools for your browser of choice

To open the HTML Inspector tool:
Right click on page â Inspect element

The Inspector allows you to:

  • View the HTML source for a page

  • Temporarily edit HTML

  • View style properties that have been applied to an HTML element

  • And more!

ID vs. Class

All elements can have attributes called id and class

The id attribute is used to uniquely identify an element

Itâs up to you to make sure each id is unique!

<p id="intro">
  Welcome!
</p>
<p id="about">
  This is my homepage.
</p>

The class attribute is used to categorize elements

Multiple elements can belong to the same class

<a class="nav-link">
  Home
</a>
<a class="nav-link">
  About
</a>

Block Elements vs. Inline Elements

All elements have a default display type

Two basic display types are block and inline

More display types

Block and inline arenât the only display types. Other display types include:

  • flex

  • grid

  • list-item

Block Elements

  • Start on a new line

  • Take up the whole width of their containing element

Examples of block elements:

  • Paragraph (<p>)

  • Headings (<h1>, <h2>, <h3>, etc.)

  • Table (<table>)

    • Table row (<tr>)

    • Table data (<td>)

  • Unordered list (<ul>), ordered list (<ol>)

    • List item (<li>)

<h1>Block Elements</h2>
<p>
  All of the elements below are block elements.
</p>

<h2>Lists</h2>
<ul>
  <li>First item</li>
  <li>Second item</li>
</ul>

<ol>
  <li>First item</li>
  <li>Second item</li>
</ol>

<h2>Table</h2>
<table>
  <tr>
    <td>print</td>
    <td>Print something to the screen</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td>list</td>
    <td>The list constructor function</td>
  </tr>
</table>

Inline Elements

  • Sit on a line together

  • Donât break the flow of your document

Examples of inline elements:

  • Hyperlink (<a>)

  • Image (<img>)

  • Strong (<strong>)

  • Emphasis (<em>)

<h1>
  <img src="cat2.gif">
  Contact Us!
</h1>

<p>
  Find us on <a href="https://facebook.com">Facebook</a>.
  Seriously, <strong>please contact us on Facebook</strong>,
  otherwise we <em>might</em> not recieve your message.
</p>

div and span

When your content isnât a paragraph or table or hyperlink (â¦etc.),
you can use div or span

  • div is a generic block element

  • span is a generic inline element

Use id and/or class to label what the element is supposed to be

<div
  id="order-confirmation"
  class="confirmation-window"
>
  <div class="window-body">
    <p>
      Your order has been placed! to change your order,
      please call us at <span class="phone">(555) 555-MELON</span>.
    </p>
  </div>

  <div class="window-footer">
    <button>
      Close window
    </button>
  </div>
</div>

Would We Use Block or Inline forâ¦

  • An email address

  • A poem

  • An authorâs name

  • A navigation bar

  • A phone number

  • A sidebar

How to Write Forms

The form Element

Forms accept user input and send it to a server for processing

A login form
<form>
  <input type="text" name="username">
  <input type="password" name="password">
  <input type="submit">
</form>

Form Input Elements

Forms can have multiple fields that are defined with form input elements

  • Theyâre used to set the name of a field

  • Sometimes theyâre used to define possible values a user can select

There are different types of form input elements:

  • The input element (<input>) comes in different types

    • Text

    • Checkbox

    • Radio (radio button)

  • The select element (<select>) is a dropdown menu

  • textarea (<textarea>) is for inputting text that is longer than a phrase

A Basic Form Input

<input
  type="text"
  name="username"
  value="ball00ni"
>

  • type is used to configure the kind of input you want

  • name is used to set the name of a field

  • value is optional â it is usually set by the user

    • If a value is defined, it becomes the default value for the field

Text Input

<form>
  <label>Email</label>
  <input type="text" name="email">
</form>

Radio Buttons

Radio buttons are used when the user should select just one option

Each group of radio buttons should have the same name

<form>
  Choose a shipping method:

  <input type="radio" name="shipping" value="standard">
  <label>Standard shipping (5-7 days)</label>

  <input type="radio" name="shipping" value="expedited">
  <label>Expedited shipping (1-3 days)</label>
</form>

Checkboxes

Checkboxes are used when the user can select many options

Each group of checkboxes should have the same name

<form>
  What music genres do you like?

  <input type="checkbox" name="genres" value="pop">
  <label>Pop</label>

  <input type="checkbox" name="genres" value="hiphop">
  <label>Hip Hop</label>

  <input type="checkbox" name="genres" value="Other">
  <label>Other</label>
</form>

Dropdown Menus

Dropdown menus allow users to select one option from a menu

<form>
  Choose your main programming language:

  <select name="lang">
    <option value="python">Python</option>
    <option value="javascript">JavaScript</option>
    <option value="ruby">Ruby</option>
  </select>
</form>

Textareas

<form>
  <label>Tell us about yourself:</label>
  <textarea name="about-me"></textarea>
</form>

Submit Button

There are two ways to create a âsubmitâ button:

<form>
  <input type="submit">
</form>

<form>
  <button type="submit">Log In</button>
</form>

Code Style

Quotation Marks

Double-quotes are standard (but HTML doesnât care either way)

<!-- Avoid doing this! -->
<input type='text' name='username'>

<!-- Do this instead -->
<input type="text" name="username">

Line Length

Keep your line-length to < 80 characters by adding line-breaks

<!-- Avoid doing this! -->
<p>This paragraph is pretty long, so it will go over the character limit and make things really hard to read</p>

<!-- Do this instead -->
<p>
  This paragraph is pretty long, so it will go over the character
  limit and make things really hard to read.
</p>

You can also add line-breaks inside a tag

<!-- Avoid doing this! -->
<img id="wow" src="/static/very/long/url/here.png" alt="A very interesting photo">

<!-- Do this instead -->
<img
  id="wow"
  src="/static/very/long/url/here.png"
  alt="A very interesting photo"
>

Indentation

Use indentation to show that content belongs inside an element

<!-- Avoid doing this! -->
<div class="article"><div class="header"><h1>Title of an Article</h1></div>
<div class="intro"><p>Hi</p></div></div>

<!-- Do this instead -->
<div class="article">
  <div class="header">
    <h1>Title of an Article</h1>
  </div>

  <div class="intro">
    <p>Hi</p>
  </div>
</div>

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • CSS

  • How the web works

  • Cookies & sessions

  • JavaScript

  • Bootstrap

Resources

MDN HTML Documentation: HTML elements reference

A list of all HTML elements â click on a particular element to see examples

MDN HTML Documentation: The Input (Form input) element

A list of different types of input elements â click on a type to see examples

Further Study

How to write semantic HTML

How to ensure your website is accessible to all

Google Developers: Web Fundamentals

Great resource to study after Hackbright

CSS

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

CSS

« Back to Homepage

  • CSS

      • Properties
      • Common Properties

      • Values
      • Keyword Values
      • Numeric Values
      • Notes about Numeric Units

      • Color Values

      • Block / Inline

CSS

Cascading Style Sheets

Our Goals

Learn basics of modern CSS

Agenda

  • What is CSS good for?
  • Syntax of CSS files
  • Common selectors
  • Common properties & values
  • Order of precedence in CSS

Separating Content from Presentation

Writing HTML was horrible before CSS because you couldnât separate your content from your presentation.

Without CSS:

<font color="red">
  <p>Make this paragraph red.</p>
  <p>And this one, too.</p>
</font>

With CSS:

p {
   color: red;
}

<p>All paragraphs are now red!</p>

More importantly, thoughâ¦

Why did we want those paragraphs red?

CSS lets us say things like:

.overdue {
   color: red;
}

<p class="overdue">
  Your homework is late!
</p>

This is the most important benefit of CSS.

CSS Syntax

CSS is made up of selectors, properties, and values.

selector {
    property: value;
}

In our example, weâre selecting all <p> elements and styling them.

p {
    color: red;
}

In CSS, comments are delineated by /* and */, like this:

p {
    color: red;   /* our brand color */
}

CSS Can Go In The Head

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <style>

      /* CSS goes here */

      p {
          color: red;
      }

    </style>
  </head>
  <body>

    <!-- HTML goes here -->

    <p>Some text</p>

</body>
</html>

Selectors

Reference: MDN Web Docs: CSS Selectors

Selectors say âwhere will this rule be applied?â

selector {
    property: value;
}

Elements as Selectors

Use an tag-name if you want to target all elements of a certain type.

h1 {
    font-family: sans-serif;
}

<h1>My Sans Serif Heading</h1>

Ids as Selectors

Use an #id if you want to selectively target one element.

#slogan {
    font-family: monospace;
}

<p id="slogan">
  Buy melons from us.
</p>

Classes as Selectors

Use a .class if you want to target elements by class:

.urgent {
    color: red;
}

<p class="urgent">
  Your melon order has shipped!
</p>

To put two classes on one element:
include each, space separated, in quotes.

.urgent {
    color: red;
}

.outlined {
    border: 2px solid black;
}

<p class="urgent outlined">
  Your melon order has shipped!
</p>

Combining Selectors

Can combine element and class, or element and Id:

/* select all paras that are urgent */

p.urgent {
    color: red;
}

<p class="urgent">
  This is an urgent paragraph!
</p>

This is an urgent paragraph!

Descendant Selector

p i {
    color: red;
}

<p>
  My favorite book is <i>Python 101</i>.
</p>

This means âitalics things anywhere descended from a paragraph.â

âDescendedâ

By âdescendedâ, this means âinside a paragraph to any depthâ.

For example, consider the following HTML:

<p>
  My favorite book is
  <b><i>Python 101</i></b>.
</p>

Now, the italic element isnât directly inside the paragraph â the bold item is. However, when you simply have a space between two items in your selector, it means âany level of descendantâ, so this will find the italic items deeper inside this paragraph.

Can use with more complex selectors:

/* select all "urgent" descended from para */

p .urgent {
    color: red;
}

<p>
  This is a regular paragraph that has an

  <b class="urgent">urgent</b>

  section within it.
</p>

This is a regular paragraph that has an urgent
section within it.

Contrast to earlier âcombiningâ:

/* select all paras that are urgent */

p.urgent {
    color: red;
}

<p>This is a paragraph.</p>

<p class="urgent">
  This is an urgent paragraph!
</p>

This is a paragraph.

This is an urgent paragraph!

Multiple Rules

p {
    color: blue;
}

.red {
    background-color: red;
}

<p>I am a blue paragraph.</p>

<p class="red">Blue on red background</p>

Weâll talk later about what happens if two rules conflict.

Properties

âPropertiesâ are the things you can set (color, font, etc):

selector {
    property: value;
}

Common Properties

  • General Properties
    • margin (space around item)
    • padding (space inside item)
    • border (border around item)
  • Block Properties
    • width, height (size of item)
    • float (âfloatâ it on page)
  • Inline/Text Properties
    • text-align (left/center/right justify)
    • text-decoration (underline style)
    • line-height (height of text lines)
  • Font Properties
    • color
    • font-family (font name)
    • font-size
    • font-style (italics or normal)
    • font-weight (light, bold, etc)
  • Background Properties
    • background-color
    • background-image
    • background-repeat
    • background-position

To show some of these, letâs see what values can be assigned!

Values

selector {
    property: value;
}

Keyword Values

Many CSS properties take one or more of a fixed set of keywords. For example, text-align takes a keyword of left, right, or center (the default):

p {
    text-align: left;
    text-align: right;
    text-align: center;
}

.book-title {
    font-style: italic;
    font-weight: bold;
}

Numeric Values

Units for specifying numeric values:

pixels (px)
Correspond to dot on screen.
ems (em)
Width of letter âMâ in font.
percentages (%)
Relative to what is available/normal.

Specifying Points

There are other units, but these are the most common. Thereâs also pts, which you might see. Using pts or points is just like saying â12ptâ in a word processing program. We donât recommend using points, but for your reference, there are 72 points to an inch.

pixels (px)
Correspond to dot on screen.

Best for things that are always the same size:

  • image heights/widths
  • border thicknesses
.boxed {
    border: solid 1px black;
}

#site-logo {
    height: 50px;
    width: 50px;
}
ems (em)
Width of letter âMâ in font.

Useful for making things ârelative to size of textâ:

  • space around text, between columns, etc
.warning {
    padding: 1em;   /* leave about "one space" around text */
    border: solid 1px black;
}

h2 {
    margin-top: 2em;  /* double line before heading */
}
percentages (%)
Relative to what is available/normal.

Best for making things ârelativeâ:

  • This item is 50% as wide as its parent
form {
    width: 50%;   /* half as wide as page */
}

Notes about Numeric Units

Zero values shouldnât have a unit:

body {
    margin: 0px;       /* bad!  */
    margin: 0;         /* good! */
}

Decimal values should have a leading zero:

footer {
    margin: .75em;   /* bad!  */
    margin: 0.75em;  /* good! */
}

This isnât required by the specification, but is considered very good style, as itâs easy to misread .75em as 75em, and the leading zero makes it much harder to misread. This is a good practice to follow in any language.

Functional Values

body {
    background-image: url("/static/img/bg-image.jpg");
}

Color Values

Referencing colors can be done in three primary ways:

  • color name
  • hex value
  • red-green-blue value
p {
     color: red;            /* or */
     color: #ff0000;        /* or */
     color: rgb(255, 0, 0);
}

Hex values are typically 6 hex (0-9, a-f) digits. There first 2 digits say how much red is in a color; the second how much green; the third, how much blue.

Hex values can also be given with only three digits, like #abc, which always means the same things as #aabbcc.

Transparency

You can also learn about the rgba() method of specifying a color, where you can provide an âalphaâ channel value that shows how opaque or transparent the color is.

Block / Inline

Block Elements

  • start on a new line
  • take up the whole width of their containing element

Inline Elements

  • sit on a line together
  • donât break the flow of document

The Anatomy of a Block Element

Block elements have some attributes that are applied to all four sides:

padding
Space between content and border (inside background color, if any)
border
Border around content
margin
Space from border to adjacent item (not in background color)

Displays: Block and Inline

  • display: block display as block
  • display: inline display as inline
  • display: inline-block display as block that flows with the surrounding content

Centering

Text Centering

/* centers text within an element */

div {
    background-color: yellow;
    text-align: center;
}

This centers the text within the div element.

Block Centering

/* centers the element itself */

div {
    width: 600px;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-right: auto;
}

This centers the div itself; text within that would still be left-justified within the div.

Centering block elements with margin: 0 auto
requires that you specify their width.

Shorthand Values

.outlined {
     border-width: 2px;
     border-style: solid;
     border-color: black;
}

.outlined {
     border: 2px solid black;
}

You should especially use the shorthand for border, as border-style is required for the border to even be visible. The shorthand makes it harder to forget this important piece.

div {
    margin-top: 1em;        /* the top margin is 1em  */
    margin-right: 1em;      /* the right margin is 1em  */
    margin-bottom: 1em;     /* the bottom margin is 1em  */
    margin-left: 1em;       /* the left margin is 1em  */
}

This works but is tedious.

div {
    margin: 1em;              /* all have 1em margin */
}

div {
    margin: 3em 1em;          /* top/bottom=3em | right/left=1em */
}

div {
    margin: 1em 2em 3em 4em;  /* top | right | bottom | left  */
}

A good mnemonic for the order of top â right â bottom â left in things like this is âtroubleâ for TRBL. Others may find it easy to remember as âstart at the top and go clockwise.â

Which One Wins?

If We Have the Same Type of Selector

p {
    color: blue;
}

p {
    color: green;
}

Last one wins.

In general, âlast one winsâ â so paragraphs would be green, not blue (however, see below for where this changes when the âspecificityâ is different). This âlast one winsâ considers all CSS to be in one big virtual file â so even if you included this in two different tags, like:

<style> ... </style>
<style> ... </style>

or, as weâll see with linking external stylesheets:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="one.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="two.css">

Thatâs all considered by your browser as one big pile of CSS, even though it came from multiple sources.

Most Specific Beats That

#form-error-message { color: red }

.urgent { color: blue; }

p { color: green; }

<p class="urgent" id="form-error-message">
  What color will this be?
</p>

The last rule, âlast one winsâ, applies when selectors are of the same specificity. Here, the specificity of our selectors changes, so even though we wrote the rule that would turn the text green last, class selectors are more specific than element selectors, and id selectors are more specific than either, so the text color will be red.

Separate CSS Files

Can store CSS:

  • In HTML page, in <style> element in <head>
    • This is convenient for small CSS, or when learning
  • In separate file, and link to it from HTML
    • This is helpful if CSS is for more than one page
    • Or if you have lots of CSS

We can put into a separate .css file:

/static/css/style.css
selector {
    property: value;
}

selector {
    property: value;
    another-property: value;
}

/* ... */

Add link element in our HTML:

page.html
<html>
<head>

  <link rel="stylesheet"
        href="/static/css/style.css">

</head>
<body>

  <!-- ... -->

</body>
</html>

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • css-trials exercise
  • Bootstrap Introduction
  • Making Your Site Pretty

Resources!

  • Head First HTML and CSS [book]
  • Delightful CSS selectors game [fun]
  • The 30 CSS Selectors You Must Memorize [article]
  • Advanced Reading: The Book of CSS [book]
Flask

Hackbright Engineering January 2020

Flask

      • Handling Forms

      • Different Types of Requests
      • GET Requests
      • POST Requests
    • Complete Example
      • Setup
      • server.py
    • Variables in a URL
      • Motivation
      • Variables in a URL

Flask

Intro

Objectives

  • What is a Framework?

  • A basic Flask app

  • Form handling

Web Frameworks

A Quick Demo

(env) $ python3 server.py
* Running on http://localhost:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)
* Restarting with stat

What is a Web Server?

A program thatâs running on a machine and waiting for a web request.

The word âweb serverâ has many different connotations

âWeb serverâ is a generic word thatâs used to describe a technology that can communicate over HTTP, the communications protocol used on the internet. The term can be used to describe software and hardware.

Here, the word âweb serverâ refers to software â we are using it to refer to our Python Flask application.

The server then responds with HTML text for that page:

Web Application

A web application is a program that can âlistenâ for web requests and respond to them

GET /hello     (http://server/hello)

â

<html>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello World!</h1>
  </body>
</html>

The HTML example above is actually incomplete

To keep code samples short in the presentation, weâre eliding some less-important HTML markup. The shortest valid HTML skeleton in modern HTML would actually be:

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Hello</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello World!</h1>
  <body>
</html>

Flask is a Web Framework

  • Set of functions, classes, etc. that help you define

    • Which requests to respond to

      • http://server/hello

      • http://server/profile

    • How to respond to requests

      • Show the message âhello,â and the userâs name.

      • Show the userâs name and profile.

  • Someone else wrote these functions, classes, etc.

    • Youâll use them.

  • Like a library, but bigger and more opinionated

  • Usage is similar to the Python Standard Library.

Importing functions from the standard library
from random import choice, randint
Importing functions from Flask
from flask import request, render_template

What Do Web Applications Need To Do?

  • handle web requests

  • produce dynamic HTML

  • handle forms

  • handle cookies

  • connect to databases

  • provide user log-in/log-out

  • cache pages for performance

  • & more!

Flask Apps

Installing Flask

$ virtualenv env
New python executable in env/bin/python
Installing setuptools, pip...done.

$ source env/bin/activate

(env) $ pip3 install flask
... lots of stuff ...
Successfully installed flask Werkzeug Jinja2 itsdangerous markupsafe
Cleaning up...

A Minimal Flask App

from flask import Flask


app = Flask(__name__)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True, host='0.0.0.0')

What is __name__?

When we create a Flask application, it needs to know what module to scan for things like routes (covered later) â so the __name__ is required and should always be written like that.

if __name__ == '__main__' tells Python to execute code if youâre running a script directly.

Making Responses

Flask responds to web requests by calling functions

  • A function that returns web response is called a view function

    • Response is a string

    • Usually, a string of HTML

  • So, our function returns an HTML string:

    def say_hello():
    """Say hello to user."""

    return '<html><body>Hello</body></html>'

Routing Requests

Routes tell Flask which URL should correspond with which function

@app.route('/hello')
def say_hello():
    """Return simple 'Hello' Greeting."""

    return '<html><body><h1>Hello</h1></body></html>'

  • Flask lets you ârouteâ a URL to a function

  • @app.route('/hello') is a Python âdecoratorâ

    • /hello is the URL we requested

Serving at the Root

The root URL is used to show a web siteâs homepage

@app.route('/')
def index():
    """Show homepage"""

    return """
    <html>
    <body>
      <h1>I am the landing page</h1>
    </body>
    </html>
    """

This function will get called if we go to http://localhost:5000/

Forms

Connecting Forms with Routes

A form element will submit data to the URL in its action attribute:

<form action="/greet">
  What's your name?
  <input type="text" name="person">
  <input type="submit">
</form>

Accessible HTML forms

For the sake of brevity, this code doesnât include good practices for accessibility in web design. A much better form would be:

<form action="/greet">

  <label for="name-input">Name:</label>
  <input type="text" name="name" id="name-input" />

  <label for="compliments-checkbox">Want compliments?</label>
  <input type="checkbox" name="wants_compliments" id="compliments-checkbox" />

  <input type="submit" />

</form>

or

<form action="/greet">
  <label>What's your name? <input type="text" name="person"></label>
  <input type="submit">
</form>

Now screenreaders for blind users of our site would know which label is the the descriptive label for each form element. This kind of stuff is really important for building a website that is usable for people with visual impairment disabilities.

Sending a Form to the Browser

@app.route('/form')
def show_form():
    """Greet user and ask for name."""

    return """
    <!doctype html>
    <html>
    <head>
      <title>Hi There!</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      <h1>Hi There!</h1>
      <form action="/greet">
        What's your name?
        <input type="text" name="person">
        <input type="submit">
      </form>
    </body>
    </html>
    """

  • Now, when the user visits http://server/form, thereâs a form there.

  • The user can interact with the form, and press submit.

  • The form submits its values to route specified in the formâs action attribute.

<form action="/greet">
  What's your name?
  <input type="text" name="person">
  <input type="submit">
</form>

This form is going to submit its values to the route with @app.route('/greet') on top of it.

Handling Forms

Here is where our form goes when the user submits.

@app.route('/greet')
def offer_greeting():
    """Greet user with a random compliment."""

    player = request.args.get('person')
    nice_thing = choice(COMPLIMENTS)

    return f"""
    <!doctype html>
    <html>
    <head>
      <title>A Compliment</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      Hi {player} I think you're {nice_thing}!
    </body>
    </html>
    """

Whatâs inside a request?

from flask import Flask, request

# (...snippet)

@app.route('/my/route')
def my_route():
    """Get stuff from form."""

    value = request.args.get('my-field-name')

Different Types of Requests

  • GET Requests

    • no side effects

    • For example, view an airlineâs homepage, search for flights

  • POST Requests

    • there are side effects

    • For example, submit an order for airplane tickets

    • Whatâs the side effect?

      • Charge a credit card

GET Requests

The GET method is implied by default an HTML formâ¦

<form action="/greet">

is the same as specifying:

<form action="/greet" method="GET">

â¦and the GET method is implied by default in the route

@app.route('/greet')

is the same as specifying:

@app.route('/greet', methods=['GET'])

To use the form data in your route you will need request.args:

player = request.args.get('person')

POST Requests

To use the POST method, it needs to be specified in both places.

  • In HTML, specify that when the form submits, it will send a POST request:

    <form action="/greet" method="POST">

  • In Flask, specify that the receiving route will accept a POST request:

    @app.route('/greet', methods=['POST'])

To use the form data in your route you will need request.form:

player = request.form.get('lastname')

Choosing a method

There are reasons to use either method, but the method must match between the form action and the app.route or you will get errors. Also note the syntax difference between the HTML âmethodâ and the route âmethodsâ. There are ways to make your route handle GET and POST at the same time, which is why even when youâre using only one method, itâs in a list and the variable is plural.

A key difference is that request.args.get() is for finding GET parameters; for POST parameters, use request.form.get().

Complete Example

Setup

$ hbget flask-intro
$ cd ~/src/flask-intro
$ virtualenv env
$ source env/bin/activate
(env) $ pip3 install flask

server.py

from flask import Flask, request
from random import choice, randint


COMPLIMENTS = ['smart', 'clever', 'tenacious', 'awesome', 'Pythonic']

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/')
def index():
    """Show homepage"""

    return """
    <html>
    <body>
      <h1>I am the landing page</h1>
    </body>
    </html>
    """

@app.route('/form')
def show_form():
    """Greet user and ask for name."""

    return """
    <!doctype html>
    <html>
    <head>
      <title>Hi There!</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      <h1>Hi There!</h1>
      <form action="/greet">
        What's your name?
        <input type="text" name="person">
        <input type="submit">
      </form>
    </body>
    </html>
    """

@app.route('/greet')
def offer_greeting():
    """Greet user with a random compliment."""

    player = request.args.get('person')
    nice_thing = choice(COMPLIMENTS)

    return f"""
    <!doctype html>
    <html>
    <head>
      <title>A Compliment</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      Hi {player} I think you're {nice_thing}!
    </body>
    </html>
    """

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True, host='0.0.0.0')

Variables in a URL

Motivation

  • Want to show info about a user with username balloonicorn at http://localhost:5000/user/balloonicorn

    • We donât want every possible username as a separate route

  • Want to show blog post with id 1 at http://localhost:5000/post/1

  • Example: Amazon

Variables in a URL

Argument capture in Flask:

@app.route('/user/<username>')
def show_user_profile(username):
    """Show the user profile for that user."""

    return f'Profile page for user: {username}'

  • <variable_name> in @app.route

  • must also be passed as argument to view function

  • default is string

Can also specify int variable:

@app.route('/post/<int:post_id>')
def show_post(post_id):
    """Show the post with the given id, the id is an integer."""

    return f'Blog post #{post_id}'

  • <int:variable_name> in @app.route

  • must also be passed as argument to view function

Other Web Frameworks

Complexity v Features

About the examples

SimpleHTTPServer is built-in to Python and focuses on single-file, very straightforward web applications. You could read the source code to the entire module in an hour.

Flask is a much more sophisticated system, but still focuses on single-file, relatively-straightforward applications. You could read the entire source of Flask in a day or two.

Node.js is a library slightly less abstract that Flask that allows a web application to be written in server-side Javascript.

Django and is an even more sophisticated system, focusing on large, highly-scalable applications, with many âopinionsâ about how things should be done to leverage common patterns and allow team members to quickly join and acclimate themselves. It would take a week or two to read all of the source code for Django.

Ruby on Rails is similar to Django in the amount of scaffolding it provides for how a web application should be laid out, and where functionality should belong. However, itâs for the Ruby programming language.

Plone and Wordpress are the most complex and sophisticated of these, having lots of user-facing features build in a huge ecosystem of add-ons. Systems this large arenât designed for someone to read all the code, but have extensive plug-in points to change the behavior â but if you did sit down to read it all, this might take months. These types of systems are often referred to as Content Management Systems or CMS.

What Is Helpful About Flask

  • Initial focus: âone fileâ web applications

  • Focus: simplicity, gets-out-of-your-way

  • Flexible about template languages, databases

  • Lots of add-on packages for additional functionality

  • Sweet spot: single-purpose apps, easy deployment

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • Templating with Flask

    • And, later, other explorations of Flask

  • flask-intro exercise

  • How the Web Works lecture

Flask Documentation

  • The Flask documentation (http://flask.pocoo.org/)

Projects: Scope & MVP

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Projects: Scope & MVP

« Back to Homepage

Projects: Scope & MVP

Project Scoping and Your MVP

Goals

  • Prep you for scoping your project
  • Talk about what an MVP is

Scoping

  • Scoping software projects is notoriously difficult
  • Your adviser can help

Why Scoping is Hard

Because estimating how long something will take is hard, especially in software.

Fred Brooks writes about the tendency towards irreducible number of errors:

Fixing bugs makes more bugs.

It’s difficult to anticipate when and how and if this will happen, especially when you’re just starting out.

What You Can Do to Help Yourself

  • Have a clear idea and a clear set of features
    • Research these features to get sense of their difficulty
  • Ask your adviser
    • We’ve seen lots of projects and know difficulties of some technologies
    • Trust us
  • Find data that does what you need

MVP

Your Minimum Viable Product

Think of a project that can be done in 2 weeks.

This leaves you time to:

  • pick next round of features based on what you learned
  • do more of something you enjoyed in sprint 1
  • write tests

Planning Features

  • A general idea is a good place to start
    • An app to find good doctors based on location and needs
    • An app to show interesting data about baby names, and add to the database
    • An app to keep track of fitness and help users meet their goals

Questions to get you thinking:

  • What is the user flow?
  • Where does the user go first in the app? Where do they go second?
  • What does the user see? How do they interact with your app?
  • Are there forms the user fills out? When?
  • Which data needs to be saved in a database?
  • Which data is provided to the users?
  • If you want to use a particular API, read the documentation to see what data you’ll be able to access, and how.
    • If you want to build a search for restaurants in a particular neighborhood, confirm that the API lets you search restaurants by neighborhood/zipcode.
  • If you’re going to use a dataset, look at the data to understand what features you can build around it.
  • If there is a library you want to use, read the documentation to understand the functionality it provides.

Example: Bird Watching Project

An example:

I want to build a birdwatching site.

It needs to capture 3D full-color hi-res models of any bird within a 100 yard radius using a button camera attached to your lapel which then sends the model via radio wave to my database, but since the technology is not quite there yet, I will consider what I can build in two weeks.

I have a dataset that lists all birds. I’d like to put some or all of that dataset into a database, search that dataset on a webserver, and be able to save a list of birds-I’ve-seen. As a nice-to-have, I’d like other users to be able to log in and save their own birds-they’ve-seen, and maybe hook up some audio of bird calls if I can find a good source, but if I don’t get to those, that’s fine.

  • Main Features (MVP)
    • Bird dataset stored in DB
    • Webapp to view list of birds and individual birds
    • Search for birds by name
    • Save a list of birds I’ve seen
  • Nice-To-Haves
    • User login (for multiple users)
    • Audio of bird calls

Data and Your Project

  • Knowing what data is available will help you decide on whether a project or a feature is feasible
  • Identifying your sources for data will be part of your MVP planning
  • You don’t necessarily have to complete the setup directions for an API to understand the type of data it provides.
  • You might create your own dataset!

Explore Your API Options

Is the data I need available?

  • At this point, you don’t need to understand the details. Look for what you can search for and what you can get back.
  • What parameters does the API allow? Does this match your needs?
  • What data is contained in the response? (It’s okay if you don’t know how to extract the data yet.)

An example: You want to look for events by location.

The documentation for Eventbrite shows that you can search
by latitude and longitude. Score!

From the docs:

What you get back:

{
  "name": {
      "text": "An Aggressive Approach to Concise Writing",
      "html": "An Aggressive Approach to Concise Writing"
  },
  "description": {
      "text": "Webinar Description \nWriting concisely is one...",
      "html": "<P><STRONG> Webinar Description<\/STRONG><\/SPAN><P>
      Writing concisely is one of the...<\/P>"
  },
  "id": "17920884849",
  "url": "http://www.eventbrite.com/concise-writing-tickets-1792089",
  "start": {
      "timezone": "America/Los_Angeles",
      "local": "2015-09-24T12:00:00",
      "utc": "2015-09-24T19:00:00Z"
  },
  "end": {
      "timezone": "America/Los_Angeles",
      "local": "2015-09-24T13:00:00",
      "utc": "2015-09-24T20:00:00Z"
  },
  ...
}

Look for a Dataset

For more static data, look for a clean, easy-to-parse data set.

There are many formats available. For now, just make sure that it contains clean, consistent data.

Another example: You want to look for film location data

Some Googling uncovers the Film Location Dataset

Some Data Resources

American Community Survey of the US Census

Bureau of Labor Statistics

Healthcare.gov

CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System

Food and Drug Adminstration

SF OpenData

UFO Reports

Python APIs

Python API Wrappers

Need more? 1001 Datasets

Other Options

  • Create your own dataset using Web Scraping
  • Create your own fake dataset using Faker

Looking Ahead

  • Projects: How Things Work
  • Projects... omg, YOUR PROJECTS!
