      • Adding a Melon
    • Looking Ahead
      • Coming Up

SQL and Python

Introduction

Goals

  • Introduce a new Python library — SQLAlchemy
  • Set up SQLAlchemy with Flask
  • Learn about “SQL Injection” attacks and how to avoid them
  • Check out some SQLAlchemy + Flask demos

Review

So far, we’ve learned how to

  • Create a PostgreSQL database

    $ createdb melondb

  • Read in an SQL file

    $ psql melondb < melons.sql

  • Open the PostgreSQL console

    $ psql melondb
melondb=#

Setup and Installation

Our Software Stack

We’ll use 3 libraries:

psycopg2
allow Python to talk to PostgreSQL
SQLAlchemy
DB-vendor-neutral way to work with databases
Flask-SQLAlchemy
make it easier to use SQLAlchemy with Flask

Install

$ pip3 install psycopg2-binary flask flask-sqlalchemy

Basic Skeleton

from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy

db = SQLAlchemy()

def connect_to_db(app):
    """Connect to database."""

    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = "postgresql:///melondb"
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS"] = False
    db.app = app
    db.init_app(app)

app = Flask(__name__)

connect_to_db(app)

Database URIs

The general form of the database URI is:

postgresql://[user][:password][@host][:port]/[database-name]

If you don’t specify user, password, host, or port, it will use default values.

In our case, the URI defaults to the PostgreSQL server running locally on our machine.

This gives us a db object — it represents our database

db = SQLAlchemy()

We also need the database session

db.session

(db.session has nothing to do with a Flask session)

Make sure to connect!

A common mistake to make is to not have the connect_to_db(app) line, or to have that line after you try to query or change the database.

If you do that, you get a rather strange error message, involving SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS.

Unfortunately, this error message is a bit misleading — the error isn’t about that (somewhat obscure) feature of SQLAlchemy; it’s just an error that gets raised when you don’t call connect_to_db.

We now have all the functionality we need to start querying the database!

Executing Queries

With db.session, we can execute SQL queries

cursor = db.session.execute("SELECT name, price FROM melons")

This gives us a cursor. To get actual data, you need to call one of these methods:

cursor.fetchone()    # (name, price)
cursor.fetchmany(2)  # [(name, price), (name, price)]
cursor.fetchall()    # [(name, price), (name, price), ...]

No semicolons needed!

Note that we don’t put semicolon at end of SQL statement;
that’s only needed in interactive programs, like psql.

Inserting, deleting, and updating work the same:

db.session.execute("""
    INSERT INTO melons (name, type, price)
    VALUES ('Razzle Dazzle', 'Watermelon', 4.25)
""")

Except each Flask route starts a new transaction — so you need to commit any changes you’ve made

db.session.commit()

Dynamic Queries

Let’s have the user pick the melon.

We want SQL like:

SELECT price FROM melons WHERE name = 'Honeydew'

We could do this with:

melon_name = request.args.get('melon-name')

sql = f"SELECT price FROM melons WHERE name = {melon_name}"

SQL Injection

... but let’s see what can happen in theory:

melon_name = request.args.get('melon-name')

sql = f"SELECT price FROM melons WHERE name = {melon_name}"

What if melon_name was Honeydew'; DROP TABLE melons; commit -- ?

SELECT price FROM melons WHERE name = 'Honeydew';
DROP TABLE melons; commit --'

Dropping Tables

Our query looks innocent enough, but we include an end quote and semi-colon, indicating to Postgres that the first query is finished.

It is then followed by another, very malicious query: to delete all of the information in our table!

Quoting

Another problem: if melon_name were O'Shea Melon, we’d get:

SELECT price FROM melons WHERE name = 'O'Shea Melon';

which is a syntax error.

Parameter Substitution

The solution: use SQLAlchemy’s built-in parameter substitution:

db.session.execute(query, dictionary-of-values)

melon_name = request.args.get('melon-name')

sql = "SELECT price FROM melons WHERE name = :name"

cursor = db.session.execute(sql, {"name": melon_name})

result = cursor.fetchone()

You can do multiple substitutions, too:

sql = """
    INSERT INTO melons (name, type, price)
    VALUES (:name, :type, :price)
"""

db.session.execute(
    sql, {
        "name": melon_name,
        "type": melon_type,
        "price": melon_price,
    }
)

Demo

Listing Melons

sql-python-demo/server.py
def index():
    """Query database and return all melons, ordered by price."""

    sql = "SELECT id, type, name, price FROM melons ORDER BY price"

    cursor = db.session.execute(sql)
    melons = cursor.fetchall()

    return render_template("index.html", melons=melons)
sql-python-demo/templates/index.html
{% if melons %}
    <table>
        <tr>
            <th>Id</th>
            <th>Type</th>
            <th>Melon Name</th>
            <th>Price</th>
        </tr>
        {% for melon in melons %}
            <tr>
                <td>{{ melon[0] }}</td>
                <td>{{ melon[1] }}</td>
                <td>{{ melon[2] }}</td>
                <td>{{ melon[3] }}</td>
            </tr>
        {% endfor %}
    </table>
{% endif %}

Finding By Price

sql-python-demo/templates/index.html
<form action="/search" method="GET">

    Min <input type="text" 
         name="min" 
         value="{{ request.args.get("min", "") }}"
         required>

    Max <input type="text"
         name="max" 
         value="{{ request.args.get("max", "") }}"
         required>

    <input type="submit">
</form>
sql-python-demo/server.py
def find_melons():
    """Find melons with cost between min and max."""

    min_price = float(request.args.get('min'))
    max_price = float(request.args.get('max'))

    sql = """SELECT id, type, name, price
             FROM melons
             WHERE price BETWEEN :minimum AND :maximum
             ORDER BY price
          """

    cursor = db.session.execute(sql,
                                {'minimum': min_price,
                                 'maximum': max_price})
    melons = cursor.fetchall()

    return render_template("index.html", melons=melons)

Adding a Melon

sql-python-demo/server.py
def add_melon():
    """Add a melon and redirect to home page."""

    name = request.form.get("melon-name")
    melon_type = request.form.get("melon-type")
    price = request.form.get("melon-price")

    sql = """INSERT INTO melons (type, name, price)
             VALUES (:type, :name, :price)
          """

    db.session.execute(sql,
                       {'type': melon_type,
                        'name': name,
                        'price': price})

    db.session.commit()

    return redirect("/")

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • SQLAlchemy as an “ORM”
    • An object-oriented way to interact with our database from Python
Projects: Order of Operations

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Projects: Order of Operations

  • Projects: Order of Operations

      • Goals
    • Agile Development
      • Agile Development
      • What That Means For You

      • What is The Help Queue?
      • How is it Used?
      • Bad and Good Examples

Projects: Order of Operations

Overview

Goals

  • Light intro to Agile development
  • The Help Queue!
  • Order of operations for projects
  • Great things to do at the end

Agile Development

Develop software responsively in iterations

Don’t design what isn’t knowable

What That Means For You

  • Make your MVP a “small bite”
    • Something you can finish in first 2-week sprint
  • Leave yourself time to do more of what you liked
    • Queries! Testing! Javascript! Design!

In Particular

It’s no fun to be racing against the clock.

The Help Queue

What is The Help Queue?

  • A FIFO Data Structure
  • A magical ed-staff-member-summoning tool
  • A slack channel
  • A place to get help and code reviews

How is it Used?

When you need help, post a message including the following information:

  • Where are you?
  • What are you trying to do?
  • What’s the error you’re getting?

Bad and Good Examples

khacks: help!

khacks: I'm trying to use jQuery but I'm getting '$ is undefined.'
        I'm in the CoS.sh by the door

Order of Operations

MVP

Have a clear MVP goal.

Example:

I’ll build a site where users can see lists of movies.
They can click on a movie to see details of a it,
then rate that movie from 1-5.

The site will show the average rating for a movie.

Data / APIs

Where will your data come from?

There’s a dataset called MovieLens100k with 100,000 movies in it. I can build a local database to hold it.

or

IMDB offers an API where you can ask for up to 100 movies in a genre. I’ll query that to show movies to users.

Data Model

  • Making late changes here is hard
  • Get this approved by your adviser before you code!

“Flow” Diagram

  • Expresses the “flow” of the application
    • How does the user move through your app?
    • This isn’t about look and feel!
    • No logos! No colors! No fancy-pants widgets!
  • The point is to discover, “What do I need to build?”

Absolute best piece of advice:

Do this using paper and pencil

Coding!

Get ready to get deep into code!

Expect to work about 5 hours a day at Hackbright

Finishing Up Your MVP

Remember, it’s “minimum viable,” which means: “it works”

But not: “it’s pretty” or “it’s done”

The first sprint ends after 2 weeks.

Round 2!

What did you enjoy?

What do you want to learn more about?

This is a great time for:

  • Getting great test coverage
  • Adding smarter searching or querying
  • Practicing object-oriented thinking
  • Adding front-end features like maps
  • Adding an external API
  • Thinking about UX and design ideas

Try hard not to commit to these prematurely.

You don’t want to box yourself in.

Round 2.5

Now draw your real wireframes.

Now add Bootstrap and decide where things go on the page.

Practice Presentations

In order to get ready to talk about:

  • the project you built
  • the technology you learned
  • the challenges you faced, and how you overcame them

You will participate in a short practice presentation with members of your education staff, as well as the Career Services department.

Feature Freeze

Fingers off keyboards for Python and Javascript!

Visual Design Time

Design: colors, CSS, images, fancy-pants widgets.

For most projects, plan to spend about 2-3 days on design/CSS.

Handsome is great, but don’t overdo it.

You’re a software engineer, not a front-end designer.

We’ll have a specific lecture right before this time.

Nearing the end

  • Make a screencast for Demo Night (more details as we get closer!)
  • Code freeze!
  • Add a great README
  • Polish your code
    • Add docstrings and comments (though you should have them already!)
  • Practice talking about your code
  • Add sparkles and glitter

Don’t Forget

Some of our most important lectures happen during this period.

#becausebootcamp

Leave time to review and study!

The Big Picture

  • It’s not what you build
    • It’s how you build it
  • Resist the temptation to think about design too soon
    • You’ll box yourself in, and not get to learn/show the most critical stuff
  • Leave time for studying!

Looking Ahead

Upcoming Lectures

  • Projects: How Things Work
  • Projects... omg, YOUR PROJECTS!

SQL III

Goals

  • Joins
  • Subqueries

Joins

Departments / Employees

Dept_Code Department
legal Legal
mktg Marketing
fin Finance
Id Name Dept_Code
1 Liz legal
2 Maggie mktg
3 Leonard legal
4 Nadine NULL

Cross Join

The most basic kind of join is a “cross join”, where all items are matched against all other items, like this:

SELECT id, fname, dept
FROM employees
  CROSS JOIN departments;

It’s as if we’re multiplying the tables together to get the combinations:

[ Liz, Maggie, Nadine, Leonard ] Ã [ Marketing, Legal, Finance ]
Id Name Department
1 Liz Marketing
1 Liz Legal
1 Liz Finance
2 Maggie Marketing
2 Maggie Legal
2 Maggie Finance
3 Leonard Marketing
3 Leonard Legal
3 Leonard Finance
4 Nadine Marketing
4 Nadine Legal
4 Nadine Finance

A cross-join is what you get if you don’t specify a join type at all but just list multiple tables in the FROM clause, like:

SELECT *
FROM departments, employees;

This kind of join is very uncommon, so you’ll find you use it much less than the kinds covered below.

Inner Join

List employees with matching departments.

(There must be a department and an employee)

SELECT ... FROM t1 JOIN t2 USING (...)

SELECT fname, employees.dept_code, departments.dept_code, dept
FROM employees
  JOIN departments
    USING (dept_code);
Name e.Dept_Code d.Dept_Code Department
Liz legal legal Legal
Maggie mktg mktg Marketing
Leonard legal legal Legal

Inner Join (ON)

JOIN ... USING works great, but only works if you called the field the same name in both tables being joined. In our case, we did name the field dept_code in both the departments and employees table, so this works.

However, there are times when you may not have called the field the same thing on both sides, so there’s a more explicit version of this, JOIN ... ON. This allows you to write an arbitrary expression for how the join happens:

SELECT ... FROM t1 JOIN t2 ON ...

SELECT fname, employees.dept_code, departments.dept_code, dept
FROM employees
  JOIN departments
    ON employees.dept_code = departments.dept_code;
Name e.Dept_Code d.Dept_Code Department
Liz legal legal Legal
Maggie mktg mktg Marketing
Leonard legal legal Legal

AS on table name

SELECT fname, e.dept_code, d.dept_code, dept
FROM employees AS e
  JOIN departments AS d
    ON e.dept_code = d.dept_code;
Name e.Dept_Code d.Dept_Code Department
Liz legal legal Legal
Maggie mktg mktg Marketing
Leonard legal legal Legal

Outer Joins

Left Join

List employees and department info, if any.

(All employees are listed even without departments)

SELECT ... FROM t1 LEFT JOIN t2 ON ...

SELECT fname, e.dept_code, d.dept_code, dept
FROM employees AS e
  LEFT JOIN departments AS d
    USING (dept_code);
Name e.Dept_Code d.Dept_Code Department
Liz legal legal Legal
Maggie mktg mktg Marketing
Nadine NULL NULL NULL
Leonard legal legal Legal

Other Left Joins

List departments with employees, if any

(All departments are listed even without empoyees)

SELECT d.dept_code, dept, id, fname, e.dept_code
FROM departments AS d
  LEFT JOIN employees AS e
    USING (dept_code);
d.Dept_Code Department ID Name e.Dept_Code
mktg Marketing 2 Maggie mktg
legal Legal 3 Leonard legal
legal Legal 1 Liz legal
fin Finance NULL NULL NULL

Puzzles!

Empty Departments

“List the name and phone number of departments without any employees”

SELECT dept, phone
FROM departments AS d
  LEFT JOIN employees AS e
    USING (dept_code)
WHERE id IS NULL;
Dept Phone
Finance 555-9876

Tallying Salaries

Make a report of all departments, showing

  • the # of the employees they have
  • the total amount of salaries

An Incomplete Tally

SELECT dept_code, COUNT(*) AS num_emps, SUM(salary) AS total_salary
FROM employees
WHERE dept_code IS NOT NULL
GROUP BY dept_code;
Dept_Code # Emps Total Salary
legal 2 180000
mktg 1 70000

Where’s Finance?

Complete Tallies

SELECT dept, COUNT(*) AS num_emps, SUM(salary) AS total_salary
FROM departments
  LEFT JOIN employees
    USING (dept_code)
GROUP BY dept;
Dept # Emps Total Salary
Finance 1 NULL
Legal 2 180000
Marketing 1 70000

Oops!

Dept # Emps Total Salary
Finance 1 NULL
Legal 2 180000
Marketing 1 70000 
SELECT dept, COUNT(*) AS num_emps, SUM(salary) AS total_salary
FROM departments
  LEFT JOIN employees
    USING (dept_code)
GROUP BY dept;

COUNT(*) vs COUNT(field)

COUNT(*)
Counts items in a group, total
COUNT(field)
Counts number of known (not-NULL) values in field
id salary
1 50000
2 25000
3 NULL
4 NULL
5 NULL 
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM salaries;  -- 5

SELECT COUNT(id) FROM salaries; -- 5

SELECT COUNT(salary) fROM Salaries; -- 2

Complete Tallies

SELECT dept, COUNT(id) AS num_emps, SUM(salary) AS total_salary
FROM departments
  LEFT JOIN employees
    USING (dept_code)
GROUP BY dept;
Dept # Emps Total Salary
Finance 0 NULL
Legal 2 180000
Marketing 1 70000

Full Outer Joins

List all employees and all departments

(Includes everything)

SELECT d.dept_code, dept, id, fname, e.dept_code
FROM departments AS d
  FULL OUTER JOIN employees AS e
    USING (dept_code);
d.Dept_Code Department ID Name e.Dept_Code
legal Legal 1 Liz legal
legal Legal 3 Leonard legal
mktg Marketing 2 Maggie mktg
fin Finance NULL NULL NULL
NULL NULL 4 Nadine NULL

(Many databases can’t do these)


If we couldn’t make a complete salary report using a FULL OUTER JOIN in our database, we could make the same report effectively by using another feature of SQL, UNION:

SELECT dept, COUNT(*) AS num_emps, SUM(salary) AS total_salary
FROM departments
  LEFT JOIN employees
    USING (dept_code)
GROUP BY dept
UNION ALL
SELECT 'NONE', COUNT(*), SUM(Salary)
FROM employees
  LEFT JOIN departments
    USING (dept_code)
WHERE departments.dept_code IS NULL;

Subqueries

Sample Subquery

“Find all employees paid more than all marketers”

SELECT id, fname, salary, dept_code
FROM employees
  WHERE salary >
    (SELECT MAX(salary)
     FROM employees
     WHERE dept_code='mktg');
ID Name Salary Dept_code
1 Liz 90000 legal
3 Leonard 90000 legal

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • Object Relational Mappers
  • Using SQL from Python / Flask
  • Data Modeling

Tutorial: SQLZoo

Classes 4

Hackbright Engineering January 2020

Classes 4

« Back to Homepage

  • Classes 4
    • Intro
      • Review: Why Do We Use Classes?
      • An Opening
      • Goals
    • Instance Methods
      • The Cat Class so farâ¦
      • Hungry Cat
      • Instance Methods
    • Static Methods
      • Why Static Methods?
      • Static Methods
    • Class Methods
      • Why Class Methods?
      • Class Methods
    • Looking Ahead

Classes 4

Intro

Review: Why Do We Use Classes?

Abstraction

Hide details we donât need

Encapsulation

Keep everything âtogetherâ

Polymorphism

Interchangeability of components

An Opening

Show me your flowcharts and conceal your tables,
and I shall continue to be mystified.

Show me your tables, and I wonât usually need
your flowcharts; theyâll be obvious.

âFrederick P. Brooks, Jr., The Mythical Man Month

Goals

Learn about static methods and class methods
so that when we run

>>> from cats import Cat

â¦ weâll have everything we need!

Instance Methods

The Cat Class so farâ¦

class Cat:
    greet = 'Meow'
    species = 'cat'

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def speak(self):
        print(f"{self.greet}, I'm {self.name} the {self.species}")

>>> felix = Cat('Felix')
>>> felix.species
'cat'

>>> felix.name = 'Dr. Felix'
>>> felix.speak()
Meow, I'm Dr. Felix the cat

Hungry Cat

Since cats love eating so much, letâs add:

class Cat:
    # (...snippet)

    def __init__(self, name, hunger=70):
        self.name = name
        self.hunger = hunger

    # (...snippet)

    def feed(self, calories):
        self.hunger = self.hunger - calories

Instance Methods

Instance methods are methods that should do something on an instance

  • Thatâs why we call them on an instance

    >>> felix.feed(10)

  • Itâs also why they need to take in self

    • Instance methods need to access instance attributes

    • Instance methods might call other instance methods

Static Methods

Why Static Methods?

Our feed method takes calories.

Weâd like a conversion function for kibble â calories.

class Cat:
    # (...snippet)


def kibble_to_calories(kibble):
    """Converts one piece of kibble to calories."""

    return kibble * 0.3456

One problem â we can no longer get all cat-related things with just

>>> from cats import Cat

Letâs move kibble_to_calories into the Cat class:

class Cat:
    # (...snippet)

    def kibble_to_calories(self, kibble):
        """Converts one piece of kibble to calories."""

        return kibble * 0.3456

  • Better organized; cat-stuff-with-cat-stuff

  • We can call auden.kibble_to_calories(10)

There are a couple problems with this approach:

  • kibble_to_calories isnât really about a single cat

    • It never uses self â the code is the same for every cat

    • Since itâs not related to instances at all, it shouldnât be an instance method

  • Also, we lose some flexibility this way

    • We canât use kibble_to_calories without creating a cat instance

    • It would be nice to convert kibbles â calories with or without a cat

Static Methods

kibble_to_calories is better as a static method

class Cat:
    # (...snippet)

    @staticmethod
    def kibble_to_calories(kibble):
        """Converts one piece of kibble to calories."""

        return kibble * 0.3456

To create a static method:

  • Add the @staticmethod decorator

  • Donât add self to the parameter list

Static methods are used to organize functions that are
related to Cat but have nothing to do with individual cats!

  • Static methods make it clear that a method will never use or need self

  • As a result, we can call kibble_to_calories without a cat instance

    >>> Cat.kibble_to_calories(10)

  • And we still achieve our goal of getting all cat-related things with

    >>> from cats import Cat

Class Methods

Why Class Methods?

Letâs write a function that can instantiate a Cat with data from a database!

CAT_SELECT = 'SELECT name, hunger FROM cats WHERE name = :name'

def get_cat_from_db(name):
    """Get cat with given name from database."""

    cursor = db.session.execute(CAT_SELECT, {'name': name})
    cat_db_row = cursor.fetchone()
    hunger = cat_db_row[1]   # row is (name, hunger)

    return Cat(name, hunger)

Yay!

>>> auden = get_cat_from_db('Auden')
>>> auden.name
'Auden'

There are a couple problems with this approach:

  • Weâre still defining things about the class outside of it

  • But we couldnât make an instance method to âget a catâ

    • Since weâd need a cat to do that!

  • We canât use a static method to âget a catâ

    • Since we need to talk about the class

Class Methods

class Cat:
    _SELECT = 'SELECT name, hunger FROM cats WHERE name = :name'

    # (...snippet)

    @classmethod
    def get_from_db(cls, name):
        """Get cat with given name from database."""

        cursor = db.session.execute(cls._SELECT, {'name': name})
        cat_db_row = cursor.fetchone()
        hunger = cat_db_row[1]   # row is (name, hunger)

        return cls(name, hunger)

Class methods operate on a class, not an instance

  • Theyâre often used to provide alternative ways to construct an instance

  • They take in a cls parameter â the class theyâre called on

  • Canât refer to instance methods â thereâs no instance yet!

    • But we can refer to class attributes and class methods

Use-cases for the cls parameter in inheritance

You may have noticed that Cat.get_cat_from_db can be made to work as a static method, since thereâs nothing stopping us from doing something like this:

class Cat:
    # (...snippet)

    @staticmethod
    def get_cat_from_db(name)
        """Get cat with given name from database."""

        cursor = db.session.execute(cls._SELECT, {'name': name})
        cat_db_row = cursor.fetchone()
        hunger = cat_db_row[1]   # row is (name, hunger)

        return Cat(name, hunger)

Itâs not pretty, but it worksâ¦ or does it?

What if, one day, we create subclass of Cat:

class FriendlyCat(Cat):
    # (...snippet)

FriendlyCat.get_cat_from_db will have a bug â itâs supposed to instantiate a FriendlyCat but it instead instantiates a Cat!

>>> shelly = FriendlyCat.get_cat_from_db('Shelly')
>>> shelly
<__main__.Cat object at 0x102bfdf10>

This is because we hardcoded the Cat constructor into Cat.get_cat_from_db instead of relying on cls to find the correct class for us.

If we make Cat.get_cat_from_db a class method again, everything will work properly:

class Cat:
    # (...snippet)

    @classmethod
    def get_from_db(cls, name):
        """Get cat with given name from database."""

        cursor = db.session.execute(cls._SELECT, {'name': name})
        cat_db_row = cursor.fetchone()
        hunger = cat_db_row[1]   # row is (name, hunger)

        return cls(name, hunger)


class FriendlyCat(Cat):
    # (...snippet)

>>> shelly = FriendlyCat.get_cat_from_db('Shelly')
>>> shelly
<__main__.FriendlyCat object at 0x10ba63d50>

Looking Ahead

Coming Up

  • Data Modeling

  • ORMs

Resources

How to Use Static, Class, or Abstract Methods in Python

Good overview of static and class methods (written in Python 2)

Exceptions: Creating your custom exceptions

Very briefly shows you how to define your own exception and use it

Further Study

Python Cookbook

Great book for after Hackbright that covers advanced techniques used by library, framework, and application maintainers

SQL Alchemy

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

SQL Alchemy

« Back to Homepage

      • Querying

    • __repr__

    • Coming Up
      • Coming Up
      • Learning More

SQL Alchemy

Goals

Learn to use object-oriented techniques with relational DBs.

Without writing any SQL.

>>> auden = Cat(name="Auden", color="grey", hunger=50)

>>> auden.hunger
50

>>> auden.hunger = 20

SQLAlchemy ORM

  • Popular, powerful, Python-based ORM
  • Can use by itself, with Flask, or other web frameworks

OO into SQL

Model

A model like this:

class Cat(db.Model):
    """Feline catus."""

    __tablename__ = "cats"

    cat_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                       primary_key=True,
                       autoincrement=True,
                       )
    name = db.Column(db.String(50), nullable=False, unique=True,)
    color = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=True,)
    hunger = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False, default=20,)

Would turn into this SQL:

CREATE TABLE cats (
        cat_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
        name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
        color VARCHAR(10),
        hunger INTEGER NOT NULL
)

Setup

Create or import SQLAlchemy and Flask objects

from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy


db = SQLAlchemy()

app = Flask(__name__)
app.secret_key = "SECRET"

Connect app with db

def connect_to_db(app, db_name):
    """Connect to database."""

    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = f"postgresql:///{db_name}"
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_ECHO"] = True
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS"] = False

    db.app = app
    db.init_app(app)

connect_to_db(app, "cats")
  • Can talk to SQLite, PostgreSQL, MySQL, and more
    • You (almost) never have to change code if you change databases
  • “Echo” shows you the SQL it executes
    • Very important for debugging/performance tuning

Models

Our Model

class Cat(db.Model):
    """Feline catus."""

    __tablename__ = "cats"

    cat_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                       primary_key=True,
                       autoincrement=True,
                       )
    name = db.Column(db.String(50), nullable=False, unique=True,)
    color = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=True,)
    hunger = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False, default=20,)
  • All models should subclass db.Model
  • Specify the tablename with __tablename__
class Cat(db.Model):
    """Feline catus."""

    __tablename__ = "cats"

    cat_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                       primary_key=True,
                       autoincrement=True,
                       )
    name = db.Column(db.String(50), nullable=False, unique=True,)
    color = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=True,)
    hunger = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False, default=20,)
  • Have to specify the type of column
  • Columns can contain NULL unless nullable=False
  • Can specify default, unique, primary_key, autoincrement

Creating the Database

db.create_all()
  • Create all the tables using this database connection
  • Only have to do once
    • No effect if tables already exist
  • If you change table schema
    • drop table & re-run

Modeling Behavior

class Cat(db.Model):
    """Feline catus."""

    __tablename__ = "cats"

    cat_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                       primary_key=True,
                       autoincrement=True,
                       )
    name = db.Column(db.String(50), nullable=False, unique=True,)
    color = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=True,)
    hunger = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False, default=20,)

    def greet(self):
        """Greet using name."""

        return f"I am {self.name}"

    def feed(self, units=10):
        """Nom nom nom."""

        self.hunger -= units
        self.hunger = max(self.hunger, 0)

Using our Model

To insert a new record, create a Cat instance

>>> tiger = Cat(name="Tiger", color="grey", hunger=20)
>>> tiger.hunger
20

>>> db.session.add(tiger)     # required to add to database!
>>> db.session.commit()       # commit the transaction

Then, to update the database

>>> tiger.feed()
>>> tiger.hunger
10

>>> db.session.commit()

You only have to use db.session.add() to add a new object once – you don’t need to keep adding it to the session each time you change it.

Querying

Cat.query.all()

SELECT *
FROM cats

Cat.query.get(1)

SELECT *
FROM cats
WHERE cat_id = 1

Cat.query.filter_by(color="grey").all()

SELECT *
FROM cats
WHERE color = 'grey'

Cat.query.filter(Cat.color == 'grey').all()

Cat.query.filter(Cat.hunger < 10).all()

SELECT *
FROM cats
WHERE hunger < 10

Cat.query.filter(Cat.hunger < 10,
                 Cat.color == "grey").all()

SELECT *
FROM cats
WHERE hunger < 10
  AND color = 'grey'

Fetching Records

.all()
Get all records as a list
.first()
Get first record or None
.one()
Get first record, error if 0 or if > 1

Class Methods

  • Most methods are “instance methods”
    • These are called on an instance of a class (ie, a single cat)
    • They can refer to/change attributes of that instance
  • Some methods are “class methods”
    • They are called on the class itself
    • They can’t refer to instance attributes
    • Often used as “factories” to return instances
in the Cat class definition
@classmethod
def get_by_color(cls, color):
    """Get all cats matching that color."""

    return cls.query.filter_by(color=color).all()

>>> Cat.get_by_color("grey")
[<Cat ...>, <Cat ...>]

__repr__

>>> Cat.get_by_color("grey")
[<Cat 1>, <Cat 2>]

Yeah, but which cat is that?

    def __repr__(self):
        """Show info about cat."""

        return f"<Cat id={self.cat_id} name={self.name}"

>>> Cat.query.get(1)
<Cat id=1 name=Auden>

SQLAlchemy with Flask

Flask-SQLAlchemy

  • Add-on product to integrate Flask and SQLAlchemy
  • Benefits
    • Ties SQLAlchemy session to Flask response
    • Simplifies finding things in SQLAlchemy API
    • Simplifies querying by allowing on class

Plain Python API vs Flask-SQLAlchemy

from sqlalchemy import Column, String, \
        create_engine
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import \
        declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker

DB_URI = "postgresql:///cats"

Base = declarative_base()

class Cat(Base):
    name = Column(String(50))

engine = create_engine(DB_URI, echo=True)
Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
session = Session()

Base.metadata.create_all(engine)

# Add cats
auden = Cat(name='Auden', color='grey')
session.add(auden)
session.commit()

from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy

app = Flask(__name__)

DB_URI = "postgresql:///cats"

# Everything comes off this tidy object
db = SQLAlchemy()

class Cat(db.Model):
    name = db.Column(db.String(50))

app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = DB_URI
db.app = app
db.init_app(app)

db.create_all()

# Add cats
auden = Cat(name="Auden", color="grey")
db.session.add(auden)
db.session.commit()

Coming Up

  • SQLAlchemy II: relationships and joins
  • Project time: lots of individual instruction!

Learning More

SQLAlchemy Docs


Flask-SQLAlchemy Docs

SQL Alchemy II

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

SQL Alchemy II

« Back to Homepage

  • SQL Alchemy II
    • Querying
      • Recap
      • More Flexible Querying
      • Returning Tuples
      • Chaining
      • Fetching Records
      • Get by PK
    • Common Operators
      • Operators
    • Relationships
      • Related Tables

    • Learning More
      • Self-Learning
      • Learning More

SQL Alchemy II

Querying

Recap

class Employee(db.Model):
    """Employee."""

    __tablename__ = "employees"

    employee_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True, autoincrement=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, unique=True)
    state = db.Column(db.String(2), nullable=False, default='CA')
    dept_code = db.Column(db.String(5), db.ForeignKey('departments.dept_code'))
    salary = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=True)

    def __repr__(self):

SELECT * FROM employees
WHERE name = 'Liz';

Employee.query.filter_by(name='Liz')

Employee.query.filter(Employee.name == 'Liz')

More Flexible Querying

SELECT * FROM employees
WHERE name = 'Liz';

Simple version:

Employee.query.filter_by(name='Liz')
Employee.query.filter(Employee.name == 'Liz')

More flexible version:

db.session.query(Employee).filter_by(name='Liz')
db.session.query(Employee).filter(Employee.name == 'Liz')

This doesn’t seem to gain us anything, but this general form of db.session.query(...) allows us to query more flexibly than a single model class.

Returning Tuples

SELECT employee_id, name FROM employees;

>>> db.session.query(Employee.employee_id, Employee.name).all()
[(1, u'Leonard'), (2, u'Liz'), (3, u'Maggie'), (4, u'Nadine')]

Useful when:

  • You only care about a few fields
  • You’re joining multiple tables

Chaining

all_emps = db.session.query(Employee.employee_id, Employee.name)

just_ca = all_emps.filter(Employee.state == 'CA')

Remember: nothing runs until we get results:

>>> just_ca
<flask_sqlalchemy.BaseQuery at 0x105234750>

>>> just_ca.all()
[(1, u'Leonard'), (2, u'Liz'), (3, u'Maggie'), (4, u'Nadine')]

Fetching Records

.all()
Get all records
.first()
Get first record, ok if there is none
.one()
Get only record, error if 0 or more than 1
.count()
Get number of records found without fetching

Get by PK

>>> Department.query.filter_by(dept_code='fin').one()
<Department code=fin name=Finance>

>>> Department.query.get('fin')
<Department code=fin name=Finance>

Common Operators

Operators

Employee.query.filter(Employee.name == 'Jane')

Employee.query.filter(Employee.name != 'Jane')

Employee.query.filter(Employee.salary > 70000)

Employee.query.filter(Employee.name.like('%Jane%'))       # LIKE

Employee.query.filter(Employee.state.in_(['CA', 'OR']))   # IN ()

Employee.query.filter(Employee.state == None)       # IS NULL

Employee.query.filter(Employee.state.is_(None))     # IS NULL


Employee.query.filter(Employee.state != None)       # IS NOT NULL

Employee.query.filter(Employee.state.isnot(None))   # IS NOT NULL

q = Employee.query

AND:

q.filter(Employee.state == 'CA', Employee.salary > 70000)

q.filter( (Employee.state == 'CA') & (Employee.salary > 70000) )

OR:

q.filter( db.or_(Employee.state == 'CA', Employee.salary > 70000) )

q.filter( (Employee.state == 'CA') | (Employee.salary > 70000) )

NOT

Employee.query.filter( db.not_(Employee.state.in_(['CA', 'OR'])) )

Employee.query.filter( ~ Employee.state.in_(['CA', 'OR']) )

Relationships

Related Tables

class Department(db.Model):
    """Department. A department has many employees."""

    __tablename__ = "departments"

    dept_code = db.Column(db.String(5), primary_key=True)
    dept_name = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, unique=True)

    def __repr__(self):

class Employee(db.Model):
    ...

    dept_code = db.Column(
          db.String(5),
          db.ForeignKey('departments.dept_code'))
  • Add an actual field, dept_code
  • ForeignKey makes primary/foreign key relationship
    • Parameter is string “tablename.fieldname”
    • Database will handle referential integrity
class Employee(db.Model):
    """Employee."""

    # ...

    dept_code = db.Column(
          db.String(5),
          db.ForeignKey('departments.dept_code'))

    dept = db.relationship('Department')
  • relationship allows SQLAlchemy to “navigate” this relationship
    • Using the name dept on an Employee
class Department(db.Model):
    """Department. A department has many employees."""

    # ...

    employees = db.relationship('Employee')
  • Can get list of employee objects from dept with .employees

Backreference

You can specify both “ends” of a database relationship as shown above: going from an employee to their department with .dept and from a department to their employees with .employees.

SQLAlchemy also allows a shortcut that some people prefer—that you can just declare one relationship, and note the “backreference” for it.

To do this, you wouldn’t need .employees attribute on the Department class and could just put this on the Employee class:

dept = db.relationship( 'Department', backref='employees')

Both give the same results—you can navigate from an employee to their department and from a department to its employees, so which you use is a matter of aesthetic preference.

Navigating

class Employee(db.Model):
    ...
    dept = db.relationship('Department')

class Department(db.Model):
    ...
    employees = db.relationship('Employee')

>>> leonard = Employee.query.filter_by(name='Leonard').one()

>>> leonard.dept_code
u'legal'

>>> leonard.dept
<Department code=legal name=Legal>

>>> legal = Department.query.get('legal')

>>> legal.employees
[<Employee employee_id=1 name=Leonard>,
 <Employee employee_id=2 name=Liz>]

Using Relationships

Our Goal

“Show phone directory of employees and their department.”
Name Department Phone
Leonard Legal 555-2222
Liz Legal 555-2222
Maggie Marketing 555-9999
Nadine - -

Navigating

phone_dir_nav():

emps = Employee.query.all()

for emp in emps:    # [<Emp>, <Emp>]
    if emp.dept is not None:
        print(emp.name, emp.dept.dept_code, emp.dept.phone)
    else:
        print(emp.name, "-", "-")
  • Yay! So pretty! So easy!
  • Boo! So inefficient!

This is inefficient because SQLAlchemy fires off several queues:

  • one for the list of employees
  • one for each department

Ask In Advance

phone_dir_nav_eager():

emps = Employee.query.options(db.joinedload('dept')).all()

for emp in emps:    # [<Emp>, <Emp>]
    if emp.dept is not None:
        print(emp.name, emp.dept.dept_code, emp.dept.phone)
    else:
        print(emp.name, "-", "-")

By adding db.joinedload('dept'), we’ve signalled to SQLAlchemy that it should “eagerly load” the department for employees by using a join-style query.

Joining

Can also specify joins directly

  • Can be more explicit about what you want to get
  • Connect tables without defined relationships
  • Needed for outer joins

phone_dir_join():

emps = db.session.query(Employee.name,
                        Department.dept_name,
                        Department.phone).join(Department).all()

for name, dept_name, phone in emps:      # [(n, d, p), (n, d, p)]
    print(name, dept_name, phone)

Don’t forget to add .join() to join the second table—otherwise, you won’t get an INNER JOIN, but will get a “cross join”, where all employees are joined with all departments!

phone_dir_join_class():

emps = db.session.query(Employee,
                        Department).join(Department).all()

for emp, dept in emps:  # [(<Emp>, <Dept>), (<Emp>, <Dept>)]
    print(emp.name, dept.dept_name, dept.phone)

Outer Join

phone_dir_join_outerjoin():

emps = db.session.query(Employee,
                        Department).outerjoin(Department).all()

for emp, dept in emps:
    if dept is not None:
        print(emp.name, dept.dept_name, dept.phone)
    else:
        print(emp.name, "-", "-")

Learning More

Self-Learning

q = Employee.query

q.group_by('state')

q.group_by('state').having(db.func.count(Employee.employee_id) > 2)

q.order_by('state')

q.offset(10)

q.limit(10)

All described at Query Docs

Learning More

SQLAlchemy Docs

Flask-SQLAlchemy Docs

Data Modeling

Hackbright Engineering February 2020

Data Modeling

Data Modeling

Goals

  • Clarify the data modeling choices in ratings
  • Discuss types of relationships between tables
  • Introduce technology and terminology for data modeling

Ratings

Our Rating App

Questions

  • What is the cardinality of the users-to-ratings relationship?
    • How many ratings can a user make?
  • What about the cardinality of the movies-to-ratings relationship?
  • Has-many relationship, or one-to-many relationship
    • A user has many ratings
    • A movie has many ratings
    • A rating has only one user, only one movie

More Formally

Normalization

The Problem

We need to store contact information in our database

Problem — some people have many phone numbers

Solution 1: Many Rows

user_id fname lname age phone1
1 Jane Jay 26 415 555 1212
2 Jane Jay 26 415 555 1213
3 Nick Nest 43 415 555 2000

Solution 2: Many Columns

user_id fname lname age phone1 phone2
1 Jane Jay 26 415 555 1212 415 555 1213
2 Nick Nest 43 415 555 2000 <null>

Two Primary Sins of Data Modeling

  1. Repeating dependencies (for example, storing Jane’s name and age twice)
  2. Representing multiple data for the same category in columns (phone1, phone2, ..., phoneInfinity)

This lecture will address how to avoid these sins!

Normalization: In Short

“Every piece of information lives in exactly one place
and relates directly to the key.”

Relationship Types

  • One-to-many
  • Many-to-many
  • One-to-one

One-to-many

I Have Lots of Cats

The Problem

We have a database of books

Problem — we want to record each printing of a book

  • Can a book have many printings?
  • Can a printing have many books?

Diagram

One book, many printings

SQLAlchemy Review

In the Printing class, what are these lines doing?

class Printing(db.Model):
    """Printing of a book."""

    __tablename__ = 'printings'

    printing_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    book_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                        db.ForeignKey('books.book_id'),
                        nullable=False)
    print_date = db.Column(db.DateTime)

    book = db.relationship('Book', backref='printings')
  • Field can’t be blank; each printing must have a book_id
  • book_id is defined as a foreign key (referential integrity)
  • Referential integrity prevents:
    • book_id in printings table but not in books table
    • Can’t delete from books table if book has a printing

What is the book definition doing?

class Printing(db.Model):
    """Printing of a book."""

    __tablename__ = 'printings'

    printing_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    book_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                        db.ForeignKey('books.book_id'),
                        nullable=False)
    print_date = db.Column(db.DateTime)

    book = db.relationship('Book', backref='printings')
  • Establishes SQLAlchemy relationship between tables
  • Navigate relationship from printing to book
  • Can use attributes book
    • Not a field in the table, but a “magic” attribute
    • Returns object or list of objects

Alternate relationship syntax: backref

Different means to same “navigation”:

class Book(db.Model):
    # ...

    printings = db.relationship('Printing')


class Printing(db.Model):
    # ...

    book = db.relationship('Book')

class Book(db.Model):
    # ...

    printings = db.relationship(
        'Printing',
        backref='book')


class Printing(db.Model):
    # ...

Using “backref” in the relationship definition on Book allows you to create both relationships in a single statement.

SQL

In PostgreSQL, that creates this SQL:

CREATE TABLE books (
    book_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    title VARCHAR(50)
);

CREATE TABLE printings (
    printing_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    book_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES books,
    print_date TIMESTAMP
);

Many-to-many

As Facebook says, “It’s Complicated”.

The Problem

In our books database, users can comment on books

Problem —

  • Can a user comment on many books?
  • Can a book be commented on by many users?

Users can have many books, books can have many users...?

Many-to-many: A Lie?

Many-to-many is kind of a lie

  • There’s no actual relationship between books and users
  • Need a middle table (a comments table) to connect them
  • In reality, two one-to-many relationships
    • A book has many comments
    • A user has many comments

Comments Diagram

A book can have many comments (by many users)

A user can have many comments (on many books)

Comments SQLAlchemy

data-modeling-demo/many_to_many.py
class Book(db.Model):
    """Book."""

    __tablename__ = 'books'

    book_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    title = db.Column(db.String(50))

    comments = db.relationship("Comment")
data-modeling-demo/many_to_many.py
class User(db.Model):
    """User of site."""

    __tablename__ = 'users'

    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    email = db.Column(db.String(50))

    comments = db.relationship("Comment")
data-modeling-demo/many_to_many.py
class Comment(db.Model):
    """Comment on a book by a user."""

    __tablename__ = 'comments'

    comment_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    book_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                        db.ForeignKey('books.book_id'),
                        nullable=False)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                        db.ForeignKey('users.user_id'),
                        nullable=False)
    body = db.Column(db.Text, nullable=False)

    book = db.relationship("Book")
    user = db.relationship("User")

Comments SQL

In PostgreSQL, that creates this SQL:

CREATE TABLE books (
    book_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    title VARCHAR(50)
);

CREATE TABLE users (
    user_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    email VARCHAR(50)
);

CREATE TABLE comments (
    comment_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    book_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES books,
    user_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES users,
    body TEXT
);

Uniqueness of Many to Many Relationship

There is the possibility of the same user making multiple comments on one book, with each comment a separate row in the comments table. If you want to limit a user to a single comment on a book, you can impose a uniqueness condition on the combined fields user_id and book_id in the comments table. This is easily done in SQL but somewhat more cumbersome in SQLAlchemy.

Many-to-many: Genres

Another many-to-many example

The New Problem

In our books database, books have genres

Problem —

  • Can a book have many genres?
  • Can a genre have many books?

What do we call the middle table?

  • No obvious name like “comments”
  • Often use combination of table names: BookGenre

BookGenre Diagram

Instead of this —

Middle Table vs. Association Table

  • Middle table (example: Comment)
    • Middle tables have meaningful fields
  • Association table (example: BookGenre)
    • No meaningful fields
    • Simply the “glue” between books and genres
  • Database can’t tell the difference between association and middle tables
    • Design decision
    • Define relationship differently in SQLAlchemy

BookGenre SQLAlchemy

data-modeling-demo/many_to_many_genre.py
class Genre(db.Model):
    """Genre of book."""

    __tablename__ = 'genres'

    genre_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    genre = db.Column(db.String(50), unique=True)
data-modeling-demo/many_to_many_genre.py
class Book(db.Model):
    """Book."""

    __tablename__ = 'books'

    book_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    title = db.Column(db.String(50))

    genres = db.relationship("Genre",
                             secondary="books_genres",
                             backref="books")
data-modeling-demo/many_to_many_genre.py
class BookGenre(db.Model):
    """Genre of a specific book."""

    __tablename__ = 'books_genres'

    book_genre_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    book_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                        db.ForeignKey('books.book_id'),
                        nullable=False)
    genre_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                         db.ForeignKey('genres.genre_id'),
                         nullable=False)

BookGenre SQL

In PostgreSQL, that creates this SQL:

CREATE TABLE books (
    book_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    title VARCHAR(50)
);

CREATE TABLE genres (
    genre_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    genre VARCHAR(50)
);

CREATE TABLE books_genres (
    book_genre_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    book_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES books,
    genre_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES genres
);

One-to-one

I’m a Special Kind of Thing

The Problem

Twitter has millions of users

They have hundreds of employees, who are required to be Twitter users

Problem —

  • Twitter needs to keep track of employees’ PII (personally identifiable info)
  • What’s wrong with putting PII (SSN, salary...) in the users table?

Diagram

In employees table, user_id is both primary key and foreign key, which means

  • Only one employee record per user (uniqueness)
  • Every employee must be a user (referential integrity)

When to Use One-to-one

One-to-one relationships are useful for:

  • Categories — “this is a special case of...”
    • Employees are a special type of users
  • Augment a table with additional data
    • Employees have salaries, SSNs, job titles, etc.
  • Analogous to subclasses in object orientation

SQLAlchemy

class User(db.Model):

    __tablename__ = 'users'

    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True, autoincrement=True)
    email = db.Column(db.String(50))

    employee = db.relationship("Employee",
                               uselist=False)

class Employee(db.Model):

    __tablename__ = 'employees'

    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer,
                        db.ForeignKey('users.user_id'),
                        primary_key=True)
    salary = db.Column(db.Integer)

    user = db.relationship("User",
                           uselist=False)

SQL

CREATE TABLE users (
    user_id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    email VARCHAR(50));

CREATE TABLE employees (
    user_id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY REFERENCES users,
    salary INTEGER);

Alternative implementation

We can also make a One to One relationship with a separate primary key (employee_id) and foreign key (user_id) in the employees table by imposing that the foreign key be unique and not nullable. This is equivalent to having one key be both primary and foreign. Use whichever approach makes more sense to you.

Using relationships best practices

Use objects, not ids:

Query the parent object, then use the relationship.

Avoid
hamlet = Book.query.filter_by(title="Hamlet").first()

printings = Printing.query.filter_by(
            book_id=hamlet.book_id))

for printing in printings:
    print(printing.print_date)
Prefer
hamlet = Book.query.filter_by(title="Hamlet").first()

for printing in hamlet.printings:
    print(printing.print_date)
Fewer queries
hamlet = Book.query.filter_by(title="Hamlet").options(
         db.joinedload('printings')).first()

for printing in hamlet.printings:
    print(printing.print_date)

The objects relate to each other. SQLAlchemy handles the SQL.

To create or update related objects:

Avoid
hamlet = Book(title="Hamlet")

db.session.add(hamlet)
db.session.commit()

hamlet_printing1 = Printing(book_id=hamlet.book_id,
                   print_date=datetime(2015, 1, 1))

db.session.add(hamlet_printing1)

hamlet_printing2 = Printing(book_id=hamlet.book_id,
                   print_date=datetime(2016, 2, 2))

db.session.add(hamlet_printing2)

db.commit()
Prefer
hamlet = Book(title="Hamlet")

hamlet_printing1 = Printing(book=hamlet,
                   print_date=datetime(2015, 1, 1))

db.session.add(hamlet, hamlet_printing1)

db.commit()
Even simpler
hamlet = Book(title="Hamlet")

hamlet.printings.append(
    Printing(print_date=datetime(2015, 1, 1))
)

db.session.add(hamlet, hamlet_printing1)

db.commit()

Backrefs

SQLAlchemy offers backrefs as a shortcut when defining relationships that make them easier to define and/or easier to use.

Shorthand for creating relationships on two related classes

  • Good: Only need one line of code to define both relationships
  • Bad: You have to look at all classes to see which ones relate to which

We still recommend using backrefs.

When the relationship has a clear direction:

  • Usually want to find all Printing objects relating to a Book
  • Usually don’t want to find out what Book a specific Printing refers to

Define the printings relationship on Book with a ‘book’ backref:

class Book(db.Model):
    # ...

    printings = db.relationship('Printing', backref='book')

back_populates

Using backrefs implicitly sets an attribute on relationships called back_populates . back_populates tells SQLAlchemy the name of the corresponding relationship on the other class. For example, if the Book class has a printings relationship to the Printing class, and the Printing class has a book relationship to the Book class, then we can use back_populates as follows:

class Book(db.Model):
    # ...

    printings = db.relationship('Printing',
                                back_populates='book')

class Printing(db.Model):
    # ...

    book = db.relationship('Book',
                            back_populates='printings')

This enables you to write the following code:

hamlet = Book(title="Hamlet")
hamlet_printing1 = Printing(book=hamlet,
                   print_date=datetime(2015, 1, 1))

db.session.add(hamlet)
db.session.commit()

Note that we only needed to add the hamlet object to the session. That’s because back_populates made it possible for SQLAlchemy to understand that it should also add the hamlet_printing1 object to the sesssion based on its book relationship that points to the hamlet object.

Without back_populates, you would have needed to do the following:

hamlet = Book(title="Hamlet")
hamlet_printing1 = Printing(book=hamlet,
                   print_date=datetime(2015, 1, 1))

db.session.add_all[(hamlet, hamlet_printing1)]
db.session.commit()

It’s important to note that, unlike backrefs, back_populates does not create the opposite relationship on the related class.

Considerations

How Much Detail?

Often times, you have to make decisions about how much detail the application needs—but it’s usually right to first model it out on paper in total.

What to Call Things?

  • Tablenames: book or books?
    • At Hackbright, we use books, but it is equally valid to use book
    • Be consistent!
  • Class name: Comment? BookUser? BookUserComment?
    • What are the advantages? Disadvantages?

Performance

Indexes can speed up common search/sort fields

We won’t cover them at Hackbright, but for databases with lots of data or complex queries, learning about “indexes” is useful—these allow you to mark particular fields to be indexed, so that searches or sorts against them can be done much faster.

“Denormalized” Data

Can get the number sold with:

SELECT book_id, title, COUNT(sale_id)
FROM books
  LEFT OUTER JOIN Sales USING (book_id)
GROUP BY book_id;

Can get sales with just:

SELECT book_id, title, num_sold
FROM books;

UML

While we’ve shown lots of examples here of a diagram style called an “entity/relationship diagram”, some data modelers work with a different visual language, called “UML” (the “Unified Modeling Language”). Note the same book/genre relationship as it would draw with the UML visual vocabulary:

Looking Forward

  • Homework tonight: Dark Crystal
  • Your project’s data model!
Testing Flask

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

Testing Flask

« Back to Homepage

  • Testing Flask
    • Testing Flask
      • Goals

    • Review
      • Integration Testing Flask App
      • setUp and tearDown
      • Flask Test Client
      • POST and form data
    • Breaking Down Code
      • Intermixed Concerns
      • Breaking Down Code

      • Coming Up

Testing Flask

Goals

  • Review Flask’s test client
  • Test databases
  • Testing with a Flask session
  • Advice on getting started

Why do we test?

  • You will write code that breaks rules that you wrote.
  • Other people will also break your rules.
  • Important part of being a software engineer

Review

Integration Testing Flask App

  • “Does this URL path map to a route function?”
  • “Does this route function return the right HTML?”
  • Use TestCase from the unittest library.
  • Your Flask app has a test_client method on it, which returns a pretend web browser.

setUp and tearDown

setUp and tearDown methods are called before/after each test.

from unittest import TestCase
from server import app

class FlaskTests(TestCase):

  def setUp(self):
      """Stuff to do before every test."""

      self.client = app.test_client()
      app.config['TESTING'] = True

  def tearDown(self):
      """Stuff to do after each test."""

  def test1(self):
      """Some test..."""

  def test2(self):
      """Some other test"""

Running this file would call: setUp, test1, tearDown, setUp, test2, tearDown

Flask Test Client

Use the Flask test client:

from unittest import TestCase
from server import app

class FlaskTests(TestCase):

  def setUp(self):
      """Stuff to do before every test."""

      self.client = app.test_client()
      app.config['TESTING'] = True

  def test_some_flask_route(self):
      """Some non-database test..."""

      result = self.client.get("/my-route")
      self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 200)
      self.assertIn('<h1>Test</h1>', result.data)

Good advice at http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/testing/

The response from a get or post request of the test_client includes the following attributes:

  • status_code HTTP status code (200, 404, etc)
  • headers HTTP headers (‘Content-Type’, etc)
  • data HTTP body (typically, HTML)

Note that usually people don’t check all the HTML in result.data, but will often just check for a few key words.

POST and form data

    def test_login(self):
        """Test login page."""

        result = self.client.post("/login",
                                  data={"user_id": "rachel", "password": "123"},
                                  follow_redirects=True)
        self.assertIn(b"You are a valued user", result.data)
  • data is a dictionary of form key/value pairs
  • result.data is the response string (html)

Breaking Down Code

Intermixed Concerns

How do we test this?

@app.route('/taxes', methods=['POST'])
def taxes():
    """Calculate taxes from web form."""

    income = request.form.get('income')

    # Calculate the taxes owed
    owed = income / 45.3 * random.randint(100) / other_stuff

    return render_template("taxes.html", owed=owed)

Breaking Down Code

Very often, you’ll want to separate web interface from logic

def calculate_taxes(income):
    """Calculate taxes owed for this income."""

    ...

@app.route('/taxes', methods=['POST'])
def taxes():
    """Calculate taxes from web form."""

    income = request.form.get('income')
    owed = calculate_taxes(income)

    return render_template("taxes.html", owed=owed)

Testing Flask & Databases

It is a bad idea to use your production database when testing.

Solution: Let’s create a separate test database with sample data.

    def setUp(self):
        """Stuff to do before every test."""

        # Get the Flask test client
        self.client = app.test_client()
        app.config['TESTING'] = True

        # Connect to test database
        connect_to_db(app, "postgresql:///testdb")

        # Create tables and add sample data
        db.create_all()
        example_data()

Create Sample Data

model.py
def example_data():
    """Create some sample data."""

    # In case this is run more than once, empty out existing data
    Employee.query.delete()
    Department.query.delete()

    # Add sample employees and departments
    df = Department(dept_code='fin', dept='Finance', phone='555-1000')
    dl = Department(dept_code='legal', dept='Legal', phone='555-2222')
    dm = Department(dept_code='mktg', dept='Marketing', phone='555-9999')

    leonard = Employee(name='Leonard', dept=dl)
    liz = Employee(name='Liz', dept=dl)
    maggie = Employee(name='Maggie', dept=dm)
    nadine = Employee(name='Nadine')

    db.session.add_all([df, dl, dm, leonard, liz, maggie, nadine])
    db.session.commit()

You only need a little sample data for testing.

Testing with the Flask Session

Testing Flask & Sessions

What if you can only visit a particular page if a user is logged in?

class FlaskTestsLoggedIn(TestCase):
    """Flask tests with user logged in to session."""

    def setUp(self):
        """Stuff to do before every test."""

        app.config['TESTING'] = True
        app.config['SECRET_KEY'] = 'key'
        self.client = app.test_client()

        with self.client as c:
            with c.session_transaction() as sess:
                sess['user_id'] = 1

    def test_important_page(self):
        """Test important page."""

        result = self.client.get("/important")
        self.assertIn(b"You are a valued user", result.data)

Be sure to set SECRET_KEY if you are using sessions.

Big Projects

Where do I even begin?

  • You don’t have to test EVERYTHING, ALL AT ONCE.
  • Refactor logic out of routes into helper functions.
  • Write unit tests for helper functions.
  • Use the Flask test client to test that one page is rendering and contains a word you expect.

Coming Up

  • Testing Approaches, an overview.
Projects: How Things Work

Hackbright Engineering February 2020

Projects: How Things Work

Overview

Goals

How do things work, day to day, during project time?

  • Whatâs different?

    • Scrum

    • Advising

    • Whiteboarding

  • What stays the same?

    • Morning Lectures, Queue, Check-ins, etc

  • Advice for project time

Scrums

What are Scrums?

Scrums are daily meetings of small teams of developers working independently.

  • You will meet daily right after lecture in your scrum group

  • Scrum groups have a Scrum Leader or Scrum Master

  • Scrum groups take turns reporting:

    • what theyâve done

    • what theyâre going to do that day

    • what theyâre stuck on (âblockersâ)

  • Scrum groups keep each other on track

If You Canât Be at Scrum

  • Emphasis on canât

  • Treat this like a job

  • You are responsible for contacting your scrum leader with your update

Advising

Meet with your advisor for a birdâs eye view of your project.

  • Where are you in relation to your MVP?

  • Check in on your work plan. What have you gotten done? Whatâs next?

  • This is not debugging time (see: Queue)

We wonât have scheduled advising in the morning or evening, so plan meeting times that work for your schedule during the day.

Whiteboarding

Whatâs Whiteboarding?

Whiteboarding is the process of solving problems at a whiteboard, often used in software engineering interviews.

Not all companies do this, but many do.

Problem topics include coding, algorithms, data structures, and more.

Whiteboarding at Hackbright

Weâll have lectures on whiteboarding techniques and question types, and will run practice whiteboarding sessions with you.

  • Practice sessions will happen in small groups.

  • Lectures and practice begin at the end of week 7.

  • In weeks 7â9, practice sessions will be in the afternoons at 1pm.

  • We will have longer sessions during weeks 10 and 11.

Lectures

What About Lectures?

Yes!

That is: yes, weâll still have them, every day at 9am.

  • Weeks 6 & 7: Developer Toolbox

    • Javascript frameworks, mapping products, Flask add-ons & more

  • Weeks 8 & 9: Core comp sci/interview stuff

    • Some of the most critical lectures at Hackbright

Attendance

Nothing has changed.

Please continue to plan to be here from 9amâ5pm every day. *

* Thereâs a little more flexibility in weeks 6â10 than in weeks 1â5. After scrum, students do sometimes take some time off campus to meet their mentors, for instance. But remember that queue time is valuable, and finite. Take advantage of it while it lasts!

As a rule, if you need to be off campus while the queue is open, check in with your advisor first.

The Queue

When Do We Queue?

  • Regular Hours:

    • After Scrumâ11:45pm

    • closed for lunch

    • 1pmâabout 4:45pm

  • Hang onto questions until the queue is open

Be True to the Queue

  • Help us keep the queue moving and be fair to all students

  • Keep your questions to the queue

  • No dibs on the queue when itâs closed

  • One question at a time

Queue Guidelines

There are a few things to keep in mind so that the queue is a fair and sane process for everyone.

The queue opens after scrum and will close a few minutes before lunch. It will open again after lunch and go until a few minutes before the end of the day.

Hang on to questions until the queue is open.

Itâs impossible for us to keep track of questions that come in when the queue is closed, especially when things get really busy. Plus by the time it opens, questions have usually changed. Weâll do everything we can to try to make sure everyone whoâs in queue gets helped. We wonât always succeed at this. But weâll do our best.

No dibs

We donât reserve spots in the queue or start queueing people for the next morning. Weâll carry the queue over if there are people who were in it when it closed and they still need help in the morning, though.

One question at a time

We want to help you get unstuck, plan, and problem solve. And then we leave so we can help the next person. Help us with this process by being mindful of asking for additional help on something else after your queue question is answered.

Reminders

  • We need you to answer some questions when asking for help:

    • Where are you?

    • What are you trying to do?

    • Whatâs the error youâre getting?

  • The queue isnât just for questions - feel free to ask for a code review, too!

Some Advice

Prepare for Scrum

What are you going to say during scrum?

Take a moment to reflect in the morning.

Work Spaces

  • Quiet areas

    • Not âlibrary quietâ but designed for undisturbed work

    • Queue conversations will still happen

  • Non-quiet areas

    • Feel free to collaborate, meet with your advisor or mentor, etc

Headphone Policy

If you are wearing headphones, no one is to disturb you

Exception: when you request help from Help Queue

Mentors

Mentors are great! You can:

  • pair with your mentor

  • ask your mentor to help you understand a particular subject

  • ask for code reviews (the more eyes on your code, the better)

Keep a Project Diary

What will the narrative of you building your project be? Itâll be hard to remember what you struggled with and what you were proud of, so keep a log.

Every day, try to make a note:

  • What did you struggle with?

  • Did you figure something out?

  • Did you fail to figure something out?

  • Did you make hard trade-offs?

  • What did you study?

  • What did you learn?

  • How do you work?

  • What do you need?

Take Short, Active Breaks

  • Go for a walk

  • Stretch

  • Practice mindfulness

  • Check in on your fellow fellowsâ projects

    • Do they need a rubber duck?

    • Do you?

Write Code Every Day

âExercise the writing muscle every day,
even if it is only a letter, notes, a title list,
a character sketch, a journal entry.

Writers are like dancers, like athletes.
Without that exercise, the muscles seize up.â

âJane Yolen

Learn

You might want to get a job, but youâre here to learn the skills to get that job.

So rejoice! Learning is the best part!

Time to Build an App!

JavaScript Language 1

Hackbright Engineering June 2018
