JavaScript Language 1

Goals

  • Why learn JavaScript?
  • Brief summary of resources and tools
  • Learn JavaScript syntax by comparing it with Python

Why JavaScript?

Itâs the standard high-level language used to program the browser

The low(er)-level language?

Itâs called WebAssembly.

Original Role of JavaScript

Handle browser interactions

  • Handling clicking, moving mouse, dragging, typing
  • Handling forms in browser
  • Talking to servers & updating page
  • Storing data in client
  • Animating objects
  • Geolocating
  • and more!

JavaScript Today

  • Still used to program the browser
  • Popular on the server side for handling back-end logic
  • Even used for programming native (desktop/mobile) applications

Modern JavaScript

JavaScript has changed significantly since 2015. If you have experience using pre-2015 JavaScript, take some time to re-learn it!

Resources and Tools

Documentation

MDN: JavaScript Reference

Created by the open source foundation behind Firefox

Node

Node (or Node.js) is a program that runs JavaScript

Itâs like the python command â it allows you to

  • start a Node REPL
  • run JavaScript files
  • run JavaScript files interactively

Running node with no arguments starts the REPL

$ node
>

node <filepath> runs a file

$ node server.js

To run a file interactively, you have to open the REPL and then use .load

$ node
> .load my_script.js

Use control-D to exit.

The PEP8 of JavaScript?

Weâll be loosely following the Airbnb style guide

There are many other style guides out there, but Airbnbâs is well-known and comprehensive

A word of caution on JavaScript tutorials

Some tutorials are outdated. Sometimes a writerâs knowledge of JavaScript is outdated! They may show examples that donât adhere to modern standards and best-practices.

Good tutorials do exist. Our recommendation for any online resource, about any language, is that you do your due diligience to understand what every line of code is doing. Donât just pattern-match blindly!

Syntax

// Pick a secret number
const myNumber = Math.floor(Math.random() * 100);

// Guess the number 50
let guess = 50;

if (guess < number) {
  console.log('Too low!');
} else if (guess > number) {
  console.log('Too high!');
} else {
  console.log('Yay!');
}
  • Pretty similar!
  • More punctuation, in general
  • Each statement ends with a semicolon
  • Curly braces are used where Python uses indentation
  • // makes rest of line a comment
  • Variables are midCase not snake_case
  • Two spaces for indentation

Multiline Comments

We show you that // starts a comment on a line, just like Pythonâs #.

JavaScript also has a âmultiline commentâ syntax; to start a comment, use /* and to end the comment, use */, like this:

/*
 * Add the integers together,
 * removing any that are negative
 *
 */

Of course, you donât need to use these â many people prefer the simplicity of remembering one kind of commenting, using //, so you could just put that at the start of each line to comment (AirBnB, until recently, advocated that all comments use //, even if they are multi-line comments):

// Add the integers together,
// removing any that are negative...

Printing

> console.log('Hi');
Hi

> console.log('Hello', 'World');
Hello World

> console.log(1 + 2);
3

Variables

  • Must declare variables with a keyword
  • Can assign value at time of declaration, or later
  • Variables can only be declared once
  • Variables come in two flavors, const and let

const

Prefer to declare variables with const
unless you need to reassign the variable later

You can mutate the value of a const variable

// Can add `0` to end of array
const nums = [7, 8];
nums.push(0);

You canât reassign a variable that was declared with const

// Can't reassign `nums` to a new array
nums = [1, 2, 3];

Controversial const

People have different opinions about whether you should default to using const or not. We recommend that you use const because itâs the industry standard.

In general, our recommendation is that you stick with your companyâs code style. Of course, after Hackbright, you can do whatever you want with code you write for yourself.

let

Declare variables with let if you need to be able to reassign its value

let totalScore = 100;

// Reassign `totalScore`
totalScore = totalScore + 1;

Summary

Python
user_score = 10
user_city = "Toronto"
user_birthday = "January 5"

birthdays = ["Jan 5"]
birthdays.append("Mar 21")

counter = 0
counter += 1
JavaScript
const userScore = 10;
const userCity = 'Toronto';
const userBirthday = 'January 5';

const birthdays = ['Jan 5'];
birthday.push('Mar 21');

let counter = 0;
counter += 1;

let and var

Earlier versions of JavaScript did not have let and const. Instead, variables were declared with the var keyword.

var myScore = 10;

var is a vestige of old JavaScript syntax. As with many old JavaScript constructs, the way var works leads to unexpected behavior which leads to bugs that are difficult to debug.

For backwards compatibility reasons, var still works. In fact, many people still use var because they donât know any better or they havenât updated their code. You do know better, so you should never use var.

Operators

Conditional Operators

Conditional Operation Python JavaScript
Less than < <
Greater than > >
Less than or = <= <=
Greater than or = >= >=
Equality   ==
Strict equality == ===
Inequality   !=
Strict inequality != !==

Prefer using === and !== over == and !=

Type Coercion

JavaScript is primarily used on the web, where most information comes in as strings, so itâs a nice feature of the language that "42" == 42 returns true.

This feature is called coercion or type coercion

Unless you need type coercion to occur, you should prefer === and !==.

This Stack Overflow answer shows some of the unexpected results from ==.

The JavaScript Equality Table shows all the differences between == and ===.

Logical Operators

Logical Operator Python JavaScript
and and &&
or or ||
not not !

Incrementing/Decrementing

Incrementing and decrementing uses the same operators as Python

> let count = 1;
> count += 1;
2
> count -= 1;
1

Unary Increments/Decrements

You may see code examples where incrementing is performed with unary increments and decrements (++, --). Unary increment and decrement statements only add and subtract by 1.

> let counter = 1;
> counter++;
2
> counter--;
1

Avoid doing this in a professional context, since += and -= is much more expressive and less prone to errors.

Control Flow

Conditionals

Python
if x > 7:
    print("Too big")
elif x < 1:
    print("Too small")
else:
    print("Just right")
JavaScript
if (x > 7) {
  console.log('Too big');
} else if (x < 1) {
  console.log('Too small');
} else {
  console.log('Just right');
}

Braces arenât needed for single-line clausesâ¦ or are they??

Due to the way JavaScript is parsed, curly braces arenât required for one-line code blocks.

The following is valid code and would run without errors:

// Valid... but a bad idea
if (x > 7) console.log('Too big');
else if (x < 1) console.log('Too small');

// This is an even worse idea
if (name === 'Brighticorn')
  console.log('Hi');

Imagine that one of our teammates wrote the code, above.

Now, remember that most people expect that if-statements have curly braces around their code-blocks. Itâs easy to see why someone might accidentally do the following:

if (name === 'Balloonicorn')
  console.log('Hi!');
  score += 10;

Since whitespace doesnât matter to the JavaScript parser, only console.log('Hi!'); is part of this if clause.

This means that score += 10 will always execute, even if name isnât Balloonicorn!

Fun fact: this was the cause of Appleâs infamous goto fail bug (except they were programming in C).

While Loops

Python
i = 0
while i < 5:
    print(i)
    i += 1
JavaScript
let i = 0;
while (i < 5) {
  console.log(i);
  i += 1;
}

Generic For Loops

Generic for-loops donât have a Python analog

for (let i = 0; i < 5; i += 1) {
  console.log(i);
}

for (init; conditional; exp)
  • init is a variable declaration; executed once
  • conditional is evaluated before every iteration
  • exp is executed at the end of every iteration

Strings

MDN JavaScript Reference: String

How to read MDNâs JavaScript documentation

  • MDN will list examples and descriptions first
  • API docs come after
    • Properties â properties of the class
    • Methods â class methods
    • Instances â instance properties and methods

Single quotes are conventional
(double quotes still valid)

Python
name = "Jane"
JavaScript
const name = 'Jane';

Sequence Methods

In JavaScript and Python, arrays (lists) and strings are sequences, so they share many of the same methods and operators. Hereâs a handy reference table:

Operation Python JavaScript
Get length len(s) s.length
Concatenate s + t s + t
Multiply s * 2  
Search el in s s.includes(el)
Find index of s.index(el) s.indexOf(el)
Slice s[start:end] s.slice(start, end)

String Templating

In JavaScript, f-strings are called template literals

Python
message = f"Hello {name}!"
JavaScript
const message = `Hello ${name}!`;

Expressions are surrounded with ${ expr }

Numbers

MDN JavaScript Reference: Number

JavaScript doesnât make a distinction between floats and integers â theyâre all just numbers

To typecast strings to numbers

Python
float('1.5')
int('1')
JavaScript
Number('1.5');
Number('1');

Arrays

MDN JavaScript Reference: Array

Like Python lists, they are ordered, mutable collections of elements

Using Arrays

JavaScript arrays donât throw IndexErrors

You can assign to an index thatâs out of range

> const fruits = ['apple'];
> fruits[3] = 'berry';

You can get values from indices that donât exist

JavaScript
> fruits[0];
'apple'
> fruits[1];
undefined

Arrays are always truthy, even if theyâre empty

> const nums = [];

> if (nums) {
... console.log('nums is true!');
... }
nums is true!

Arrays: Iteration

forâ¦ ofâ¦ gets you each element of the array

Python
# Loop over elements
for state in states:
    print(state)
JavaScript
// Loop over elements
for (const state of states) {
  console.log(state);
}

forâ¦ inâ¦ gets you each index in the array

Python
# Generate range to loop over indices
for i in range(len(states)):
    print(i)
JavaScript
// Loop over indices
for (const i in states) {
  console.log(i);
}

Arrays: Common Operations

Python
# Create list
states = ["MD", "VA", "CA"]

# Get length
len(states)

# Constructor function
vowels = list("aeiou")

# Index into list
states[2]
states[-1]

# Slice list
states[2:]
states[:-1]
states[2:3]
states[2:3:2]

# Search
"CA" in states
"NH" in states
JavaScript
// Create an array
const states = ['MD', 'VA', 'CA'];

// Get length
states.length

// Constructor method
const vowels = Array.from('aeiou');

// Index into array
states[2];
// No negative indexing

// Slice
states.slice(2);
states.slice(0, -1);
states.slice(2, 3);
// No step

// Search
states.includes('CA');
states.includes('NH');

Arrays: Methods

Python
# Add to end
vowels.append("y")

# Remove from end
vowels.pop()

# Get index of el
vowels.index("a")

# Join to string
"".join(vowels)
JavaScript
// Add to end
vowels.push('y');

// Remove from end
vowels.pop();

// Get index of el
vowels.indexOf('a');

// Join to string
vowels.join('');

Array Destructuring

Array destructuring is similar to variable unpacking in Python

Python
>>> first, last = ['Hi', 'friends']
>>> first
'Hi'
>>> last
'friends'
JavaScript
> const [ first, last ] = ['Hi', 'friends'];
> first;
'Hi'
> last;
'friends'

Unlike Python, you donât have to completely unpack each value

Python
>>> a, b = [1, 2, 3]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)
JavaScript
> const [ a, b ] = [1, 2, 3];
> a;
1
> b;
2

None(s)

In Python, there is only one None-thing

In JavaScriptâ¦

undefined
No assigned value. Functions â by default â return undefined.
null
Explicitly having no value. More similar to Pythonâs None.
NaN
Not-a-Number. Gets returned when mathematical operations fail.

The following will all evaluate to falsey:

  • null
  • undefined
  • NaN
  • Empty string ('')
  • 0
  • false

Semicolons

  • Required after each expression:

    let x = 1;

  • Not after âblocksâ:

    if (x === 1) {
  console.log(x);
}

function adder(x, y) {
  return x + y;
}

  • Itâs dangerous to leave them off where needed!

  • Itâs dangerous to put them in where not required!

    • It gets read as an âempty expressionâ:
    if (x === 1) {
  console.log(x);
};                  // error! won't work!

else {
  console.log('not one');
}

Use Strict

Let JavaScript Help You

"use strict"; at top of file

"use strict";

// More code goes here

$ node --use-strict
  • Raises error for undeclared variables
  • Raises error for other common JS mistakes
    • See MDN JavaScript Reference: Strict Mode for more info

Protection From JavaScript Weirdness

Style Tip: Always start files with "use strict";

Without strict-mode, this wonât throw an error:

result = 1 + 2;

With strict-mode, this throws a ReferenceError:

"use strict";

result = (x + y) * 2;
// ReferenceError: result is not defined

Coming Up

  • Functions, objects, and sets
  • Inspecting/changing HTML via JavaScript
  • Handling events in browsers
JavaScript Language 2

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

      • Coming Up

JavaScript Language 2

Goals

Continue learning JavaScript syntax

  • Functions
  • Objects
  • Sets

Functions

Function Definitions

Python
def subtract(x, y):
    return x - y

# Default params
def add(x, y=0):
    return x + y
JavaScript
function subtract(x, y) {
  return x - y;
}

// Default params
function add(x, y = 0) {
  return x + y;
}

Calling Functions

Order still matters

Python
>>> subtract(2, 1)
1
>>> subtract(1, 2)
-1
JavaScript
> subtract(2, 1);
1
> subtract(1, 2);
-1

Keyword arguments donât work in JavaScript

Python
>>> subtract(y=1, x=2)
1  # x - y -> 2 - 1 = 1
JavaScript
> subtract(y = 1, x = 2);
-1  // x - y -> 1 - 2 = -1

JavaScript wonât throw an error if you donât pass enough
arguments to your function

function getArg(a) {
  return a;
}

The function will just return undefined

> getArg();
undefined

It also wonât throw an error if you pass in too many arguments

> getArg(1, 2);
1

Problems with Function Declarations

Function declarations behave in unexpected ways

In Python, you canât call a function before itâs been defined

function.py
print_msg('Hi!')

def print_msg(msg):
    print(msg)

$ python3 function.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 1, in <module>
    print_msg('hi')
NameError: name 'print_msg' is not defined

In JavaScript, you can call a function before itâs defined

function.js
printMsg('Hi!');

function printMsg(msg) {
  console.log(msg);
}

$ node function.js
Hi!

This can cause errors that are hard to debug, especially for large codebases.

A new way to define functions was created to solve these problems.

Arrow Function Expressions

This is a function expression, written with the arrow function syntax

const functionName = (listOfParams) => {

  // code block

};

Donât forget the semicolon after the closing curly brace!

For example

const subtract = (x, y) => {
  return x - y;
};

const add = (x, y = 0) => {
  return x + y;
};

Calling these functions works the same way

> subtract(2, 1);
1
> add(1, 1);
2

Old-school function expressions

Before the arrow function syntax was created, you could also write function expressions like this

const add = function (x, y = 0) {
  return x + y;
};

Actually, back in the day, const didnât exist and default parameters werenât a thing. For the sake of historical accuracy, function expressions actually looked like this

var add = function (x, y) {
  return x + y;
};

If your function only contains a one-line return statement,
you can leave out the curly braces and return statement

const subtract = (x, y) => x - y;

const add = (x, y = 0) => x + y;

The expression after => is automatically returned

If your function only has one parameter, you can omit the parentheses

const printMsg = msg => {
  console.log(msg);
};

Simulating keyword/named parameters

JavaScript does not allow named parameters, but you can simulate named parameters using an object (more on that later)

const lotsOfOptions = (opt = {}) => {
  const { color, letter } = opt;

  console.log(color, letter);
};

lotsOfOptions({ color: 'red', letter: 'Z' });
// > red Z

Function Declarations vs. Function Expressions

People still use both

  • Itâs important to recognize both syntaxes
  • Itâs important to be aware of the quirks of function declarations
  • Most people prefer function expressions

Objects

In JavaScript, you can make standalone objects without a class

MDN JavaScript Reference: Object

Like Python dictionaries, they are collections of key-value pairs

const melonCodes = {
  cren: 'Crenshaw',
  musk: 'Muskmelon'
};
  • Called plain objects
  • Often used as dictionaries

Using Objects

Attributes are called properties or keys

Like Python dictionaries

  • Properties must be unique
  • Values can be anything

Unlike Python dictionaries, properties can be

  • Valid identifiers (firstName)
  • Strings ('favorite word')
  • Numbers (500)

In most cases, you can get the value of a property with the dot operator (.)

const cat = {
  name: 'Marvin',
  'age': 2,
  'favorite smell': 'cotton'
};

> cat.name;
'Marvin'

It even works on properties that are strings

> cat.age;
2

In other cases, you can use square brackets ([])

Like when the property canât be accessed with the dot-operator

> cat['favorite smell'];
'cotton'

Or when you want to use a variable

> const prop = 'name';
> cat[prop];
'Marvin'

Objects donât throw KeyErrors

If you try to access a property that doesnât exist, it will return undefined

> cat.color;
undefined

Objects: Common Operations

Python
# Create dictionary
capitals = {
  "MD": "Annapolis",
  "CA": "Sacramento",
}

len(capitals)

# Index into dictionary
capitals["MD"]

# Add/update value
capitals["OR"] = "Salem"

# Check inclusion
"OR" in capitals
JavaScript
// Create object
const capitals = {
  MD: 'Annapolis',
  CA: 'Sacramento',
};

// No length

// Access values with dot-op
capitals.MD;
// Or with index
capitals['MD'];

// Add/update value
capitals.OR = 'Salem';

// Check inclusion
capitals.hasOwnProperty('OR');

Objects: Iteration

forâ¦ inâ¦ gets you each property (key)

Python
# Loop over keys
for state in capitals:
    print(state)
JavaScript
// Loop over properties (keys)
for (const state in capitals) {
  console.log(state);
}

forâ¦ ofâ¦ does not work

> for (const val of capitals) {
... console.log(val);
... }
Thrown:
TypeError: c is not iterable

Just like Python, we canât loop over values automatically.

We can use Object.values to get an array of values and then loop over the array

Python
# Loop over values
for capital in capitals.values():
    print(capital)
JavaScript
// Loop over values
for (const capital of Object.values(capitals)) {
  console.log(capital);
}

Object Destructuring

Object destructuring is similar to array destructuring

const melon = {
  commonName: 'watermelon',
  color: 'green',
  price: 2.0
};

> const { commonName, price } = melon;
> commonName
'watermelon'
> price
2.0

Sets

Like Python sets, Set objects are unordered, unique, mutable collections

MDN JavaScript Reference: Set

Using Sets

In JavaScript, Set objects have to be instantiated with the new keyword

Python
# Instantiate an inline set
set1 = {1, 2, 3}

# Instantiate with set function
set2 = set()

set3 = set(["a", "b"])
JavaScript
// No inline set syntax

// Instantiate with constructor
const set2 = new Set();

const set3 = new Set(['a', 'b']);

Sets: Iteration

forâ¦ ofâ¦ gets you each item in the set

Python
# Loop over items in set
for item in set2:
    print(item)
JavaScript
// Loop over items in set
for (const item of set2) {
  console.log(item);
}

Sets: Common Operations

Python
# Get length
len(set2)

# Add to set
set2.add(3)

# Remove from set
set2.remove(2)

# Check if value is in set
1 in set2
JavaScript
// Get length
set2.size;

// Add to set
set2.add(3);

// Remove from set
set2.delete(2);

// Check if value is in set
set2.has(1);

No Set Math

JavaScript doesnât have set math operators.

For example, this is what happens when we try adding two Set objects:

> const set1 = new Set([1, 2]);
> const set2 = new Set([3, 4]);
> set1 + set2
'[object Set][object Set]'

If you want to perform a union with two Set objects, youâll have to do it by hand

> const set1 = new Set([1, 2]);
> const set2 = new Set([3, 4]);

> const unionSet = new Set();

> for (const item of set1) {
... unionSet.add(item);
... }

> for (const item of set2) {
... unionSet.add(item);
... }

Coming Up

  • Use JavaScript in the browser to
    • change the contents of a webpage
    • react to user input (clicks, keypresses, etc.!)
  • Writing your own classes in JS
  • A taste of ReactJS (a frontend framework)

Books

Gentle Introduction:

Great Intermediate Book:

Further Study

The JavaScript ecosystem is huge â here are some ideas to get you started

  • The Node-equivalent of pip is npm
    • The Absolute Beginnerâs Guide to npm
  • ExpressJS is an unopinionated web framework, similar to Flask
  • Sequelize is similar to SQLAlchemy
JavaScript and DOM Manipulation

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

JavaScript and DOM Manipulation

« Back to Homepage

  • JavaScript and DOM Manipulation
    • Intro
      • Goals
    • JavaScript in Browsers
      • JavaScript in Browsers
      • Loading JavaScript
    • JavaScript Web API
      • JavaScript Web API
      • Whatâs the DOM?
      • Getting Elements from the DOM
      • Manipulating DOM Elements
    • jQuery
      • Why jQuery?
      • How to Use jQuery
      • Getting Elements with jQuery
      • DOM Manipulation with jQuery
      • jQuery or Built-in JavaScript?
    • Coming Up
      • Coming Up
      • Further Study

JavaScript and DOM Manipulation

Intro

Goals

Learn how to manipulate the browser with JavaScript

JavaScript in Browsers

Browsers have their own JavaScript runtime engines

  • Google Chrome uses the same engine as Node
  • Safari, Firefox, etc. use their own engines

There can be minor differences between implementations

Feature Compatibility Table

If youâre curious about the differences between platforms, check out this JavaScript compatibility table.

You can interact with your browserâs JS runtime through the Web Console

Open your browserâs developer tools â click on Console tab

  • Itâs a REPL, so you execute JS expressions and see what they do (just like python3)
  • This is also where any error messages, warnings, or print statements will appear

Loading JavaScript

There are two ways to include JavaScript in a web page

You can write inline JavaScript with the script tag

<body>
  <h1>JavaScript is fun!</h1>

  <script>
    console.log('Hello, world!');
  </script>
</body>

Even better, you can import code from a JavaScript file with the script tag

<body>
  <h1>JavaScript is neat!</h1>

  <script src="/static/helloWorld.js"></script>
</body>

When your browser encounters a script tag, it loads and executes that code

  • All code is executed in the same namespace, as if youâve copied and pasted all your code into one document
  • Be careful if youâve defined many globally-scoped variables or functions
    • Further study: look into loading JS files as modules and how to use the import/export statements

JavaScript Web API

A collection of classes, methods, functions, etc. that are built into your browser

They expose data from the browser so you can do useful, complex things with it

What else is in the Web API?

Some examples from MDN: Web API Documentation:

  • WebGL is used to render 2d and 3d images in the browser
  • The Notifications API is used to send notifications to your user
  • Ambient Light Events can help you execute code based on changes to ambient light

For example, these functions are used to open dialog windows in your browser

alert('Message to pop up');

confirm('Hey, user, is this ok?');
// => true or false

prompt('Enter a string');
// => the string that was entered

Weâll focus on the most commonly-used Web API â the document API

Itâs used to make change the contents of a web page by giving us the ability to manipulate the DOM

Whatâs the DOM?

DOM == Document Object Model

A tree that stores HTML elements as objects

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>The Title</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>First Heading</h1>
    <h2 class="urgent">Second Heading</h2>
  </body>
</html>

Getting Elements from the DOM

document.querySelector(selector)

Return one HTMLElement object that matches the selector

Reference: MDN Web Docs: Document.querySelector()

<p class="lead">
  DOM manipulation is fun.
</p>
<p id="main-content">
  Here's how you do it.
</p>

document.querySelector('p');
// => <p class="lead">

document.querySelector('#main-content');
// => <p id="main-content">
document.querySelectorAll(selector)

Return a collection of HTMLElement objects that match the selector

Reference: MDN Web Docs: Document.querySelectorAll())

<p class="lead">
  DOM manipulation is fun.
</p>
<p id="main-content">
  Here's how you do it.
</p>

document.querySelectorAll('p');
// => NodeList [ <p class="lead">, <p id="main-content"> ]

Manipulating DOM Elements

HTMLElement objects have methods and properties for you to get/set data about them

Reference: MDN Web Docs: HTMLElement

How to use the docs

Check out MDNâs documentation for the HTMLElement object and youâll notice that there are more than a few methods missing from the Methods list. Theyâre not actually missing from the docs!

HTMLElement inherits methods and properties from its parent class, Element. If you want a complete list of methods and properties available on HTMLElement objects, you should also check out MDN Web Docs: Element.

You can get/set the HTML inside an element

<a href="/about">About</a>

const aboutLink = document.querySelector('a');

aboutLink.innerHTML;  // => "About"

aboutLink.innerHtml = 'About Me';
Result of setting innerHTML
<a href="/about">About Me</a>

You can get/set attributes

<img src="cat.jpg">

const catPhoto = document.querySelector('img');

catPhoto.getAttribute('src');  // => 'cat.jpg'

catPhoto.setAttribute('src', 'cat2.gif')
Result of setAttribute
<img src="cat2.png">

Get a list of the elementâs classes

<div class="container blog-content"></div>

const blogContainer = document.querySelector('div');

blogContainer.classList;
// => DOMTokenList [ "container", "blog-content" ]

Add/remove a class

blogContainer.classList.remove('blog-content');

blogContainer.classList.add('article');
Result
<div class="container article"></div>

Check out the documentation for more things you can change!

jQuery

Why jQuery?

We want to add a new task that says 'Learn jQuery'

<h1>Task List</h1>
<ul>
  <li>Do something fun on the weekend!</li>
  <li>Buy myself a cupcake</li>
</ul>

Without jQuery:

const taskList = document.querySelector('ul');

const newTask = document.createElement('li');
newTask.innerText = 'Learn jQuery';

taskList.append(newTask);

With jQuery:

$('ul').append('<li>Learn jQuery</li>');

How to Use jQuery

First, import jQueryâs code into your webpage

Go to https://code.jquery.com

Get the latest, uncompressed version of jQuery

Copy and paste the provided script tag into your head

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <script
      src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.4.1.js"
      integrity="sha256-WpOohJOqMqqyKL9FccASB9O0KwACQJpFTUBLTYOVvVU="
      crossorigin="anonymous"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

Now you can use jQuery constructor function

jQuery();

Youâll end up calling this function a lot, so they have a shortcut

$();

Getting Elements with jQuery

$(selector)

Return jQuery object with all elements that match the selector

Reference: jQuery API Docs: jQuery()

jQuery
$('#main-content');

$('p');

// No equivalent in jQuery
Built-in JavaScript
document.querySelectorAll('#main-content');

document.querySelectorAll('p');

document.querySelector('p');

DOM Manipulation with jQuery

You can find a list of jQuery methods related to DOM manipulation under the Manipulation category of the jQuery docs

jQuery API Docs: Category: Manipulation

Letâs look at some examples and compare them to the built-in API

Change CSS classes

jQuery
$('#main-content').addClass('fancy');

$('#main-content').hasClass('fancy');

$('#main-content').removeClass('fancy');
Built-in JavaScript
document.querySelector('#main-content')
  .classList.add('fancy');

document.querySelector('#main-content')
  .classList.contains('fancy');

document.querySelector('#main-content')
  .classList.remove('fancy');

Change CSS classes of all elements that match selector

jQuery
$('p').addClass('fancy');
Built-in JavaScript
const paragraphs = document
  .querySelectorAll('p');

for (const p of paragraphs) {
  p.classList.add('fancy');
}

Change attributes

jQuery
$('img').attr('src');
// => "cat.jpg"

$('img').attr('src', 'cat2.gif');
Built-in JavaScript
document.querySelector('img')
  .getAttribute('src');

document.querySelector('img')
  .setAttribute('src', 'cat2.gif');

Replace HTML inside element

jQuery
$('a').html();
// => "About"

$('a').html('About Me');
Built-in JavaScript
document.querySelector('a').innerHTML;
// => "About"

document.querySelector('a')
  .innerHTML = 'About Me';

Add HTML inside element

<ul>
  <li>Do something fun on the weekend!</li>
  <li>Buy myself a cupcake</li>
</ul>

$('ul').append('<li>Learn jQuery!</li>');

$('ul').prepend('<li>Learn about the DOM</li>');
Result
<ul>
  <li>Learn about the DOM</li>
  <li>Do something fun on the weekend!</li>
  <li>Buy myself a cupcake</li>
  <li>Learn jQuery!</li>
</ul>

Remove element (also removes children of that element)

jQuery
$('ul').remove();
Built-in JavaScript
document.querySelector('ul').remove();

Remove all children of element (keep parent element)

jQuery
$('ul').empty();
Built-in JavaScript
const ul = document
  .querySelector('ul');

for (const li of ul.children) {
  li.remove();
}

Show/hide elements

jQuery
$('img').hide();

$('img').show();
Built-in JavaScript
document.querySelector('img')
  .style.display = 'none';

document.querySelector('img')
  .style.display = '';

jQuery or Built-in JavaScript?

It depends!

  • Everything you do in jQuery can be done with built-in JavaScript
  • jQuery is more readable and less verbose
    • If you need to do lots of DOM manipulation, use jQuery
  • However, jQuery is an external piece of code that takes some time to load
    • If youâre not doing tons of complex manipulations, built-in JS is fine

Coming Up

  • Browser event handling
  • AJAX
  • Object-oriented JavaScript

Further Study

  • Google V8 Engine Docs: Using JS modules in the browser
  • JavaScript is no longer the only programming language of the web! Check out WebAssembly
JavaScript and Event Handling

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

JavaScript and Event Handling

« Back to Homepage

  • JavaScript and Event Handling
    • Intro
      • Goals
    • Event Driven Programming
      • What is Event Driven Programming?
      • A Basic Event System
    • Event Handling in the Browser
      • Event Handling in the Browser
      • Common Event Types
      • Adding Event Listeners
      • Callback Functions
      • Who Calls the Callback Function
      • Event Handling with jQuery
    • The Event Object
      • The Event Object
      • Cancelling Events
      • Event Target
    • Further Study
      • Further Study

JavaScript and Event Handling

Intro

Goals

How to change web pages based on user interactions with event driven programming

Event Driven Programming

What is Event Driven Programming?

A way to design programs where code execution is triggered by events like

  • User actions, such as clicks and keypresses
  • Output from other programs
  • Other sensors, such as temperature, movement, pressure
  • Custom events that you define

A Basic Event System

Event-driven systems are used in many languages and applications

They all have the same basic parts

event source/event target
The button, sensor, etc. where the event is coming from
event emitter/event dispatcher
Notify the rest of the system that an event has occurred
event listeners and event handlers
Work together to listen for events and handle them by executing code
event loop
In charge of making all of the above work together

Event Handling in the Browser

In the browser, DOM elements are (one of many) sources of events

Common Event Types

MDN Web Docs: Event Reference

  • Mouse events
    • click â when you click on an element
    • dblclick â when you double-click on an element
    • mouseover â when the mouse is on top of an element
  • Input events
    • change â when the value of an input element changes
  • Form events
    • submit â when a form is submitted

Adding Event Listeners

HTMLElement.addEventListener(eventType, callback)

Add an event listener to HTMLElement

  • eventType â the type of event to listen for
  • callback â the function to call when that event happens
const button = document.querySelector('#angry-button');

button.addEventListener('click', () => {
  alert('Stop clicking me!');
});

Callback Functions

Callback functions are functions that we donât call right away

Instead, theyâre passed in as arguments so the program can call them later

Letâs break down the syntax in button.addEventListener

button.addEventListener(
  'click',

  () => {
    alert('Stop clicking me!');
  }
);
  • 'click' is the event type
  • 2nd argument is the callback function
Another way to write the above
const showAlert = () => {
  alert('Stop clicking me!');
}

button.addEventListener('click', showAlert);

Note that weâre passing in the function object

This wonât work:

button.addEventListener(
  'click',
  showAlert()  // Don't do this!
);

Why the code above doesnât work

It all has to do with objects and their data types. HTMLElement.addEventListener expects you to pass in a function object â it wonât work if you pass in a value with a different data type.

For example, hereâs a function definition:

const getGreeting = () => {
  return 'hello';
}

When the definition is executed, JavaScript creates an identifier called getGreeting and assigns it to a function object. When we access getGreeting, a function object is returned:

getGreeting;
// => function getGreeting()

typeof getGreeting;
// => "function"

This is different from accessing the result of calling getGreeting. The result of calling getGreeting isnât a function object â itâs a string:

getGreeting();
// => "hello"

typeof getGreeting();
// => "string"

Who Calls the Callback Function

We donât call callback functions â JavaScript does that for us!

  • JavaScript will listen for the event
  • If the event occurs, JavaScript handles the event for us by
    • Calling the appropriate function
    • Passing in arguments to that function

Event Handling with jQuery

const button = $('#jq-button');

button.on('click', () => {
  alert('Handled with jQuery!');
});
Shorter version of the above
$('#jq-button').on('click', () => {
  alert('Handled with jQuery!');
})

Another Way to Add an Event Listener

jQuery also supports a shorter syntax. To add a click-listener to an element, we teach:

$("#my-element").on("click", myFunction);

However, you can also say:

$("#my-element").click(myFunction);

However, this method is generally discouraged by the jQuery developers, as it is less obvious (are you listening for a click or making one happen?). Also, it is much more difficult to use this with custom events, as jQuery allows you to create new types of events as you get more advanced.

So: you may see this shorter form in some peopleâs code, but itâs best not to use it.

The Event Object

When JavaScript calls a function to handle an event,
it passes in one argument â the Event object

The Event object contains data about the event that had occurred

Event objects have methods and properties that let us do things like

  • Cancel the event
  • Get the event target (in this case, the HTMLElement where the event came from)
  • Get the position of the mouse when the event occurred

To access the Event object, our callback needs a parameter:

const eventBtn = document.querySelector('#event-btn');

eventBtn.addEventListener('click', (evt) => {
  console.log(evt);
});

Cancelling Events

Event.preventDefault()
Cancel an event
<a href="/secrets">Don't go to this page</a>

const secretLink = document.querySelector('a');

secretLink.addEventListener('click' (evt) => {
  evt.preventDefault();

  alert('I told you not to go to that page.');
});

This is useful when you want to validate data in a form before submitting it

<h4>Suggest a word!</h4>
<p>Your word must be > 5 characters long</p>

<form action="/suggest-word" method="POST">
  <input type="text" name="word">
  <input type="submit">
</form>

const wordForm = document.querySelector('form');

wordForm.addEventListener('submit', (evt) => {
  const wordInput = document.querySelector('input[name="word"]');

  if (wordInput.value.length < 5) {
    evt.preventDefault();
  }
});

Event Target

Event.target
Return the source of the event as an HTMLElement
<button id="event-target">See event target (in console)</button>

const targetBtn = document.querySelector('#event-target');

targetBtn.addEventListener('click', (evt) => {
  console.log(evt.target);
});

Event.target is an HTMLElement!

  • It has all properties and methods of HTMLElements

  • This is great when you need to extract info from the element that caused the event

  • If you prefer using jQuery, you can typecast it to a jQuery object with the $ function

    const btn = $(evt.target);

For example, we have a bunch of buttons.

We want to use each button to change the font-family of the page

<button class="font-changer" id="monospace">
  Change to monospace!
</button>
<button class="font-changer" id="sans-serif">
  Change to sans-serif!
</button>
<button class="font-changer" id="serif">
  Change to serif!
</button>

We could do it this way

$('#monospace').on('click', () => {
  $('body').css('fontFamily', 'monospace');
});

$('#sans-serif').on('click', () => {
  $('body').css('fontFamily', 'sans-serif');
});

$('#sans').on('click', () => {
  $('body').css('fontFamily', 'sans');
});

If we take advantage of Event.target, we can avoid repetition

$('button.font-changer').on('click', (evt) => {
  const button = $(evt.target);

  const buttonId = button.attr('id');

  $('body').css('fontFamily', buttonId);
});

Further Study

How to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Event Driven Programming in Python

NodeJS fundamentals: Events

AJAX

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

AJAX

« Back to Homepage

  • AJAX
    • Goals
      • Goals
    • JSON: A Recap
      • JSON

      • Why Use AJAX?
    • AJAX: How?
      • AJAX with jQuery
      • $.get
      • $.get Demo
      • $.get with Arguments
      • Asynchronicity
      • $.post
      • $.post Demo
      • A Melon, in Python
      • Demo!

      • AJAX
    • Learning More
      • jQuery AJAX Docs
      • Further Study

AJAX

Goals

  • Introduce AJAX, a technological cornerstone of modern websites
  • Use jQuery to send AJAX requests

JSON: A Recap

JSON

  • JSON is a string that represents a JavaScript object
  • In Python, it can be converted into a dictionary
  • JSON is the most common way that the browser gets/sends info to the server
  • Most APIs will send their responses in JSON

AJAX: Motivation

What is AJAX?

AJAX is a technology for sending requests and receiving responses from a server without having to reload the browser page.

AJAX == Asynchronous JavaScript and XML

AJAX originally was an acronym for âAsynchronous JavaScript and XMLâ.

However many people donât send XML over AJAX nowadays; itâs more common to send HTML or JSON.

The technology is still the same, though, even if the data payload is usually different.

Regular Request

AJAX Request

Why Use AJAX?

  • Donât need to reload the entire page if just 1 thing is changing
  • Interactive web sites
  • Fewer âround-tripsâ to server
    • Your JS can talk to other servers directly
  • Less load on your server
  • CORE JOB SKILL

AJAX: How?

AJAX with jQuery

Pretty much all Javascript frameworks, including jQuery, include helper functions to make AJAX calls without having to enter all the complex, finicky AJAX code directly.

$.get('/adjective', (data) => {
    alert(data);
});

$.get

$.get(url, successFunction)
  • url â the GET request URL
  • successFunction â the function to call when we get a response from the server

$.get Demo

ajax-demo/server.py
@app.route("/adjective")
def get_random_adjective():
    """Return a simple adjective."""

    return random.choice(ADJECTIVES)
ajax-demo/static/js/adjective.js
$.get('/adjective', (response) => {
  $('#adjective').text(response);
});

$.get with Arguments

$.get(url, data, successFunction)
  • data â an object; each key-value pair gets sent via query string
ajax-demo/server.py
@app.route("/status")
def get_order_status():
    """Get order status."""

    order_number = request.args.get("order")

    if order_number == "123":
        return random.choice(["LATE", "SUPER-LATE"])
    else:
        return "ON-TIME"
ajax-demo/static/js/order-status.js
$('#update-status').on('click', () => {
  // Our GET request URL will look like this:
  //       /status?order=123
  $.get('/status', { order: 123 }, (res) => {
    $('#order-status').html(res);
  });
});

Asynchronicity

What happens when we call
$.get(url, successFunction)

  • A GET request is made to url
    • This may take a while!
  • $.get waits for the serverâs response
    • This may take a while too!
  • When the response comes back successfully, successFunction is called

jQuery.load

You might also find $element.load to be useful.

$('element').load('/get_content') replaces the content of the element with the result returned (via AJAX) at the given URL.

$.post

$.post(url, data, successFunction)
Similar to $.get, but uses a POST request

$.post Demo

ajax-demo/server.py
@app.route("/new-order", methods=["POST"])
def add_order():
    """Add a melon order to our database."""

    melon_type = request.form.get("type")
    amount = request.form.get("amount")

    return "Your order has been confirmed"
ajax-demo/static/js/submit-order.js
$('#order-form').on('submit', (evt) => {
  evt.preventDefault();

  const formInputs = {
    'type': $('#type-field').val(),
    'amount': $('#amount-field').val()
  };

  $.post('/new-order', formInputs, (res) => {
    alert(res);
  });
});

Form âSerializationâ

In the above example, weâre getting the the form values in Javascript like this:

ajax-demo/static/js/submit-order.js
const formInputs = {
  'type': $('#type-field').val(),
  'amount': $('#amount-field').val()
};

This is fine, but it can be awkward if you have lots of fields, and can feel like lots of cut-and-paste.

When youâre ready, you can investigate jQueryâs form.serialize method. This turns a form into a Javascript object, ready to be handed off in AJAX.

For example, given the following form:

<form id="color-form">
  Name: <input type="text" name="name">
  Color: <input type="text" name="color">
</form>

You could get all that data into an object like:

const formValues = $('#color-form').serialize();

And then hand it off in a jQuery get or post AJAX call like so:

$.post("/color-report", formValues, resultHandler);

A Melon, in Python

We want to return a dictionary from a Flask route:

ajax-demo/server.py
@app.route("/melon-info.py")
def melon_info_py():
    """This route will fail!"""

    melon = {
        "id": "watermelon",
        "name": "Watermelon",
        "price": 5.00,
        "available": True,
        "countries": ["US", "CA", "MX"]
    }

    return melon

Problem: You canât return a raw Python dictionary from a Flask route.

Solution: Convert dictionary to JSON using Flaskâs jsonify function

Remember to import jsonify!

from flask import Flask, request, render_template, jsonify, request_finished
ajax-demo/server.py
@app.route("/melon-info.json")
def melon_info():
    """Return info about a melon as JSON."""

    # In real life, we would probably get this info
    # from our database
    melon = {
        "id": "watermelon",
        "name": "Watermelon",
        "price": 5.00,
        "available": True,
        "countries": ["US", "CA", "MX"]
    }

    return jsonify(melon)

Demo!

ajax-demo/server.py
@app.route("/delivery-info.json")
def get_delivery_info():
    """Get delivery info."""

    address = request.args.get("address")
    city = request.args.get("city")

    if city in CITY_DELIVERY_INFO:
        return jsonify(CITY_DELIVERY_INFO[city])
    else:
        return jsonify(CITY_DELIVERY_INFO["other"])
ajax-demo/static/js/delivery-time.js
$('#delivery-form').on('submit', (evt) => {
  evt.preventDefault();

  // Get user input from a form
  const formData = {
    city: $('#city-field').val(),
    address: $('#adr-field').val()
  };

  // Send formData to the server (becomes a query string)
  $.get('/delivery-info.json', formData, (res) => {
    // Display response from the server
    alert(`This will cost $${res.cost}`);
    alert(`This will arrive in ${res.days} day(s)`);
  });
});

Style tip: if a Flask route returns JSON, make it obvious:

@app.route("/tuition.json")
def get_tuition():
    """Return information about tuition as JSON."""

    return jsonify({"tuition": 1000})
Or you can do it this way
@app.route("/api/tuition")
def get_tuition():
  """Return information about tuition as JSON."""

  return jsonify({"tuition": 1000})

Complex AJAX

Thereâs another jQuery function â $.ajax!

You can use it to make more complex requests.

$.ajax(url, settings-object)

  • settings â object with key/values for settings

This can handle:

  • Telling server what kind of data to give back
  • Making a synchronous request
  • Custom error handlers
  • Setting headers on the request
  • Sending authentication info

â¦and more! There are more details in the official docs.

What Did We learn?

AJAX

  • Send requests and receive responses without having to reload the browser page
  • Weâll use jQueryâs implementation:
    • $.get(url, [data,] successFunction)
    • $.post(url, [data,] successFunction)
  • When sending/receiving data, send it as JSON, using jsonify

Learning More

jQuery AJAX Docs

https://api.jquery.com/category/ajax/

Further Study

  • JavaScript async/await â make asynchronous code look like synchronous code
  • JavaScript Promises â supports success and failure callbacks
React 2

Hackbright Engineering June 2018

React 2

« Back to Homepage

  • React 2
    • Intro
      • Review: Components
      • Goals
    • Event Handlers
      • Click Event
      • Other Event Types
    • State
      • The Basic Idea
      • Demo: Dice
      • Updating State
      • Properties v State
      • Component Lifecycle
      • Lifecycle Methods
      • componentDidMount and AJAX
      • Further Study

React 2

Intro

Review: Components

  • Custom properties are stored as key-value pairs on this.props

    class Hello extends React.Component {
  render() {
    return (<p>Hello {this.props.to} from {this.props.from}!</p>);
  }
}

  • Render component to DOM with ReactDOM.render

    ReactDOM.render(
  <Hello to="World" from="Balloonicorn"/>,
  document.getElementById('root')
);

Goals

  • Event handling
  • Component state
  • Component lifecycle
  • Making AJAX requests

Event Handlers

Click Event

react-2-demo/static/clicker.jsx
class HelloClicker extends React.Component {
  alertMessage() {
    alert('You just handled an event!');
  }

  render() {
    return (
      <button onClick={this.alertMessage}>
        Click me
      </button>
    );
  }
}

Other Event Types

Look like browser events, but in camelCase

  • onSubmit
  • onChange
  • onMouseOver
  • And more!

React Docs: Supported Events

State

The Basic Idea

React was created to make it easier to develop complex UI that reacts to events

Changes to UI are driven by changes to a component’s state

Here’s how it works

  • Components can keep track of state — data used to configure how a component should look
  • It uses those differences to update the DOM in an efficient way

Demo: Dice

We’re making a role playing game, __Dunder__ & Dragons

  • We need dice components for users to roll!
  • There are many different types of dice, with different # of sides (4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 20)
    • An individual die’s # of sides never changes though
sides
Number of sides of die
// For example:
<Die sides="6" />
  • Users should click on a die to “roll” it & see results
  • The result can change every time they roll

Properties can’t change, but state can!

value
Current result of die after a die-roll
(let’s make initial value of state = ‘?’)
react-2-demo/static/die.jsx
class Die extends React.Component {
  constructor() {
    super();

    this.state = { value: '?' };  // Set initial value
    this.roll = this.roll.bind(this);
  }

  roll() {
    const rollResult = getRandomNum(this.props.sides);

    // Update state in callback
    this.setState({ value: rollResult });
  }

  render() {
    // Use state in render method to change DOM
    return (
      <button className="die" onClick={this.roll}>
        <i>sides={this.props.sides}</i>
        <b>{this.state.value}</b>
      </button>
    );
  }
}
  • Instance attribute state = initial state
    • Initial value is '?'
  • Property sides = # of sides
    • Use this.props.sides to generate random num
  • On click, call function this.roll
    • Change this.state.value to rollResult
  • React re-renders die since state changed

Updating State

React handles changing the DOM

  • You handle when component’s state should change
  • React detects change, then decides where to update DOM (if needed)
  • It is very efficient about this

Always update state with this.setState({ ... })

  • Never do it directly with this.state = { ... }
  • Otherwise, React won’t notice the change

Updating part of this.state

this.setState can intelligently decide which part of this.state to update.

For example, let’s say you keep track of several things in this.state, like so:

// Example state that keeps track of month, day, year
this.state = {
  month: 'Nov',
  day: 22,
  year: 1963
};

To update year, we don’t have to make a copy of month or day. We can simply pass in an object with the updated value for year:

this.setState({ year: 2018 });

// DON'T do this:
// this.setState({
//   month: this.state.month,
//   day: this.state.day,
//   year: 2018
// });

this.setState updates the specified property and leaves the others unchanged.

Properties v State

Properties are usually set by the parent

  • Properties are immutable
  • They’re used to configure components (since components should be reuseable)

State has an initial value and changes over the component’s lifetime

  • Changes to state trigger re-rendering of the component and its children
  • Use a combination of state changes and props to make interactive UI

Component Lifecycle

Components are born — then they change — then they die

  • Lifecycle methods get called during stages of component’s life
    • constructor and render are called after component enters DOM
  • Override these methods to execute code during a stage of component’s life
    • Example — after component mounts, send AJAX request; use data to change initial state

Lifecycle Methods

  1. constructor
  2. componentWillMount
  3. render
  4. componentDidMount

(If you’re curious, there are more lifecycle methods that are not mentioned in this lecture)

componentDidMount and AJAX

You can use AJAX to populate React components with info from your Flask server

Set up a route that returns JSON

react-2-demo/server.py
@app.route('/api/fruits')
def get_fruits():
    """Return a list of all melons."""

    time.sleep(2)  # Simulate a slow internet connection

    return jsonify([{'fruit_id': 1,
                     'name': 'apple'},
                    {'fruit_id': 2,
                     'name': 'berry'},
                    {'fruit_id': 3,
                     'name': 'cherry'}])

Then, in your React component...

react-2-demo/static/fruits.jsx
class Fruits extends React.Component {
  constructor() {
    super();

    this.state = {
      fruits: [],
      isLoaded: false
    };
  }

  componentDidMount() {
    $.get('/api/fruits', (result) => {
      this.setState({ fruits: result, isLoaded: true });
    });
  }

  render() {
    const fruits = this.state.fruits;

    const fruitListItems = fruits.map((fruit) => {
      return (<li key={fruit.fruit_id}>{fruit.name}</li>);
    });

    if (this.state.isLoaded) {
      return (
        <ul>
          {fruitListItems}
        </ul>
      );
    } else {
      return <p>Loading...</p>;
    }
  }
}

Further Study

  • Instead of using jQuery to make AJAX requests, look into using the built-in AJAX module, fetch
    • The official React docs have a good example: React Docs: AJAX and APIs
  • React Router — allows your React app to have multiple pages with links
  • Redux — for complex state management
